PT J
AN ZOOR15010052188
DT Article
TI Bats (Mammalia: Chiroptera) of the Eastern Mediterranean and Middle
   East. Part 10. Bat fauna of Iran.
AU Benda, Petr (petr_benda@nm.cz) 
   Faizolahi, Kaveh
   Andreas, Michal
   Obuch, Jan
   Reiter, Antonin
   Sevcik, Martin
   Uhrin, Marcel
   Vallo, Peter
   Ashrafi, Sohrab
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 76
IS 3-4
PS 163-582
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A complete list of bat records available from Iran was compiled from
   literature and from new records, based on field studies and examination
   of museum specimens. The record review is complemented by distribution
   maps, summaries of distributional status of the particular species,
   files of field data, findings on feeding ecology, and observations of
   morphology and variation. Basic descriptive echolocation parameters for
   at least 24 species (426 calls from 68 call sequences analysed) are
   given and discussed. From the territory of Iran, at least 902 records of
   50 bat species belonging to eight families are known; viz. Rousettus
   aegyptiacus (Geoffroy, 1810) (33 record sites), Rhinopoma microphyllum
   (Brannich, 1782) (38), R. muscatellum Thomas, 1903 (42), R. hardwickii
   Gray, 1831 (12), Rhinolophus ferrumequinum (Schreber, 1774) (61), R.
   hipposideros (Borkhausen, 1797) (36), R. euryale Blasius, 1853 (17), R.
   mehelyi Matschie, 1901 (14), R. blasii Peters, 1866 (28), Hipposideros
   fulvus Gray, 1838 (1), Asellia tridens (Geoffroy, 1813) (37), Triaenops
   persicus Dobson, 1871(5), Taphozous perforatus Geoffroy, 1818 (7), T.
   nudiventris Cretzschmar, 1830 (11), Myotis blythii (Tomes, 1857) (98), M
   bechsteinii (Kuhl, 1817) (4), M nattereri (Kuhl, 1817) (2), M schaubi
   Kormos, 1935 (10), M. emarginatus (Geoffroy, 1806) (20), M mystacinus
   morpho-group (23), M capaccinii (Bonaparte, 1837) (11), Vespertilio
   murinus Linnaeus, 1758 (7), Eptesicus serotinus (Schreber, 1774) (25),
   E. pachyomus (Tomes, 1857) (2), E. nilssonii (Keyserling et Blasius,
   1839) (2), E. bobrinskoi Kuzakin, 1935 (1), E. anatolicus Felten, 1971
   (10), E. bottae (Peters, 1869) (2), E. ognevi Bobrinskoj, 1918 (5),
   Rhyneptesicus nasutus (Dobson, 1877) (9), Hypsugo savii (Bonaparte,
   1837) (19), H. arabicus (Harrison, 1979) (1), Pipistrellus pipistrellus
   (Schreber, 1774) (63), P pygmaeus (Leach, 1825) (2), P kuhlii (Kuhl,
   1817) (107), Nyctalus noctula (Schreber, 1774) (6), N. lasiopterus
   (Schreber, 1780) (1), N. leisleri (Kuhl, 1817) (9), Otonycteris
   hemprichii Peters, 1859 (15), O. leucophaea (Severcov, 1873) (3),
   Barbastella barbastellus (Schreber, 1774) (4), B. darjelingensis
   (Hodgson, 1855) (6), Plecotus auritus (Linnaeus, 1758) (1), P
   macrobullaris Kuzakin, 1965 (12), P strelkovi Spitzenberger, 2006 (1-2),
   Miniopterus pallidus Thomas, 1907 (50), Tadarida teniotis (Rafinesque,
   1814) (26), and Nyctinomus aegyptiacus Geoffroy, 1818(3). Hipposideros
   fulvus and Myotis nattereri are here reported from the country for the
   first time, while Rhinolophus bocharicus Kasenko et Akimov, 1917 has
   been deleted from the faunal list of Iran. Reviews of taxonomic opinions
   concerning the Iranian populations of particular species, supplemented
   in some cases by original analyses, are added. Three species were
   detected within the Myotis mystacinus morpho-group in Iran: M.
   mystacinus (Kuhl, 1817), M davidii (Peters, 1869) and here described M.
   hyrcanicus sp. n. Within the species rank of Nyctinomus aegyptiacus, a
   separate species occurring in south-western Asia has been documented, N.
   thomasi (Wroughton, 1919). Arthropod ectoparasites were newly collected
   from 14 species of bats; altogether 36 species of ectoparasites
   belonging to twelve families were recorded from Iran. The following
   species are here reported from the country for the first time:
   Ischnopsyllus dolosus Dampf, 1912 (collected from Myotis
   blythii),Ischnopsyllus petropolitanus (Wagner, 1898) (from Plecotus
   macrobullaris), Stricticimex namru Usinger, 1960 (from a mixed colony),
   Basilia nana Theodor et Moscona, 1954 (from Myotis bechsteinii and M.
   nattereri), Nycteribia latreillii Leach, 1817) (from Myotis blythii and
   M capaccinii), Steatonyssus periblepharus Kolenati, 1858 (from
   Pipistrellus kuhlii), Spinturnix myoti (Kolenati, 1856) (from Myotis
   blythii), Spinturnix psi (Kolenati, 1856) (from Myotis capaccinii and
   Miniopterus pallidus), and Meristaspis lateralis Kolenati, 1857 (from
   Rousettus aegyptiacus and Pipistrellus kuhlii).
C1 Benda, Petr; Natl Museum Nat Hist, Dept Zool, Vaclavske 68, Prague,
   CZ-11579, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM petr_benda@nm.cz
RI Benda, Petr/B-5437-2011; Vallo, Peter/F-9650-2014
SC Zoology; Education &Educational Research
SN 1211-376X
BD Animals and man; Education and entertainment; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chiroptera [Museums collections and exhibitions /  / new record]
   [Literature review /  / ] [Iran /  / biology; distribution]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia
OR Chiroptera (Mammalia): [New record].

TI Chionodes meridiochilensis sp nov from Chile: contribution to an
   understanding of its biology and description of its early stages
   (Insecta: Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae).
AU Edward King, Gareth (Sterrhinae@gmail.com) 
   Viejo Montesinos, Jose Luis
SO Acta Zoologica Cracoviensia
VL 55
IS 1
PS 45-58
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB G. E. KING, J. L. VIEJO MONTESINOS. 2012. Chionodes meridiochilensis sp.
   nov. from Chile: contribution to an understanding of its biology and
   description of its early stages (Insecta: Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae).
   Acta zool. cracov., 55(1): 45-58. Chionodes meridiochilensis sp. nov. is
   described from south central Chile from larvae collected in January
   2011. In addition, the present paper describes the morphology and the
   chaetotaxy of the fifth instar larva, as well as the pupa. Data is also
   presented on the bionomics of this new gelechiid species, including
   feeding strategies and food-plant.

   (Insecta: Lepidoptera; Gelechiidae) a new species from Chile. Acta zool.

TI Natural enemies associated to Diaphorina citri Kuwayama (Hemiptera:
   Psyllidae) in Citrus latifolia Tanaka, in the state of Nayarit, Mexico.
FT Enemigos naturales asociados a Diaphorina citri Kuwayama (Hemiptera:
   Psyllidae) en limon persa (Citrus latifolia tanaka) en Nayarit, Mexico.
AU Rodriguez-Palomera, Marcia (jhony695@gmail.com) 
   Cambero-Campos, Jhonathan
   Robles-Bermudez, Agustin

VL 28
IS 3
PS 625-629
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB Natural enemies associated to Diaphorina citri in the state of Nayarit
   were identified. The study was carried Out in three orchards of Persian
   lime from May to October 2011. The identified depredator species were
   Olla v-nigrum, Chilocorzis cacti, Cycloneda sanguinea, and Ceraeochrysa
   sp.; as well as the parasitoid Tamarixia radiata and the
   entomopathogenic Beauveria bassiana. Nephus sp. Mulsant, 1850 and
   Pentilia sp. Mulsant, 1850 are new distribution records to Mexico.

SO African Natural History
VL 8
PS 16-29
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Recent genetic studies have shown that the South African crown crab,
   Hymenosoma orbiculare, in fact represents five distinct species, three
   of which are new to science and one of which needs to be resurrected.
   Three of these species occur in the southwestern Cape, the remaining two
   being found in estuaries on the South East and East coasts of South
   Africa. Based on genetic evidence and morphological analyses, H.
   geometricum Stimpson, 1858 is no longer considered a junior synonym of
   H. orbiculare, and is resurrected as a full species. A deeper-water
   species from False Bay, H. trilobatum sp. nov. as well as two East coast
   species, H. longicrure sp. nov. and H. projectum sp. nov., are
   described. The true H. orbiculare ranges from Walvis Bay in Namibia to
   the Gqunube Estuary near East London. H. geometricum and H. trilobatum
   sp. nov. are both found in deeper water and are currently known only
   from False Bay. H. longicrure sp. nov. is found from the Qolora Estuary
   to the Mngazi Estuary in the Eastern Cape and H. projectum sp. nov.
   along the east coast from the Mzimvubu Estuary to Lake Sibaya and Kosi
   Bay. The size and shape of the rostrum and ornamentation of the carapace
   are the main features distinguishing species. H. orbiculare has a
   smooth, simple rostrum and only two pairs of plain teeth on the
   carapace; H. geometricum has a very complex, long, trilobate rostrum and
   three pairs of complex, granulate teeth on the carapace; H. trilobatum
   sp. nov. has a less complex, extended, trilobate rostrum with smooth
   margins and granulate surface, with only two pairs of teeth on the
   carapace; H. longicrure sp. nov. and H. projectum sp. nov. both have a
   simple rostrum, little ornamentation on the carapace and unusual
   abdominal projections.
C1 Dawson, Jessica; Univ Cape Town, Dept Zool, Cape Town, ZA-7701, South
   Africa, South Africa.
EM jessica.dawson@uct.ac.za
SC Zoology
SN 1816-8396
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Marine zones;
   Atlantic Ocean; Indian Ocean
DE Hymenosoma longicrure; Hymenosoma projectum [South Indian Ocean / South
   Africa / New species]. 
   Hymenosoma trilobatum [South Atlantic / South Africa / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Hymenosoma - Desmarest 1825 (Brachyura): [Revision, P. 16; Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 27]. 
   Hymenosoma geometricum - Stimpson 1858 (Brachyura): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Hymenosoma orbiculare Desmarest 1825, p. 19]. 
   Hymenosoma longicrure (Brachyura): [Sp nov, South Africa (marine), P.
   21]. 
   Hymenosoma orbiculare - Desmarest 1825 (Brachyura): [Removal from
   synonymy, Hymenosoma geometricum Stimpson 1858, p. 19].

   23].

   21].

PT J
AN ZOOR15006029901
DT Article
TI Cretaceous faunas from Zululand and Natal, South Africa. The
   desmoceratoid ammonite genera Moretella Collignon, 1963, Beudanticeras
   Hitzel, 1902, and Aioloceras Whitehouse, 1926.
AU Kennedy, William James (jim.kennedy@oum.ox.ac.uk) 
   Klinger, Herbert Christian
SO African Natural History
VL 8
PS 55-75
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Three taxa of desmoceratoid ammonites are recognized in the Lower Albian
   of northern KwaZulu-Natal, all of them previously known only from
   Madagascar: Moretella sp., Beudanticeras komihevitraense Collignon,
   1950, and Aioloceras besairiei (Collignon, 1949). Madagascan type and
   figured material, much of it difficult to interpret from the original
   figures is re-illustrated, and the intraspecific variation and
   dimorphism in Moretella and Aioloceras are documented.
C1 Kennedy, William James; Univ Oxford, Museum Nat Hist, Parks Rd, Oxford,
   OX1 3PR, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM jim.kennedy@oum.ox.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 1816-8396

   Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Africa / Kwazulu-Natal / new record; systematics] [Cretaceous / Lower
   Albian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   record].

   New record].

   Paracleoniceras - Collignon 1963 (Ammonitida): [Status, P. 58].

TI A new peculiar species of Chrysotus from the Far East of Russia
   (Dolichopodidae, Diptera).
AU Grichanov, I.Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
SO Amurskii Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
IS 4
PS 333-335
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new long-legged fly species Chrysotus chukotkensis sp. nov. from the
   Primorskii Krai Province of Russia is described and illustrated. A key
   to species of Chrysotus albipalpus and C. longipalpus groups is
   supplied.

PT J

DT Article
TI New data for a revision of the genus Ctenolepisma (Zygentoma:
   Lepismatidae): redescription of Ctenolepisma lineata and new status for
   Ctenolepisma nicoletii.
AU Molero Baltanas, Rafael (balmobar@uco.es) 
   Gaju Ricart, Miguel
   Bach de Roca, Carmen
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 48
IS 1-2
PS 66-80
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB As a starting point for the revision of the genus Ctenolepisma Escherich
   1905, the status of its type-species, Ctenolepisma lineata (Fabricius
   1775), is clarified. In the present study, this species (originally
   described from Switzerland) is redescribed by means of many samples from
   several European countries and a neotype is designated. The constant
   presence of a third pair of abdominal styli in adult C. lineata s. str.
   leads to abandon the obsolete name C. lineata var. pilifera (Lucas 1840)
   for referring to a presumed non-typical variety of this species. The
   status of Lepisma pilifera Lucas 1840 is discussed, concluding that this
   name must be treated as a new synonym of Thermobia aegyptiaca (Lucas
   1840). After our redefinition of the characters of C. lineata, an
   examination of many specimens of Ctenolepisma that were previously
   identified as C. lineata reveals that some of them are actually members
   of different taxa. This is the case for a species occurring in the
   Canary Islands, Northwest Africa, the Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic
   Islands. In this work this species is ascribed to Lepisma nicoletii
   Lucas 1846, which was described from Algeria and regarded as a synonym
   of Ctenolepisma lineata by Escherich; this species is now redescribed as
   Ctenolepisma nicoletii stat. res. This species differs from C. lineata
   in that it bears only two pairs of abdominal styli, and it also differs
   in the shape of the prosternum and femoral scales. Lepisma eatoni Ridley
   1881, which was described from Morocco and the Canary Islands and
   subsequently regarded as synonym of C. lineata, is now synonymised with
   C. nicoletii.
C1 Molero Baltanas, Rafael; Univ Cordoba, Dept Zool C1, Campus Rabanales,
   Cordoba, 14014, Spain, Spain.
EM balmobar@uco.es
SC Zoology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Synonymy; Land
   zones
DE Ctenolepisma; Ctenolepisma lineata; Ctenolepisma nicoletii [Palaearctic
   region /  / Biology; distribution; new record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanura
OR Ctenolepisma - Escherich 1905 (Thysanura): [New record]. 
   Ctenolepisma lineata - (Fabricius 1775) (Thysanura): [Redescription, P.
   68; Synonymy, P. 75; Senior synonym, Of Lepisma subvittata Guerin 1838,
   p. 75; Senior synonym, Of Lepisma vittata Fabricius 1798, p. 70; Removal
   from synonymy, Ctenolepisma nicoletii Lucas 1846, p. 70; New record]. 
   Ctenolepisma nicoletii - (Lucas 1846) (Thysanura): [Redescription, P.
   70; Syn nov, Ctenolepisma lineata var. eatoni (Ridley 1881), p. 70;
   Removal from synonymy, With Ctenolepisma lineata (Fabricius 1775), p.
   70; New record]. 
   Lepisma - Linnaeus 1758 (Thysanura): [Systematics, P. 75]. 
   Lepisma lineata - Fabricius 1775 (Thysanura): [Neotype designated, P.
   69]. 
   Lepisma nicoletii - Lucas 1846 (Thysanura): [Neotype designated, P. 73].
   
   Lepisma subvittata - Guerin 1838 (Thysanura): [Junior synonym, Of
   Ctenolepisma lineata (Fabricius 1775), p. 75]. 
   Lepisma vittata - Fabricius 1798 (Thysanura): [Junior synonym, Of
   Ctenolepisma lineata (Fabricius 1775), p. 70]. 
   Thermobia aegyptiaca - Lucas 1840 (Thysanura): [Neotype designated, P.
   75; Syn nov, Lepisma pilifera Lucas 1840, p. 74]. 
DI 10.1080/00379271.2012.10697753

AN ZOOR15010051378
DT Article
TI On the Pseudoxyporus species of East Siberia and description of a new
   species from China (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae: Oxyporinae).
AU Makranczy, Gy (makranczy@nhmus.hu) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 111-126
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus-group name Pseudoxyporus is currently of dubious status.
   Available facts about the distinctness of the group are presented. The
   species in the Russian Far East are reviewed based on examination of
   types and previously unstudied material, the three names include the
   oldest one in the East Palearctic. Lectotype is designated for Oxyporus
   dybowskii SOLSKY, 1871. The diagnostic value of the internal sclerites
   in the aedeagi is discussed. A new species with peculiar colouration is
   described: Oxyporus (Pseudoxyporus) tessellatus sp. n. (Yunnan, China).
   Habitus and male genitalia are illustrated for all species. With 25
   figures.
C1 Makranczy, Gy; Hungarian Natl Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross Utca 13,
   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM makranczy@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Oxyporus (Pseudoxyporus) tessellatus [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae

   (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P. 115]. 
   Oxyporus (Pseudoxyporus) dybowskii - Solsky 1871 (Staphylinidae):
   [Redescription, P. 121].

   (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P. 122].

   P. 124]. 
   Oxyporus dybowskii - Solsky 1871 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 116].

DT Article
TI Two new Stenaesthetus species from Tanzania (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae:
   Euaesthetinae).
AU Puthz, V. (stenus.puthz@t-online.de) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 127-130
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new Stenaesthetus SHARP, 1874 species are described from Tanzania:
   Stenaesthetus minimus sp. n. (Tanzania: Tanga region) and S. usambarae
   sp. n. (Tanzania: West Usambra Mts), the former is remarkable as the
   smallest known member of the genus. With 4 figures.

DT Article
TI Description of new species in the Leucotrichiini tribe (Trichoptera:
   Hydroptilidae).
AU Olah, J. (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Flint, O.S., Jr
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 131-213
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Hydroptilid Leucotrichiini tribe is limited to the New World. Set aside
   material collected in the Neotropical Realm during the last 60 years is
   elaborated, identified and described in this paper. Besides routine
   template description of specimens preserved in alcohol, the coloration
   of field pinned examples is also described. Totally 49 new species in
   the Leucotrichiini tribe of the hydroptilid genera Abtrichia MOSELY,
   1939 (2 spp.), Acostatrichia MOSELY, 1939 (12 spp.), Alisotrichia FLINT,
   1964 (1 sp.), Anchitrichia FLINT, 1970 (4 spp.), Ascotrichia FLINT, 1983
   (1 sp.), Betrichia MOSELY, 1939 (2 spp.), Ceratotrichia FLINT, 1992 (2
   spp.), Zumatrichia MOSELY, 1937 (25 spp.) are described and illustrated.
   New records for 13 species are given. With 157 figures an 4 tables.
C1 Olah, J.; Tarjan U 28, Debrecen, H-4032, Hungary, Hungary.
EM profolah@gmail.com

SN 0521-4726

TI New species and records of Neotropical Macronematinae and Smicrideinae
   (Trichoptera: Hydropsychidae).
AU Otah, J. (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Johanson, K.A.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 215-297
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fifty-four new species in the hydropsychid genera Centromacronema ULMER,
   1905 (3 new species), Leptonema GUERIN-MENEVILLE, 1843 (10 new species),
   Macronema PICTET, 1836 (2 new species), Macrostemurn KOLENATI, 1859 (1
   new species), and Smicridea MCLACHLAN, 1871 (38 new species) are
   described and illustrated. New records of 48 species in the above listed
   genera, as well as Plectromacronema ULMER, 1906, are given. With 287
   figures and 1 table.

DT Article
TI Description of an Ocaria species from the Venezuelan Pantepuy
   (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae: Theclinae).
AU Balint, Zs. (balint@nhmus.hu) 
   Costa, M.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 299-310
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ocaria elisa sp. n. (Lycaenidae: Theclinae: Eumaeini) is described from
   the Guyana Shield in Venezuela. It is unique amongst congeners having
   the combination of the following external characters, (1) relatively
   large size compared with congeners, (2) black male dorsal forewing
   surface, (3) a dorsal forewing androconial cluster in the apical part of
   the discal cell, and (4) patternless ventral hindwing submedial area. A
   key for the species groups, notes on the diversity of the genus,
   discussion on the external characters of the species, and a checklist of
   the species are given. With 16 figures.
C1 Balint, Zs.; Hungarian Natl Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross Utca 13,
   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM balint@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Ocaria [Checklists / Distributional & taxonomic checklist / ]. 
   Ocaria elisa [Venezuela /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae
OR Ocaria - Clench 1970 (Lycaenidae): [Key to species groups, Male
   characters, p. 300]. 
   Ocaria arpoxais species group (Lycaenidae): [Key to species, Male
   characters, p. 300]. 
   Ocaria elisa (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 301].

DT Article
TI Types of the Bathyaulax Szepligeti species in the Hungarian Natural
   History Museum (Hymenoptera, Braconidae: Braconinae).
AU Papp, J. (j.papp1933@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 331-367
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Types of seven Bathyaulax species described by SZEPLIGETI from tropical
   Africa are valid (B. bicolor SZEPLIGETI, 1906, B. concolor SZEPLIGETI,
   1906, B. cyanogaster SZEPLIGETI, 1901, B. perspicax SZEPLIGETI, 1905, B.
   rufus SZEPLIGETI, 1906, B. transitus SZEPLIGETI, 1913) and one name (B.
   areolatus SZEPLIGETI, 1913) is junior synonym of B. kersteni
   (GERSTAECKER, 1871). B. transitus is resurrected from the synonymy of
   Megagonia rufa SZEPLIGETI, 1906. These seven species and B. martinii
   (GRIBoDo, 1879) are redescribed, and a key is given for them. A list of
   the 52 species of Bathyaulax is given with subgeneric affiliation of the
   species. With 124 figures.

   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.

PT J
AN ZOOR15010051387
DT Article
TI Vertesella (Colloniidae), a new genus in a Middle Jurassic gastropod
   faunula from the Vertes Mts (Hungary).
AU Szabo, J. (jszabo@nhmus.hu) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 104
PS 417-430
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Remains of six gastropods are available from an outcrop that is one of
   the rare Jurassic fossil localities in the Vertes Mts. Most shells are
   poorly preserved; however, a single specimen indicates a new genus,
   Vertesella gen. n. with its type species, Vertesella vertesensis sp. n.
   in the faunula. Shell morphology suggests that it belongs to Colloniidae
   of its original diagnosis; pre-Cretaceous origin of this family seems
   very likely from a group of Jurassic genera, however, not all
   malacologists share this opinion. The occurrence of this new genus
   prompts us to continue thinking about the relationships and history of
   this insufficiently known but diversely interpreted family. With 15
   figures.
C1 Szabo, J.; Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Dept Palaeontol & Geol, Ludovika
   Ter 2, Budapest, H-1083, Hungary, Hungary.
EM jszabo@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Available name; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Vertesella [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Vertesella vertesensis [Hungary /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Archaeogastropoda,
   Trochoidea
OR Ataphroidea - Cossmann 1915 (Archaeogastropoda): [Nomen translatum, P.
   423]. 
   Ataphridae - Cossmann 1915 (Trochoidea): [Nomen translatum, P. 423]. 
   Colloniidae - Cossmann 1917 (Trochoidea): [Emended diagnosis, P. 423]. 
   Vertesella (Trochoidea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Colloniinae?, Type
   species Vertesella vertesensis, p. 424, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Vertesella vertesensis (Trochoidea): [Sp nov, Hungary, Jurassic, P. 426;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14903013025
DT Article
TI A peculiar new species of Stilobezzia Kieffer breeding in bamboo
   internodes in northeastern Argentina (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae).
AU Marcela Ronderos, Maria (ronderos@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Ricardo Spinelli, Gustavo
   Borkent, Art
SO Aquatic Insects
VL 34
IS 1
PS 1-17
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Stilobezzia enigma, a new Neotropical species, is described and
   illustrated from larvae, pupae and adults. Larvae and pupae were
   collected from internodes of two bamboo species, Guadua chacoensis
   (Rojas) and Guadua trinii (Ness) Ness ex Rupr (Bambuseae) in Misiones
   province, Argentina, and were examined in the laboratory with a scanning
   electron microscope. The generic placement of S. enigma is somewhat
   uncertain but we provide cladistic evidence indicating that it is
   probably an autapomorphic member of Stilobezzia.
C1 Marcela Ronderos, Maria; Museo La Plata, Div Entomol, La Plata,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM ronderos@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0424

   South America

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Ceratopogonidae
OR Stilobezzia enigma (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 2].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201000042
DT Article
TI The breeding population of Saker Falcon (Falco cherrug) in the Czech
   Republic between 1999-2010.
AU Beran, Vaclav (lutra@email.cz) 
   Skorpikova, Vlasta
   Valasek, Martin
   Horal, David
   Horak, Petr
SO Aquila
VL 119
PS 21-30
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Saker Falcon (Falco cherrug) is a rare but regular breeder in the
   Czech Republic. It has only bred in the Pannonian part of Moravia over
   the past few decades, except for an isolated breeding locality in
   Northern Moravia/Silesia, occupied in 1989-1999 and 2003-2007. Between
   1999-2010, the breeding of the species was confirmed in 15 grid squares.
   In total, 92 breedings were confirmed (5-11 annually); with at least a
   further 24 occupied territories found. At least 39 probable breedings
   were detected. The total population size of the Saker in the Czech
   Republic was estimated at 15-20 pairs during this period. Out of 89
   breedings, 13 occurred on high voltage pylons, 75 on trees and one nest
   was situated on a cliff. In 47 cases, nests of other bird species such
   as Common Buzzard (Buteo buteo), White Stork (Ciconia ciconia), Northern
   Goshawk (Accipiter gentilis) and other species were used. Artificial
   nesting platforms or nestboxes were used in 30 cases, tree hollows in 10
   cases. The following trees were used for nesting: Quercus sp. - 29
   cases, Populus sp. - 22, Fraxinus sp. - 10, Robinia pseudacacia - 6 and
   Alnus sp. - 4. Out of 92 breeding attempts, 72 (78%) were successful; at
   least 200 young were fledged. The average breeding productivity was 2.2
   young per nest and 2.9 young per each successful breeding. Out of all
   breeding attempts 22% failed because the nest was abandoned due to
   disturbance or for unknown reasons (8 cases), presumably predated by
   Marten (Martes sp.) (4 cases), chicks were found dead in the nests (two
   cases) or, in one case, a clutch probably went cold due to the death of
   one or both parents. In three cases broken eggs were found in the nests,
   and in one case, the clutch was not fertilized. In another case, the
   breeding probably failed due to the sexual immaturity of the parent
   bird(s). Egg-laying most often took place between March 1 and April 10;
   in nearly 65%, it occurred between March 21 and 31 (n = 68). Five
   replacement clutches were found. In these cases, the egg-laying occurred
   between April 15 and 30 (4 cases) or even as late as between May 1 and 5
   (1 case). In 1999-2010, 159 Sakers were ringed (9 adults and 150
   juveniles). A juvenile from the Bruntal district (North Moravia/Silesia)
   was found in Italy (660 km) after 214 days. In several cases, Sakers
   bred surprisingly close to the occupied nests of other raptors or wading
   birds. The minimum distance between two occupied nests of Sakers was 1.3
   km (both pairs were successful).
C1 Beran, Vaclav; Town Museum Usti Nad Labem, Masarykova 1000-3, Usti Nad
   Labem, 40001, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM lutra@email.cz
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation
SN 0374-5708
BD Animals and man; Conservation; Ecology; Population dynamics; Pollution;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Falco cherrug [Disturbance by man /  / breeding distribution]
   [Conservation measures / Monitoring & protection programme / ]
   [Population size / Breeding population size / ] [Chemical pollution /  /
   ] [Czech Republic /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Falconiformes, Falconidae
OR Falco cherrug (Falconidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201000042
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15402009032
DT Article
TI A NEW EPIGEAN PSEUDOSCORPION FROM EAST SERBIA: CHTHONIUS
   (EPHIPPIOCHTHONIUS) TIMACENSIS N. SP. (CHTHONIIDAE, PSEUDOSCORPIONES).
AU Curcic, B.P.M.
   Dimitrijevic, R.N.
   Stojanovic, D.Z.
SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 64
IS 3
PS 1093-1098
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Only five species of Chthonius C. L. Koch (subgenus Ephippiochthonius
   Beier, 1930) (Chthoniidae) are presently known from Serbia. Among these,
   one should mention Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) bidentatus Beier, 1939
   (endemic to the Petnicka Pecina Cave in Western Serbia), C. (E.) kemza
   Curcic, Lee & Makarov, 1993 (from a cave in Eastern Serbia), C. (E.)
   microtuberculatus Hadzi, 1937 (distributed in southern Serbia, FYROM,
   and Bulgaria), C. (E.) tetrachelatus (Preyssler), 1970 (widely
   distributed all over the world), C. (E.) metohicus Curcic, 2011 (from
   the UN Administered Province of Kosovo), and C. (E.) civitatisveti
   Curcic & Rada, 2011 (from southern Croatia), respectively. However, a
   new epigean species belonging to the genus Chthonius - Chthonius
   (Ephippiochthonius) timacensis Curcic & Stojanovic n. sp. is described
   from eastern Serbia and is endemic to the area studied. Its taxonomic
   relationships with the phenetically close congeners C. (E.) metohicus
   Curcic and C. (E.) tetrachelatus (Preyssler), as well as its comparative
   morphological traits, are described.
C1 Curcic, B.P.M.; Univ Belgrade, Fac Biol, Belgrade, 11000, Serbia,
   Serbia.
OI Stojanovic, Dalibor/0000-0003-1602-1247
SC Zoology
SN 0354-4664
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe

   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) timacensis [Serbia /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Pseudoscorpionida
OR Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) - Beier 1930 (Pseudoscorpionida). 
   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) timacensis - B. Curcic & Stojanovic 2017
   (Pseudoscorpionida): [Sp nov, Serbia, P. 1093].

AB Pachybrachis (Pachybrachis) alcantarensis n. sp. from the International
   Tagus Natural Park (Province of Caceres), Western Spain (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae: Cryptocephalinae). Pachybrachis (Pachybrachis)
   alcantarensis sp. n. from the International Tagus Natural Park, area of
   Alcantara, province of Caceres, Western Spain, is described and
   illustrated. Ecological observations are made. It is clearly separated
   from other closely related species of Pachybrachis by the morphology of
   male genitalia.

PT J
AN ZOOR15006031509
DT Article
TI Microfauna of Lichen (Xanthoria parietina) in Lithuania: Diversity
   Patterns in Polluted and Non - Polluted Sites.
AU Satkauskiene, Ingrida (i.satkaukiene@gmf.vdu.lt) 
SO Baltic Forestry
VL 18
IS 2
PS 255-262
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Assemblages of lichen are served as the habitat and food resource for
   various microinvertebrates. The lichens' dwelling microfauna is of
   special interest regarding the maintenance of sustainable balance in
   terrestrial ecosystems. Little is known about microfauna consisting of
   protists and micrometazoa. The present study focused on the composition,
   diversity and distribution of microfauna in lichen Xanthoria parietina
   in Lithuania. Lichens were investigated beside highways and in
   unpolluted sites. The microfauna of X. parietina were represented by 24
   taxa. Two species of tardigrades, two species of testate amoebae and one
   species of gymnoamoebae that are new in Lithuania were founded. The
   study results revealed that dominating protozoa in lichen X. parietina
   are testate amoebae (genus Arcella) and ciliates (Colpoda, Paramecium).
   Philodina sp. (Rotifera), Aphelenchoides sp. (Nematoda) and Ramazzottius
   oberhaueseri (Tardigrada) were found to be dominant micrometazoa in X.
   parietina. The dominant protozoa (Colpoda cuculus, Paramecium sp.
   Arcella sp.) and micrometazoa (rotifers Philodina) didn't reveal the
   significant difference between polluted and unpolluted sites. Meanwhile
   the tardigrades were more abundant in unpolluted sites. Further studies
   on microfauna diversity using increased number of samples, sampling
   sites and estimating more environmental parameters can result in more
   distinct conclusions.
C1 Satkauskiene, Ingrida; Vytautas Magnus University, Faculty of Natural
   Science, Vileikos 8, Kaunas, LT-44404, Lithuania, Lithuania.
EM i.satkaukiene@gmf.vdu.lt
RI Satkauskiene, Ingrida/M-9760-2014
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1392-1355
BD Associations; Ecology; Pollution; Abiotic factors; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Animalia [Associations / Xanthoria parietina (lichen) / ] [Community
   structure /  / ] [Distribution within habitat /  / ] [Pollution /
   Polluted vs. unpolluted sites / ] [Abiotic factors /  / ] [Lithuania / 
   / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Animalia. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15006031509
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15306035044
DT Article
TI STUDIES ON THE PROTOZOAN PARASITES OF HILSA SHAD, TENUALOSA ILISHA IN
   BANGLADESH.
AU Bhuiyan, Aminul Islam (aminul_islam89@yahoo.com) 
   Momen, Mahfuza
SO Bangladesh Journal of Zoology
VL 40
IS 1
PS 33-41
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Present investigation was conducted to study the protozoan parasites of
   hilsa shad, Tenualosa ilisha collected from Aricha Ghat, Dhaka. Thirty
   fishes were observed. Fishes were collected during months of August 2010
   and September 2010. A total of 1099 individuals of protozoan parasite of
   eight genera/species were recorded during the present study. These
   parasites were found on body surface, gills and gall bladder of the
   fish. Jirovecia piscicola had the highest prevalence (53.33%) while
   Coccomyxa baleswarensis had the lowest prevalence (26.67%) of infection.
   Most of the host individuals had double (43%) and single (40%) species
   infection. Only a few (10%) host had triple species infection. No fish
   had more than three species of parasite at a time. Glugea sp. dominated
   over all other parasites. J. piscicola, Zschokkella ilishae and
   Ceratomyxa hilsae had almost similar abundance while C. baleswarensis
   had the lowest (5.64%) abundance. Abundance of Sphaeromyxa dighae,
   Myxobolus sp. and Kudoa sp. were comparatively low ranging from 9.36% to
   17.35%.
C1 Bhuiyan, Aminul Islam; Univ Dhaka, Dept Zool, Dhaka, 1000, Bangladesh,
   Bangladesh.
EM aminul_islam89@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0304-9027
BD General morphology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   ilisha / Prevalence] [Bangladesh / Dhaka, Aricha Ghat, Padma River / ].

   geographical record] [Bangladesh /  / ].

   piscicola / ] [Bangladesh /  / ] [ /  / ] [ /  / ] [ / Dhaka, Aricha

DT Article
TI STUDIES ON THE BIODIVERSITY OF ASEPTATE GREGARINE PARASITE FROM THE
   OLIGOCHAETE HOST OF BANGLADESH.
AU Sarkar, Sutapa
   Bandyopadhyay, Probir K. (prabir0432@hotmail.com) 
SO Bangladesh Journal of Zoology
VL 40
IS 1
PS 51-58
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Biodiversity studies in search of endoparasitic acephaline gregarines of
   the earthworms of Dhaka, Bangladesh, revealed a new species under the
   genus Nematocystis Hesse, 1909. The species was obtained from the
   seminal vesicles of the earthworm Metaphire peguana Rasa, 1890. It is a
   perfectly ribbon like organism, solitary, cylindrical, with several
   bulges and foldings in the middle portion of the body, especially in
   mature forms. Mature gamont measures 1955.85-1989.0 (1970.215 [plus or
   minus] 13.830) [mu]m in length and 48.62-53.04 (51.714 [plus or minus]
   2.135) [mu]m in width. Nucleus small and rounded, measures 26.52-33.15
   (29.835 [plus or minus] 2.992) [mu]m in length and 17.68-22.01 (19.448
   [plus or minus] 2.282) [mu]m in width. Gametocysts spherical with two
   approximately equal sized gametocytes. It measures 110.05-121.55 (116.24
   [plus or minus] 4.908) [mu]m in length and 88.04-99.45 (93.925 [plus or
   minus] 5.823) [mu]m in width. Oocysts biconical, measuring 22.1-30.94
   (26.962 [plus or minus] 3.870) [mu]m x 11.05-15.47 (13.26 [plus or
   minus] 2.08) [mu]m.
C1 Bandyopadhyay, Probir K.; Univ Kalyani, Dept Zool, Kalyani, W Bengal,
   741235, India, India.
EM prabir0432@hotmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0304-9027
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Metaphire peguana [Protozoan parasites / Nematocystis bangladeshensis /
   New parasite species] [Bangladesh /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
   Nematocystis bangladeshensis [Annelid hosts / Metaphire peguana / New
   parasite species] [Bangladesh /  / New species from annelid host]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta, Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea,
   Gregarinia

   Nematocystis bangladeshensis (Gregarinia): [Sp nov, Bangladesh, Parasite
   of Metaphire peguana (Annelida), p. 57; Parasite].

TI A Contribution to the fauna of Earwings of Nepal with description of a
   new species (Insecta: Dermaptera).
FT Ein Beitrag zur Ohrwurmfauna Nepals mit Besehreibung einer neuen
   Ohrwurmart (Insecta: Dermaptera).
AU Matzke, Danilo (danilo.matzke@arcor.de) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 149-177
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A Contribution to the fauna of Earwings of Nepal with description of a
   new species (Insecta: Dermaptera) In Nepal 79 species of Dermaptera are
   recorded after intensivly studies in the collections and in literature
   by listing of faunistic records after 1987. Among them 19 species were
   recorded as new for the fauna of Nepal. The species Liparura charlottea
   sp. nov. is described and figured as new for science. A current
   checklist is given and all records of studied material were listed.

DT Book chapter
TI The genus Timasius Distant, 1909 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Hebridae) in
   Nepal: three new species and notes on the brachypterous morph.
AU Zettel, Herbert (herbert.zettel@nhm-wien.ac.at) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 179-186
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Timasius comprises ripicolous hebrid species with a preference for rocky
   substrates in the Oriental region. One important centre of
   diversification lies in the southern parts of the Himalayas (29% of
   described species). Timasius was hitherto unknown from Nepal. This study
   describes three new species from Central Nepal: Timasius nesemanni sp.
   n. and Timasius nepalensis sp. n. of the Timasius rupestris species
   group, and Timasius tachamoae sp. n. of the Timasius livens species
   group. Timasius tachamoae sp. n. is also recorded from northwestern and
   northeastern India. A key for male specimens of the Timasius rupestris
   species group is provided. The type specimens of T. nesemanni sp. n. are
   short-winged; hitherto such a morph was undescribed in Timasius. Wing
   polymorphism in Timasius and in Hebridae in general is discussed.
C1 Zettel, Herbert; Nat Hist Museum Vienna, Dept Entomol, Burgring 7,
   Vienna, A-1010, Austria, Austria.
EM herbert.zettel@nhm-wien.ac.at
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; General morphology;
   Appendages; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Hebridae [Wings / Wing polymorphism / ]. 
   Timasius [Wings / Wing polymorphism / ] [Nepal /  / Systematics]. 
   Timasius nepalensis; Timasius nesemanni; Timasius tachamoae [Nepal /  /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Gerromorpha,
   Gerroidea, Hebridae
OR Hebridae (Gerroidea).

   Timasius nepalensis (Hebridae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 179]. 
   Timasius nesemanni (Hebridae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 179]. 
   Timasius rupestris species group (Hebridae): [Key to species, Males, p.
   179]. 
   Timasius tachamoae (Hebridae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 179].

PT B
AN ZOOR15109055468
DT Book chapter
TI Muga silkworm, Antheraea assamensis (Insecta: Lepidoptera: Saturniidae):
   rearing and insect predators.
AU Kumar, Rajesh (rajesh.ento@gmail.com) 
   Rajkhowa, G.
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 187-189
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The "Golden Silk" obtained from Muga Silkworm, Antheraea assamensis
   (Helfer) (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) is endemic and found exclusively in
   rainforest ecosystems of the Himalayan Foot Hills in North Eastern
   India, especially in Assam and Meghalaya, due to their unique climatic
   conditions. Muga culture is of considerable economic importance and
   closely associated with the life, tradition and culture of the tribal
   people. The North Eastern region of India, comprising the states of
   Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Meghalaya, Manipur, Tripura, Mizoram, Nagaland
   and Sikkim can be physiographically categorized as the Eastern
   Himalayas. North Eastern India is one of 34 world biodiversity hotspots
   and is a natural abode for insect biodiversity. The muga silkworm is
   multivoltine and is reared in outdoor conditions. A. assamensis
   completes its life cycle in 35-45 days in six crop seasons (Oct-Nov,
   Dec-Jan, Feb-Mar, Apr-May, Jun-July, Aug-Sept) and moults four times
   (i.e. has five larval instars). Outdoor reared muga silkworms are
   attacked by many pests and predators. Previously, only a few pests and
   predators were reported for muga silkworm. Recently, six species of
   predatory bugs (Hemiptera: Reduviidae, Pentatomidae) and three species
   of Mantis (Mantodea: Mantidae) have been observed feeding on this
   species. The feeding behavior of predators was observed in field
   conditions. It was found that the bugs first pierce the larva,
   paralyzing its body, and when the paralyzed caterpillars become
   inactive, the predator starts to suck the body juices of the muga
   silkworms. Mantis spp. were found feeding voraciously on healthy fourth
   and fifth instar larvae, leaving behind the head and anal prolegs of the
   caterpillars. All these predators were observed during the entire larval
   period (first instar to fifth instar) and were found to cause a 10% loss
   of muga silkworms in the area studied. Photographs were taken using a
   Sony DSC R1 10.3 mega pixel camera.
C1 Kumar, Rajesh; Minist Text Govt India, Cent Silk Board, Landoigarh,
   Assam, 785700, India, India.
EM rajesh.ento@gmail.com
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Entomology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Nutrition
   &Dietetics
BN 9783000389764
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Ecology; Predators; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Antheraea assamensis [Insect predators / Mantidae (Mantodea) / Predator
   records & feeding behaviour; larva] [ / Pentatomidae (Hemiptera) / ]
   [India / North east / ]. 
   Mantidae; Pentatomidae [Insect prey / Antheraea assamensis (Lepidoptera)
   / Predator records] [Feeding behaviour /  / ] [India / North east / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Mantodea, Hemiptera,
   Heteroptera, Pentatomomorpha, Pentatomoidea, Lepidoptera, Glossata,
   Heteroneura, Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Mantidae (Mantodea): [Predator]. 
   Pentatomidae (Pentatomoidea): [Predator]. 
   Antheraea assamensis (Saturniidae): [Prey]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15109055468
DA 2020-09-17

TI Nebria (Epinebriola) martensi n. sp. from the eastern Nepal Himalaya,

U2 1
AB Nebria (Epinebriola) martensi n. sp. from the Lumba Sumba Himal (Eastern
   Nepal) is described. Up to now, these specimens were erroneously
   reported to be N. rasa Andrewes, 1936. A redescription of N. rasa is
   given on the basis of the holotype.

TI Additional data on the genus Ophoniscus Bates, 1892, with a description
   of a new species from Nepal, and notes on the taxonomic position of
   Parophonus rectangulus Ito, 1994 (Insecta: Coleoptera: Carabidae,
   Harpalini).
AU Kataev, Boris M. (harpal@zin.ru) 
   Wrase, David W.
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 215-223
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ophoniscus nepalensis spec. nov. is described from Nepal (type locality:
   "okolica (= environments) h. Lama, 1500-2400 m"). The morphological
   characteristics of males of O. lopatini Kataev, 2005 and O.
   hypolithoides Bates, 1892, and revised additional descriptions of O.
   cribrifrons Bates, 1892 and O. lopatini Kataev, 2005 are provided. New
   records of some species of Ophoniscus are listed. O. hypolithoides is
   reported from Thailand, O. cribrifrons is reported from Thailand and
   Nepal, and O. batesi Kataev, 2005 is reported from Nepal for the first
   time. The taxonomical position of Parophonus rectangulus Ito, 1994 is
   discussed; this species is reported from India (Deccan) for the first
   time.

   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

AN ZOOR15109055473
DT Book chapter
TI New Pterostichus species from the Eastern Himalaya, with a revision of
   the atrox group of the subgenus Pseudethira Sciaky, 1996 (Insecta:
   Coleoptera: Carabidae: Pterostichini).
AU Schmidt, Joachim (schmidt@agonum.de) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 225-257
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the Pseudethira fauna of the eastern portion of
   the Himalaya. In the first part a review of the atrox group with a key
   to species is presented. Three species of this group, Pterostichus atrox
   Andrewes, 1937 from southeast Tibet, P. brancuccii Straneo, 1982 from
   East Nepal, and P. exochus Andrewes, 1930 from Sikkim, are redescribed
   based on their type material, and three additional species are described
   as new: P. kalo sp. n. from East Nepal, P. kangchenjunga sp. n. from
   Sikkim, and P. rugosiceps sp. n. from southeast Tibet. The second part
   of this paper updates our knowledge on the species of the harmandi group
   in East Nepal. The poorly known species P. perlamatus Straneo, 1989 is
   redescribed based on its holotype, and the male genital characters of P.
   janbritoi Movan, 1994 are described and figured for the first time. P.
   jaljaleensis Schmidt, 2009, stat. nov., which was previously described
   as a subspecies of R angoarnigi Movan, 1994, is upgraded to species
   level. Eight taxa are newly described: P. makalu sp. n., P. sagarmatha
   sp. n., and P. schrettenbrunneri sp. n. from the south eastern slopes of
   Khumbu Himal in East Nepal, and P. angoarnigi pathibaraensis ssp. n., P.
   jaljaleensis arun ssp. n., P. janbritoi tamur ssp. n., P. mewakholensis
   sp. n., and P. thanglaensis sp. n. from the mountains between Arun River
   and Tamur River valleys in East Nepal. In the third part of this paper
   the first representative of the subgenus Pseudethira from Arunachal
   Pradesh, northeast India, is described: P. leica sp. n. from the
   mountains north of Bomdila. All differential characters of the species
   described and redescribed in the presented paper are figured, and the
   distributional areas of these species are mapped. Finally, an updated
   checklist of all species of the subgenus Pseudethira is provided.
C1 Schmidt, Joachim; Lindenstr 3A, Admannshagen, D-18211, Germany, Germany.
EM schmidt@agonum.de
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Status; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; India
DE Pterostichus (Pseudethira) [Checklists / Updated taxonomic checklist / ]
   [Asia / Himalayas, east / ]. 
   Pterostichus (Pseudethira) leica [Arunachal Pradesh /  / New species]. 
   Pterostichus angoarnigi pathibaraensis; Pterostichus jaljaleensis arun;

   Pterostichus kalo; Pterostichus makalu; Pterostichus mewakholensis;
   Pterostichus sagarmatha; Pterostichus schrettenbrunneri; Pterostichus
   thanglaensis [Nepal /  / New species]. 
   Pterostichus kangchenjunga [Sikkim /  / New species]. 
   Pterostichus rugosiceps [Xizang /  / New species].

   Carabidae

   to, Pterostichus jaljaleensis, p. 225]. 
   Pterostichus angoarnigi pathibaraensis (Carabidae): [Subsp nov, Nepal,
   P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus atrox - Andrewes 1937 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P. 225].
   
   Pterostichus brancuccii - Straneo 1982 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P.

   Pterostichus exochus - Andrewes 1930 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P.

   Pterostichus jaljaleensis - Schmidt 2009 (Carabidae): [Raised from,
   Pterostichus angoarnigi jaljaleensis, p. 225]. 
   Pterostichus jaljaleensis arun (Carabidae): [Subsp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus janbritoi - Movan 1994 (Carabidae): [First time described,
   Male genital characters, p. 225; First time figured, Male genital
   characters, p. 225]. 
   Pterostichus janbritoi tamur (Carabidae): [Subsp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus kalo (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus kangchenjunga (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sikkim, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus makalu (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus mewakholensis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus perlamatus - Straneo 1989 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P.

   Pterostichus rugosiceps (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus sagarmatha (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 225]. 
   Pterostichus schrettenbrunneri (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 225].

PT B
AN ZOOR15109055474
DT Book chapter
TI The species of Amara subgenus Pseudocelia Lutshnik, 1935 and some more
   new species of Amara (Insecta: Coleoptera: Carabidae).
FT Die Amara-Arten der Untergattung Pseudocelia Lutshnik, 1935 und weitere
   neue Amara-Arten (Insecta: Coleoptera: Carabidae).
AU Hieke, Fritz
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 259-271
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of Amara-subgenus Pseudocelia Lutshnik, 1935 and some more
   new species of Amara (Insecta: Coleoptera: Carabidae) The species Amara
   (Xenocelia) qinghaiensis n. sp. from Qinghai, Amara (Pseudoleiromorpha)
   junkarensis from Pakistan, Amara (Pseudocelia) yushuana n. sp. from
   Qinghai and Amara (Pseudocelia) zhanglaensis n. sp. from Sichuan are
   described as new for sciences. A review of all known 19 species of
   subgenus Pseudocelia Lutshnik, 1935 with distribution maps is given.

TI A contribution to the knowledge of the Himalayan Leiodinae (Insecta:
   Coleoptera: Leiodidae).
AU Svec, Zdenek
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 273-281
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four species of the tribe Agathidiini - Cyrtoplastus himalayanus sp. n.,
   Agathidium (Agathidium) monstrosum sp. n., Agathidium (A.) simillimum
   sp. n. and A. (A.) diversum sp. n. are described from Nepal. Agathidium
   (A.) montanum Angelini & De Marzo, 1981, Pseudcolenis rostrata Champion,
   1923, P bouvieri Portevin, 1903 and genera Cyrtoplastus Reitter, 1885
   and Pseudoagathidium Angelini, 1993 are recorded from Nepal for the
   first time. The possible variability of A. (A.) johnsoni Angelini & De
   Marzo, 1981, A. (A.) garhwalense Angelini & De Marzo, 1981, A. (A.)
   glaciale Angelini & De Marzo, 1981 and the variability of the Himalayan
   Agathidium in general are discussed.

   Republic.

PA Erfurt

   Asia

AN ZOOR15109055476
DT Book chapter
TI New data, two new genera and new species of Aleocharinae from Indian and
   Chinese Subregions (Insecta: Coleoptera: Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 283-296
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Ten tribes (Leucocraspedini, Pronomaeini, Gyrophaenini, Homalotini,
   Falagriini, Athetini, Lomechusini, Oxypodini, Hoplandriini,
   Aleocharini), 19 genera (Leucocraspedum, Philomina, Brachida, Silusa,
   Stenomastax, Cordalia, Exakanthinusa, Nehemitropia, Atheta, Pelioptera,
   Tetrabothrus, Orphnebius, Zyras, Parapimela, Ocyusa, Oxypoda, Tinotus,
   Indiachara, Aleochara) and 28 species are recognized. Two genera,
   Exakanthinusa n. gen, of the tribe Athetini, and Indiachara n. gen., of
   the tribe Aleocharini, and 13 species are described as new to science:
   Leucocraspedum nilgiriense n. sp., Silusa turensis n. sp., Stenomastax
   garhiensis n. sp., Exakanthinusa mirabilis n. sp., Atheta chainpurensis
   n. sp., Pelioptera Tamil n. sp., Orphnebius turensis n. sp., Zyras
   turensis n. sp., Zyras azadensis n. sp., Zyras pakisthospes n. sp.,
   Zyras dissimilis n. sp., Ocyusa junkarensis n. sp., Indiachara
   bageshwarensis n. sp. All new species and the new genera are illustrated
   and compared with similar species or genera. Philomina torrentum
   (Cameron, 1939), is the new combination for Mniophila torrentum Cameron,
   1939. Gnypetalia Cameron, 1939 is newly synonymized with Ischnopoda
   Stephens, 1831. Eleven species are transferred from Gnypetalia to
   Ischnopoda and two from Tachyusa to the same genus.

PT B
AN ZOOR15109055479
DT Book chapter
TI New species and a morphology-based phylogeny of the genus Nepaloserica
   (Insecta: Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae).
AU Ahrens, Dirk (ahrens.dirk_col@gmx.de) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 305-316
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species of Nepaloserica are highly endemic but diversified within
   the Himalaya. The current paper presents a first phylogenetic analysis
   of Nepaloserica based on characters of adult morphology. Fourty-nine
   species were examined for the phylogenetic reconstruction using
   parsimony and Bayesian inference based on 59 characters. As a result of
   the phylogenetic hypothesis on the genus, the monophyly of Nepaloserica
   is highly supported while interspecific relationships are widely poorly
   resolved. Three new species from Nepal, Nepaloserica richardsonae sp.
   n., N. baglungensis sp. n. and N. pewaensis sp. n., were additionally
   discovered and described herein under inclusion of their diagnostics and
   the illustration of male copulation organs.
C1 Ahrens, Dirk; Alexander Koenig Bonn, Zool Forsch Museum, Adenauerallee
   160, Bonn, D-53113, Germany, Germany.
EM ahrens.dirk_col@gmx.de
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Evolution;
   Variation; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia
DE Nepaloserica [General morphology / Adult morphology / systematics]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic reconstruction / ] [Morphological variation / 
   / ] [Asia / Himalayas / biology; distribution]. 
   Nepaloserica baglungensis; Nepaloserica pewaensis; Nepaloserica
   richardsonae [Nepal /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae
OR Nepaloserica - Frey 1965 (Scarabaeidae). 
   Nepaloserica baglungensis (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 305]. 
   Nepaloserica pewaensis (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 305]. 
   Nepaloserica richardsonae (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 305].

DT Book chapter
TI Notes on the Himalayan Valgina with description of a new genus (Insecta:
   Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae).
AU Ricchiardi, Enrico (alericor@fastwebnet.it) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 323-328
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A study of several new Valgina1 from the sub-Himalayan area of the
   Oriental Region has confirmed the presence of a new monospecific genus,
   which is described here and allowed the description of females of three
   species present in the area, belonging to three different genera. This
   may help to improve the subdivision of the subtribe into genera, as
   currently this is based only on males. Finally, the presence of an
   additional species of Dasyvalgus Kolbe 1904, increases the number of
   Valgina species present in the Himalayan area to eleven.
C1 Ricchiardi, Enrico; Corso A Tassoni 79-4, Turin, I-10143, Italy, Italy.
EM alericor@fastwebnet.it
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   systematics] [Asia / Himalayas / ].

   Scarabaeidae

PT B
AN ZOOR15109055482
DT Book chapter
TI Knowledge on Hydrocyphon L. Redtenbacher, 1858 and Cyphon Paykull, 1799
   in Nepal and the Orient (Insecta: Coleoptera: Scirtidae).
FT Zur Kenntnis von Hydrocyphon L. Redtenbacher, 1858 und Cyphon Paykull,
   1799 aus Nepal und der Orientalischen Region (Insecta: Coleoptera:
   Scirtidae) (169. Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Scirtidae).
AU Klausnitzer, Bernhard
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 329-347
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species from North India (H. subinterrogationis sp. n.) from the
   Hydrocyphon deflexicollis-group is described. It is compared with H.
   interrogationis Klausnitzer, 1980. Additions to the original description
   are given. H. verrucosus sp. n. is described from Nepal (Hydrocyphon
   kambaiticus-group) and compared with H. steueri Klausnitzer, 2006. A new
   Hydrocyphon (H. centriminutus sp. n.) is described from Java. It belongs
   to the Hydrocyphon pallidicollis-group. It is compared with the other
   three species of this group which are already known from this island.
   Within the H. pallidicollis-group there is a species-group. It possesses
   a characteristic 9th tergite with strong differences from the other
   species. In this species-group Cyphon sieberi Klausnitzer, 2010 is
   transferred (Hydrocyphon sieberi (Klausnitzer, 2010) nov. comb.). A new
   species (C. polycelis sp. n.) of the Cyphon erythrinus-subgroup from
   Thailand is described. The description of C. scabridus Klausnitzer, 1980
   is supplemented. It will be given a determination key for the species of
   this subgroup. A different form of C. thailandicus Ruta, 2004 from
   Vietnam is described. C. thailandicus is reported new in Laos. A new
   species (C. rotundosternalis sp. n.) of the Cyphon apoanus-subgroup from
   Nepal is described. C. suspiciosus Klausnitzer, 1980 is classified in
   this subgroup. A determination key for the species of this subgroup is
   being presented. There are also additions to the known distributions of
   18 species occurring in Nepal and in the Orientalis.
C1 Klausnitzer, Bernhard; Mitglied Senckenberg Deutsch Entomol Inst,
   Lannerstr 5, Dresden, D-01219, Germany, Germany.
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India
DE Cyphon; Hydrocyphon [Oriental region /  / Biology; distribution;
   systematics]. 
   Cyphon polycelis [Thailand /  / New species]. 
   Cyphon rotundosternalis; Hydrocyphon verrucosus [Nepal /  / New
   species]. 
   Cyphon thailandicus [Laos /  / New record]. 
   Hydrocyphon centriminutus [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Hydrocyphon mirabilis [Nepal /  / New record]. 
   Hydrocyphon subinterrogationis [West Bengal /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Eucinetoidea,
   Scirtidae
OR Cyphon - Paykull 1799 (Scirtidae). 
   Cyphon erythrinus subgroup (Scirtidae): [Key to species, P. 329]. 
   Cyphon polycelis (Scirtidae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 329]. 
   Cyphon rotundosternalis (Scirtidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 329]. 
   Cyphon scabridus - Klausnitzer 1980 (Scirtidae): [Redescription, P.
   329]. 
   Cyphon sieberi - Klausnitzer 2010 (Scirtidae): [Referred to,
   Hydrocyphon, p. 329]. 
   Cyphon thailandicus (Scirtidae): [New record]. 
   Hydrocyphon - Redtenbacher 1858 (Scirtidae). 
   Hydrocyphon centriminutus (Scirtidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 329]. 
   Hydrocyphon interrogationis - Klausnitzer 1980 (Scirtidae):
   [Redescription, P. 329]. 
   Hydrocyphon mirabilis (Scirtidae): [New record]. 
   Hydrocyphon sieberi - (Klausnitzer 2010) (Scirtidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Cyphon, p. 329]. 
   Hydrocyphon subinterrogationis (Scirtidae): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P.
   329].

TI Coccinellidae (Insecta: Coleoptera) of Nepal Himalaya in the
   Naturkundemuseum Erfurt.
AU Canepari, Claudio (ccanepari@libero.it) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 357-390
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A list of Coleoptera Coccinellidae collected by the expeditions of
   Naturkundemuseum Erfurt and by P. Cechovski is given. 15 new species are
   described: Sasajiella hartmanni, Sumnius simplex, Scymnus (Pullus)
   kopetzi, Scymnus (Pullus) monachus, Scymnus (Pullus) rufomaculatus,
   Scymnus (Pullus) cirroticus, Scymnus (Pullus) ictericus, Scymnus
   (Pullus) dubitabilis, Scymnus (Pullus) sufflavoides, Sasajiscymnus
   nirvana, Orcus nepalicus, Oenopia octovittata, Epilachna cechovskii,
   Epilachna similbengalica, Epilachna siphopocula. Oenopia smetanai
   Canepari is considered a junior synonym of Oenopia flavidbrunna Jing.
   The following species are new for the Fauna of Nepal: Pharoscymnus
   flexibilis (Mulsant), Chilocorus alishanus Sasaji, Chilocorus melas
   Weise, Scymnus (Pullus) kawamurai (Ohta), Illeis confusa Timberlake,

PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A determination key and new distributional data of the genus Callimerus
   are presented. The new species Callimerus tricoloratus n. sp. is
   described and figured. Callimerus distinctus Corporaal, 1939 n. syn. is
   synonymised with Callimerua albofasciatus (Thomson, 1860). The
   systematic position of the genus Callimerus is discussed regarding
   molecular data.

DT Book chapter
TI Taxonomic and faunistic notes on the genera Danodema Gebien, 1925 and
   Falsonannocerus Pic, 1946 (Insecta: Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae:
   Cnodalonini).
AU Schawaller, Wolfgang (wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 403-404
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The status of the genera Danodema Gebien, 1925 and Falsoannocerus Pic,
   1946 within the tenebrionid tribe Cnodalonini is discussed. Either,
   Falsonannocerus might be a junior synonym of Danodema. Or, more
   probably, both genera remain valid with the African species dentaticeps
   Pic, 1946 in Falsonannocerus, and with all Oriental species newly
   combined in Danodema. New faunistic records, a list of all 12 Oriental
   species as well as figures of both genera for subsequent identifications
   are added. Falsoperichilus alternatus Ardoin, 1965 is considered a
   junior synonym of Falsonannocerus dentaticeps Pic, 1946.
C1 Schawaller, Wolfgang; Staatliches Museum Nat Kunde, Rosenstein 1,
   Stuttgart, D-70191, Germany, Germany.
EM wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Falsonannocerus dentaticeps [Ghana /  / New record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Danodema - Gebien 1925 (Tenebrionidae): [Status, P. 403]. 
   Falsoannocerus - Pic 1946 (Tenebrionidae): [Status, P. 403]. 
   Falsonannocerus dentaticeps - Pic 1946 (Tenebrionidae): [Syn nov,
   Falsoperichilus alternatus Ardoin 1965, p. 404; New record].

DT Book chapter
TI Contribution to the fauna of longhorn beetles from Arunachal Pradesh
   (India), with description of a new species from in the genus Acalolepta
   Pascoe, 1858 (Insecta: Coleoptera: Cerambycidae).
FT Beitrag zur Bockkaferfauna von Arunachal Pradesh (Indien) mit
   Beschreibung einer neuen Art aus der Gattung Acalolepta Pascoe, 1858
   (Insecta: Coleoptera: Cerambycidae).
AU Weigel, Andreas (rosalia@versanet.de) 
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 405-411
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB The fauna of longhorn beetles in Arunachal Pradesh is very less known
   containing only 48 species up to now. In this contribution all together
   data from 67 species are given, 42 species are documented of this Indian
   state for the first time. One species of the tibe Monochamini,
   Acalolepta bretschneideri spec. nov., will be described as new for
   science and illustrated herein. Pseudomeges gigas Lepesme, 1947 syn.
   nov. is considered as a junior synonym of Pseudomeges varioti Le Moult,
   1946. For 17 species identifications to species level are not possible
   in this time. All species are pictured on plates. The material comes
   from all together four expeditions made by Mr. Gil Bretschneider in the
   period from 2006 to 2010 in different regions of Arunachal Pradesh.
C1 Weigel, Andreas; Schlossgarten 6, Wernburg, D-07381, Germany, Germany.
EM rosalia@versanet.de
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Acalolepta bretschneideri [Arunachal Pradesh /  / New species]. 
   Cerambycidae [Checklists /  / New record; systematics] [Arunachal
   Pradesh /  / Distribution; faunal list]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Cerambycidae (Chrysomeloidea): [New record]. 
   Acalolepta bretschneideri (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Arunachal Pradesh, P.
   405]. 
   Pseudomeges varioti - Le Moult 1946 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Pseudomeges gigas Lepesme 1947, p. 411].

DT Book chapter
TI New species of Phaedon Latreille, 1829 (Insecta: Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae) from the Himalaya.
AU Sprecher-Uebersax, Eva (eva.sprecher@bs.ch) 
   Daccordi, Mauro
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 415-421
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Himalayan species of Phaedon were studied and three new species
   described. So far four species were recorded in Nepal, one from Bhutan
   and three from Sikkim and Darjeeling. The new species are all from
   Nepal. They differ in colour and in the punctuation of the elytra and
   prothorax. They are all endemic in Nepal and found at high altitudes
   above 2600 m. It is supposed that they feed on mosses.
C1 Sprecher-Uebersax, Eva; Nat Hist Museum Basel, Augustinergasse 2, Basel,
   CH-4001, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM eva.sprecher@bs.ch
PU Naturkundemuseum Erfurt
PA Erfurt
SC Zoology
BN 9783000389764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Phaedon chaukiensis; Phaedon ivalianus; Phaedon tashigaonensis [Nepal / 
   / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Phaedon chaukiensis (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 415]. 
   Phaedon ivalianus (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 415]. 
   Phaedon tashigaonensis (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 415].

TI To the knowledge of the genera Mandarella Duvivier and Stenoluperus
   Ogloblin (Insecta: Chrysomelidae: Alticinae) from the Himalayas.
AU Medvedev, Lav N.
ED Hartmann, Matthias
   Weipert, Joerg
SO Biodiversity and natural heritage of the Himalaya, vol. IV.
PS 423-427
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two genera of Alticinae were studied. Following new synonymies are
   proposed: Mandarella Duvivier, 1892 = Stenoluperus Ogloblin, 1936 (syn.
   nov.); Mandarella nigricornis L. Medvedev, 2000 (comb. nov.) =
   Stenoluperus emotoi Kimoto, 2001 (syn. nov.) = S. thudemensis Kimoto,
   2001 (syn. nov.) A key to Himalayan species and a catalogue of the genus
   Mandarella are given.

   Mandarella, p. 427].

   Mandarella, p. 427].

   replaced by, Mandarella taiwanensis, p. 427]. 
   Stenoluperus lemoides - Weise 1889 (Chrysomelidae): [Referred to,
   Mandarella, p. 427]. 
   Stenoluperus major - Kimoto 1977 (Chrysomelidae): [Referred to,
   Mandarella, p. 427].

PT J
AN ZOOR15003011152
DT Article
TI New cases of pathogens imported with ornamental fish.
AU Sobecka, Ewa (ewa.sobecka@zut.edu.pl) 
   Luczak, Ewa
   Marcinkiewicz, Michal
SO Biological Letters
VL 49
IS 1
PS 3-10
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The global trade in live ornamental fish carries with it the potential
   threat of unwanted movement of pathogens. The live ornamental fish, when
   released into the natural environment of their destination countries,
   may disseminate their parasites, threatening local fish and causing
   economic loss in fish aquaculture. This study was aimed to explain the
   reasons for deterioration of health and premature death of ornamental
   fish: Nannostomus spp. from Colombia and Symphysodon spp. Some specimens
   of Symphysodon aequifasciatus Pellegrin, 1904 were captured from their
   natural habitats in the Amazon River basin and shipped to Poland by air
   mail. The hybrids of Symphysodon spp. originated from an aquarium in
   Poland (shared with S. aequifasciatus). The third discus fish species,
   Symphysodon discus Heckel, 1840 came from a fish farm in Thailand and
   represents an Asian breeding line. All the studied fish were infected
   with pathogens. Nannostomus spp. housed a single parasite species on its
   skin, namely Artystone minima. This isopod species was not recorded in
   Poland and probably in Europe before. The examined fish of the genus
   Symphysodon yielded 13 pathogens. Five of them Philodina sp.,
   Ichthyobodo necator, Hexamita symphysodonis, Sciadicleithrum variabilum
   and Eustrongylides sp. were not earlier recorded in this host species in
   Poland. The findings of Ichthyophonus hoferi and Myxobolus sp. are new
   host records for Symphysodon spp. fish. Hybrid fish and S.
   aequifasciatus are reported here as hosts of Entamoeba sp. for the first
   time.
C1 Sobecka, Ewa; West Pomeranian Univ Technol Szczecin, Div Fish Physiol &
   Pathol, Kazimierza Krolewicza 4, Szczecin, PL-71550, Poland, Poland.
EM ewa.sobecka@zut.edu.pl

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Asida Latreille, 1802 subgenus Planasida
   Escalera, 1907 from North Africa (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
FT Descripcion de una nueva especie de Asida Latreille, 1802 del subgenero
   Planasida Escalera, 1907, del norte de Africa (Coleoptera,
   Tenebrionidae).
AU Perez-Vera, Francisco (fperezvera@yahoo.fr) 
   Ruiz, Jose L.
   Avila, Jose Miguel
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 36
IS 3-4
PS 381-400
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper we describe a new species of Asida of the subgenus
   Planasida: Asida (Planasida) septemsis, localized in the Spanish
   territory of Ceuta and distributed from the neighbouring areas of the
   Morocco's northern tip (north-eastern part of the Peninsula Tingitana).
   The new species is part of the group of Asida (Planasida) bereai,
   species of which are characterized by the epipleural edge of the elytra
   being smooth and fine (not crenulated), and within that in the subgroup
   of Asida (Planasida) lauzannei, containing species with the propleura
   reticulate-dotted and grainy. The new species is morphologically related
   to Asida (Planasida) lanceocollis, which clearly differs, among other
   characters, in that the elytra of the latter has a strong midrib, which
   is absent in the former.
C1 Perez-Vera, Francisco; Calle Real,2,Soportujar, Granada, 18410, Spain,
   Spain.

TI Description of a new species of Hybreoleptops Kuschel, 1949, and
   comments about other species of the genus (Insecta: Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae).
FT Descripcion de una nueva especie de Hybreoleptops Kuschel, 1949 y
   comentarios sobre otros representantes del genero (insecta: Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae).
AU Elgueta, Mario (melgueta@mnhn.cl) 
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 61
PS 29-43
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hybreoleptops roseus n. sp. is described, and it distribution in the
   coast of central Chile, at elevations of 200 to 450 meters above sea
   level, and between 34[degree]10' S and 36[degree]10' S, is recognized.
   Adults are associated with leaves of various trees and shrubs present
   there. Based on the study of the type material, the following synonymy
   is established: Hybreoleptops santiagensis Perez and Posadas, 2006 =
   Hybreoleptops juanjosei Perez and Posadas, 2006. The first name having
   priority by page precedence over the second. Notes about the diagnostic
   characters of Hybreoleptops are made, host plants are indicated and a
   key to the species is presented. Hybreoleptops vestitus (Blanchard) is
   recorded for the first time for Neuquen, in Argentina.
C1 Elgueta, Mario; Museo Nacl Hist Nat, Area Entomol, Casilla 787,
   Santiago, Correo Central, Chile, Chile.

PT J
AN ZOOR15010053836
DT Article
TI Notes on a finding of Megatherium sp (Mammalia, Xenarthra,
   Megatheriidae) in the lower course of the Salado River (Region of
   Antofagasta, Chile).
FT Notas sobre un hallazgo de Megatherium sp. (Mammalia, Xenarthra,
   Megatheriidae) en el curso inferior del rio Salado (Region de
   Antofagasta, Chile).
AU Rojas M., Osvaldo (museocalama@vtr.net) 
   Lopez M., Patricio
   Martinez R., Ismael
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 61
PS 75-85
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present results of a taxonomic analysis of a mandible assigned to
   Megatherium sp. which was recovered from a secondary deposit on the
   fluvial north terrace in the lower course of the Salado River
   (Antofagasta Region, Chile). The comparison of the dimensions of the
   mandibular molariforms indicates that the Salado River specimen is
   smaller than M. americanum and larger than M. altiplanicum, being closer
   to the ranges of M. tarijense, M. sundti and M. medinae. Although the
   materials were collected from a collapsed block of a yet unidentified
   layer, sediments impregnated in the interstices of the bone, and in
   agreement with the stratigraphic distribution of the genus in other
   sites of the area suggest that the mandible comes from deposits of the
   Chiu-Chiu Formation (Upper Pleistocene and Upper Holocene).
C1 Rojas M., Osvaldo; Museo Hist Nat & Cultural Desierto Atacama, Av
   Bernardo OHiggins S-N,Interior Parque El Loa, Calama, Chile, Chile.
EM museocalama@vtr.net
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Paleontology
SN 0027-3910

   zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic
DE Megatherium [Jaws / Mandible / New record; systematics] [Chile /
   Antofagasta, Salado River / ] [Quaternary /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Edentates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Edentata, Megatheriidae

DT Article
TI An ornithological survey of Pinas Bay, a site on the Pacific coast of
   Darien Province, Panama.
AU Miller, Matthew J. (millerma@si.edu) 
   Weir, Jason T.
   Angehr, George R.
   Guitton M, Peggy
   Bermingham, Eldredge
SO Boletin SAO
VL 20
IS 2
PS 29-38
PD 2011-2012
PY 2012
UR http://sao.org.co/publicaciones/boletinsao/20%282%29/20%282%29.html
AW http://sao.org.co/publicaciones/boletinsao/20%282%29/AP320%282%29Millere
   tal.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We surveyed the avifauna of the lowland and foothill habitats
   surrounding Pinas Bay, located on the Pacific coast of Darien Province,
   Panama from 3 May-16 May, 2003 as part of a general biological inventory
   sponsored by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute and the Tropic
   Star Lodge. During the two weeks, we recorded 179 species, of which we
   collected 112 species. We recorded three restricted-range species, all
   near-threatened at the global level, and one globally-threatened
   species: Great Green Macaw. Furthermore, we collected two species at
   elevations substantially below previously published records for Panama,
   and we report the first instance of syntopic breeding condition Purple
   and Shining Honeycreepers (Cyanerpes sp.), as well as several first
   records of non-forest species for southwestern Darien Province.
C1 Miller, Matthew J.; Smithsonian Tropical Resarch Institute, Apartado
   0843-03092, Balboa, Panama, Panama.
EM millerma@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0123-9082
BD Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America
DE Aves [Panama / Darien, south west / Biology; distribution; faunal list;
   new record]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Aves (Vertebrata): [New record].
