PT J
AN ZOOR15204022894
DT Article
TI Diversity and distribution of the Diptera Chironomidae in 22 springs in
   Veneto Prealps.
FT Diversita e distribuzione dei ditteri chironomidi in 22 sorgenti
   prealpine (Veneto).
AU Lencioni, Valeria (valeria.lencioni@mtsn.tn.it) 
   Sartori, Gianni
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 36
PS 35-45
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The chironomid fauna from 22 springs in the Veneto Prealps was studied
   within the CESSPA project (Censimento e Studio delle Sorgenti e dei
   Pozzi del territorio alpino e prealpino di competenza dell'Autorita di
   Bacino del Fiume Adige, 2007-2009). About 700 larvae were collected,
   belonging to 38 taxa of which 16 crenophilous (e.g., Brillia bifida,
   Heleniella serratosioi, Thienemannia gracilis) and 5 new to the Italian
   springs (Bryophaenocladius spp., Eukiefferiella similis,
   Parametriocnemus sp. A, Pseudorthocladius sp., Tvetenia discoloripes).
   Natural and moderately to highly disturbed springs (e.g., by water
   captation, agriculture, etc.) and different spring types (rheocrenes,
   helocrenes and limnocrenes) are colonized by different genera and
   species, highlighting the role of chironomids as indicators of different
   levels of integrity and quality. Furtheromre, even the cold springs at
   highest altitudes, natural or moderately disturbed (e.g., by pasture),
   host different chironomid communities than the warmer and generally
   highly disturbed lowland springs. Environmental variables that better
   explain the species distribution we observed with CCA analysis are
   physic-chemical (e.g., nutrients), hydrological (e.g., discharge) and
   biological (e.g., riparian vegetation and the consequent shading)
   parameters. Overall these results implement the knowledge on autoecology
   of non-biting species, giving information on their crenophilous habit
   and ecological valency.
C1 Lencioni, Valeria; Museo Sci, Sez Zool Invertebrati & Idrobiol, Via
   Calepina 14, Trento, I-38122, Italy, Italy.
EM valeria.lencioni@mtsn.tn.it
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1590-8399
BD Animals and man; Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lotic water;
   Abiotic factors; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Bryophaenocladius; Eukiefferiella similis; Parametriocnemus;
   Pseudorthocladius; Tvetenia discoloripes [Italy /  / New record]. 
   Chironomidae [Disturbance by man / Anthropogenic pressure / ] [Community
   structure /  / ] [Environmental indicators /  / ] [Spring water /  / ]
   [Abiotic factors / Environmental variables / ] [Italy / Veneto Pralps /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   Parametriocnemus (Chironomidae): [New record].

TI On the genus Sporades Fauvel, 1882 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechini)
   with the description of three new species from New Caledonia.
AU Giachino, Pier Mauro (PierMauro.Giachino@regione.piemonte.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 36
PS 47-54

PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species of Sporades Fauvel, 1882 (Carabidae, Trechini) are
   described from the central part of New Caledonia: Sporades beatricis
   n.sp., S. daccordii n. sp. and S. millei n. sp.. New chorological data
   are given about Sporades sexpunctatus Fauvel, 1882, S. perileptoides
   Donabauer, 2011, S. testaceus Ueno, 1966 and S. macrops Ueno, 1966. A
   subdivision of the genus Sporades into five distinct species groups is
   proposed.

   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae).

AB Three new synonymies are proposed: Eusphalerum minutum (Fabricius, 1792)
   = E. anatolicum (Coiffait, 1976); Eusphalerum aetolicum (Kraatz, 1858) =
   E. sicanum Zanetti, 1980; Eusphalerum parnassicum (Bernhauer, 1910) = E.

   sp. (Italy, Molise), E. assingi nov. sp. (Albania), E. solodovnokovi
   nov. sp. (Greece), E. taygeticum nov. sp. (Greece), E. samai nov. sp.
   (Greece), E. caucasicum feldmanni nov. ssp. (Israel), and Phyllodrepa

TI The Italian species of the group Leiosoma scrobiferum with descriprion
   of six new species (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Molytini).
FT Le specie italiane del gruppo di Leiosoma scrobiferum con descrizione di
   sei specie nuove (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Molytini).
AU Pedroni, Guido (guido-pedroni@libero.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 36
PS 73-90
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Italian species of Leiosoma Stephens, 1829 close to L. scrobiferum
   Rottenberg, 1871 are revised. The group scrobiferum is defined, and L.
   baudii Bedel, 1884 is raised to species level. A neotypus of L.
   scrobiferum and the lectotypus of L. baudii are selected, and six new
   species are described from Italy: L. dardagnense n. sp., L. hernicum n.
   sp., L. alpinum n. sp., L. fiscellense n. sp., L. angelinii n. sp., L.
   colonnellii n. sp. Leiosoma hipponense Desbrochers, 1875 from Algeria is
   included in the scrobiferum group. A key to the Italian species of the
   group is provided, as well as remarks about the ecology and host plants
   of a number of Leiosoma. Leiosoma cyanopterum is recorded from Italy
   (Julian Alps) for the first time.

TI Coleoptera Apionidae and Curculionidae of subalpine and alpine plains of
   Dolomiti di Brenta (Trentino Alto Adige) with description of Tropiphorus
   paulae n. sp from the subalpine plane (Coleoptera, Apionidae,

   paulae n. sp. del piano subalpino (Coleoptera, Apionidae,
   Curculionidae).
AU Pedroni, Guido (guido-pedroni@libero.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 36
PS 91-108
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A study on the Coleoptera Apionidae and Curculionidae of high altitude
   of the Dolomiti di Brenta ( Northern Italy) is presented, and have bring
   to know 37 species and 16 genera. Of particular importance is the
   description of a new species for the science: Tropiphorus paulae n.sp.
   from Monte Spinale, close to Tropiphorus cucullatus (Bonsdorff, 1785).
   The reletively high number of species found indicates a richness in
   biodiversity. Some species are also local and quite rare, as
   Otiorhynchus eremicola, Otiorhynchus schmidti tridentinus, Tropiphorus
   obtusus, Dichotrachelus stierlini stierlini, Dichotrachelus vulpinus
   vulpinus and Tropiphorus paulae n.sp. Are also given notes about
   ecology, distribution and biogeography of the species found.

DT Article
TI The Cretaceous fishes of Nardo. 34[degree]. Nardoelops nybelini gen. et
   sp. nov. and Lebonichthys nardoensis sp. nov. (Teleostei, Elopomorpha).
FT Les poissons cretaces de Nardo. 34[degree]. Nardoelops nybelini gen. et
   sp. nov. et Lebonichthys nardoensis sp. nov. (Teleostei, Elopomorpha).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
   Capasso, Luigi
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 36
PS 3-23
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The osteology of two elopomorph teleosts from the marine
   Campano-Maastrichtian of Nardo (Lecce province, Apulia, southern Italy),
   Nardoelops nybelini gen. and sp. nov. (Elopidae) and Lebonichthys
   nardoensis sp. nov. (Albulidae), is described in details. In Nardoelops
   nybelini, the mesethmoid is narrow and without lateral processes and
   visible ethmoid sensory commissure. The jaws, the vomer and the
   parasphenoid are toothless. The premaxilla is short. The lower jaw is
   elongated, devoid of coronoid process and articulated with the quadrate
   behind the orbit. The angular, articular and retroarticular are fused.
   The first infraorbital exhibits a well developed anterior dorsal
   process. The posterior infraorbitals are large. The hyoid bar is long,
   robust, devoid of beryciform foramen and bearing numerous branchiostegal
   rays. Lebonichthys nardoensis differs from the three other species of
   the genus, known in the Upper Cretaceous of Lebanon, by some characters
   of its caudal skeleton.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Blvd Souverain 142 Boite 8, Bruxelles, B-1170, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8402

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Nardoelops [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,

DT Article
TI The Cretaceous fishes of Nardo. 35[degree]. Complements to the study of
   halecostomes Belonostomus (Aspidorhynchiformes) and Pseudopycnodus
   (Pycnodontiformes).
FT Les poissons cretaces de Nardo. 35[degree]. Complements a l'etude des
   halecostomes Belonostomus (Aspidorhynchiformes) and Pseudopycnodus
   (Pycnodontiformes).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
   Capasso, Luigi
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 36
PS 25-44
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB New data are presented concerning the two halecostomes from the
   ichthyofauna of the Campanian-Maastrichtian of Nardo (province of Lecce,
   Apulia, southern Italy). Belonostomus marquesbritoi sp. nov.
   (Aspidorhynchiformes) differs from the other species of the genus by its
   caudal skeleton and shares a peculiar apomorphy with Belonostomus sp. 2
   from the Cenomanian of Lebanon and Israel, the presence of strong spines
   on the dorsal and ventral scales just before the tail. The cranial
   osteology of Pseudopycnodus nardoensis (Pycnodontiformes) places this
   fish as the more primitive member of the Pycnodontinae, a subfamily also
   containing the genera Pycnodus, Oropycnodus and Polazzodus.

   Belgium.

PT J
AN ZOOR15012073860
DT Article
TI Frippia labroiformis n. gen. n. sp., a new perciform fish from the
   Eocene of Pesciara di Bolca, Italy.
AU Bannikov, Alexandre F.
   Carnevale, Giorgio (aban@paleo.ru) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 51
IS 3
PS 155-165
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of percoid fish, Frippia labroiformis n. gen. n.
   sp. from the Eocene of Pesciara di Bolca, northern Italy, is described
   based on three well-preserved specimens characterized by a moderately
   elongate body and a short and deep caudal peduncle. Frippia n. gen.
   exhibits a unique combination of features, including the following: weak
   pharyngeal apophysis of the parasphenoid; orbit with sclerotic
   ossifications; jaws with single series of strong conical teeth; slightly
   curved preopercle with smooth posterior margin; opercle devoid of
   spines; six branchiostegal rays; blunt and conical lower pharyngeal
   teeth; 26 (10+16) vertebrae; caudal skeleton with urostylar complex
   fused to uroneural and third and fourth hypurals, first and second
   hypurals fused, fifth hypural and parhypural autogenous, three epurals,
   autogenous haemal spines of second and third preural vertebrae, and low
   neural crest on second preural vertebra; caudalfin rounded with 17
   principal rays and six to seven upper and five to six lower procurrent
   rays; predorsal formula 0/0/0+2/1+1/; continuous dorsal fin with nine
   spines and 14 soft rays; anal fin with three strong spines and 10 rays;
   pectoral fin with 15 rays; pelvic fin with one spine and five long rays,
   the longest reaching posteriorly to anal-fin origin; scales relatively
   large, thin and finely ctenoid on trunk and cycloid on head Because of
   its unique combination of features Frippia n. gen. cannot be confidently
   assigned to any of the existing extant or fossil percoid families and it
   is therefore interpreted herein as incertae sedis within the Percoidei.
C1 Carnevale, Giorgio; Univ Turin, Dipartimento Sci Terra, Via Valperga
   Caluso 35, Turin, I-10125, Italy, Italy.
EM aban@paleo.ru
RI Bannikov, Alexander F./P-9902-2015
SC Zoology
SN 0375-7633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Frippia [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Frippia labroiformis [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes
OR Frippia (Perciformes): [Gen nov, Of family Incertae sedis, Type species
   Frippia labroiformis, p. 156, Eocene; Fossil].

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Risananeiza crassaparies n. sp from the upper Chattian of Porto Badisco
   (southern Apulia, Italy).
AU Benedetti, Andrea (andrea.benedetti@uniroma1.it) 
   Briguglio, Antonino
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 51
IS 3
PS 167-176
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Rotaliidae, Risananeiza crassaparies n. sp., is
   described from the upper Chattian of the Porto Badisco Calcarenites
   (Salento Peninsula, Southern Italy). The studied specimens are assigned
   to the foraminiferal genus Risananeiza based on the presence of vertical
   canals in both the ventral and dorsal side of the test, and an
   intraseptal canal system that evolves into marginal sutural canals. The
   new species differs from the type species of the genus, R. pustulosa, in
   having a lower chamber lumen, and smaller dimension.

DT Article
TI The cryptobiotic foraminifer Troglotella? panormitana n. sp from the
   Valanginian of Sicily, Italy. Mode of life of the genus Troglotella
   Wernli & Fookes, 1992.
AU Cherchi, Antonietta (acherchi@unica.it) 
   Schroeder, Rolf
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 51
IS 3
PS 177-183
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The cryptobiotic foraminifer Troglotella incrustans Wernli & Fookes,
   1992 from the Upper Tithonian of the Madonie Mountains (Sicily) and
   Troglotella? panormitana n. sp. from the Valanginian of Monte Pellegrino
   near Palermo (Sicily) are described. A new interpretation of the mode of
   life of T. incrustans is presented and compared with previous theories.
   The embryo settled on the surface of the substrate, bored a tunnel, and
   after having reached a certain depth bioactivity in a downwards
   direction ceased. A series of uniserially arranged post-embryonic
   chambers was then formed in an upwards direction towards the substrate
   surface. Subsequent to this growth stage, irregular epilithic chambers
   were formed. However, the possibility that the growth of the test may
   have sometimes begun at the base of a pre-existing cavity cannot be
   excluded.
C1 Cherchi, Antonietta; Univ Cagliari, Dipartimento Sci Chim & Geol, Via
   Trentino 51, Cagliari, I-09127, Italy, Italy.
EM acherchi@unica.it
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0375-7633

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Cretaceous / Valanginian / ]. 
   Troglotella? panormitana [Sicily /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans

   P. 180; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new species of Sangiorgioichthys (Actinopterygii, Semionotiformes)
   from the Kalkschieferzone of Monte San Giorgio (Middle Triassic; Meride,
   Canton Ticino, Switzerland).
AU Lombardo, Cristina (cristina.lombardo@unimi.it) 
   Tintori, Andrea
   Tona, Daniele
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 51
IS 3
PS 203-212
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The genus Sangiorgioichthys is one of the few Semionotidae known from
   the Middle Triassic. The type species S. aldae Tintori & Lombardo, 2007
   has been found in Late Ladinian marine deposits of both the Italian and
   Swiss sides of Monte San Giorgio. A second species, S. sui
   Lopez-Arbarello et al., 2011 described from the Pelsonian (Middle
   Anisian) of Luoping (Yunnan, South China) has extended the range of the
   genus both in time and space. A further species of Sangiorgioichthys,
   Sangiorgioichthys valmarensis n. sp., is described herein from the Late
   Ladinian Kalkschieferzone (Meride Limestone) of the Monte San Giorgio
   area, the same unit yielding the type species. Sangiorgioichthys
   valmarensis n. sp. differs from the already known species in number and
   arrangement of suborbitals, shape of the teeth and in shape and row
   number of the scales. The new species of Sangiorgioichthys increases the
   diversity of Semionotidae already in the Middle Triassic, indicating
   that the explosive radiation of Semionotidae during the Norian was
   preceded by a first phase of diversification during the Middle Triassic.
C1 Lombardo, Cristina; Dipartimento Sci Terra Ardito Desio, Via Mangiagalli
   34, Milan, I-20133, Italy, Italy.
EM cristina.lombardo@unimi.it
RI Tintori, Andrea/D-7878-2014
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0375-7633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   systematics] [Triassic / Middle Triassic / ]. 
   Sangiorgioichthys valmarensis [Switzerland /  / new species] [Triassic /
    / ].

   Semionotiformes

   Triassic, P. 206; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Gastropods from the Norian (Late Triassic) Nayband Formation near Natanz
   (Iran).
AU Nuetzel, Alexander (a.nuetzel@lrz.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Aghababalou, Babak
   Senowbari-Daryan, Baba
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 87
IS 1
PS 53-65
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A collection of marine gastropods from the Late Triassic (Norian)
   Nayband Formation of Iran near Isfahan consists of 207 specimens
   representing 9 species (3 species are new). Rarefaction analyses and
   diversity indices indicate that the diversity of the studied fauna is
   much lower than that from the vicinity of Ali Abad (Tabas region) and
   somewhat less diverse than that of Dizlu (Isfahan region). All known
   gastropod faunas from. the Nayband Formation are dominated by more or
   less high-spired caenogastropods. However, species composition and rank
   abundance of the most common taxa differ strongly in all three gastropod
   collections. The new species are Acilia? basistriata, Teutonica?
   natanzensis and Protorcula iranica. The present gastropod fauna is
   dominated by the caenogastropods Coelostylina conica, Protorcula iranica
   and Teutonica? natanzensis.
C1 Nuetzel, Alexander; Univ Munich, Bayer Staatssammlung Palaontol & Geol,
   Richard Wagner Str 10, Munich, D-80333, Germany, Germany.
EM a.nuetzel@lrz.uni-muenchen.de
RI Nutzel, Alexander/G-2798-2015
OI Nutzel, Alexander/0000-0002-8852-7688

SN 1214-1119

   / new species] [Triassic /  / ].

   Kuh-e Panjar mountain / ] [Triassic / Norian / ].

   Fossil].

   58; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14809063977
DT Article
TI THE BRAZILIAN GOBLIN SPIDERS OF THE NEW GENUS PREDATOROONOPS (ARANEAE:
   OONOPIDAE).
AU Brescovit, Antonio D.
   Bonaldo, Alexandre B.
   Santos, Adalberto J.
   Ott, Ricardo
   Rheims, Cristina A.
SO Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
VL 370
PS 1-68
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB The new endemic goblin spider genus Predatoroonops is erected for 17 new
   soft-bodied oonopid species from Brazil: Predatoroonops schwarzeneggeri,
   sp. nov., is the type species of the genus, P. poncho, sp. nov., P.
   billy, sp. nov., P. valverde, sp. nov., P. blain, sp. nov., P. maceliot,
   sp. nov., P. anna, sp. nov., P. rickhawkins. sp. nov., P. Dutch, sp.
   nov., P. dillon, sp. nov., P. vallarta, sp. nov., P. phillips, sp. nov.,
   P. yautja, sp. nov., P. peterharlli, sp. nov., P. mctiernani, sp. nov.,
   P. chicano, sp. nov., and P. olddemon, sp. nov. Males of this new genus
   are easily diagnosed and separated from other Oonopinae genera by the
   extremely modified male chelicerae that frontally have median furrows
   and accentuated projections. The females can be recognized by the
   genitalia, which have a conspicuous posterior receptaculum, usually
   exposed between the epigastric folds. An auxiliary character for both
   sexes could be the presence of very long pairs of ventral spines with
   pronounced bases on the legs I and II tibiae and metatarsi. The genus is
   considered endemic and the species are recorded mainly from the
   Brazilian Atlantic Forest. An identification key is provided for all
   Predatoroonops species known to date.
C1 Brescovit, Antonio D.; Inst Butantan, Lab Especial Colecoes Zool, Av
   Vital Brasil 1509, Sao Paulo, SP, BR-05503-9OO, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Rheims, Cristina/L-6117-2014; Bonaldo, Alexandre Bragio/C-6622-2011;

DT Article
TI A REVISION OF LEPOPHIDIUM (TELEOSTEI, OPHIDIIDAE), WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF
   EIGHT NEW SPECIES.
AU Robins, C. Richard (crr@ku.edu) 
   Robins, Robert H.
   Brown, Mary E.
SO Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
VL 52
IS 1
PS 1-94
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A comprehensive revision of the cusk-eel genus Lepophidium, encompassing
   all 23 known species, is presented in a single work for the first time.
   A summary discussion of the status of Lepophidium and its position in
   the Lepophidiini is presented. Systematic accounts for each species of
   Lepophidium detail meristic, mensural, and pigment pattern variability,
   including features of the skeletal and internal anatomy. Eight species
   are described as new: Lepophidium collettei n. sp., Lepophidium
   zophochir n. sp., Lepophidium entomelan n. sp., Lepophidium cultratum n.
   sp., Lepophidium crossotum n. sp., Lepophidium wileyi n. sp.,
   Lepophidium robustum n. sp., and Lepophidium gilmorei n. sp. Two
   subspecies are elevated to full species. Individual species distribution
   maps based on 1,012 collections of Lepophidium examined by the authors
   are presented. A dichotomous key to the 23 species of Lepophidium is
   provided. Study material, examined over the course of six decades by the
   senior author, is archived in various natural history museums detailed
   herein.
C1 Robins, C. Richard; Univ Kansas Lawrence, Natural Hist Museum &
   Biodivers Res Ctr, Lawrence, KS, 66045, USA, USA.
EM crr@ku.edu

DT Article
TI OCCURANCE OF ADULT MUSCID FLIES ON STICKY TRAPS IN SOME IRAQI PROVINCES.
AU Al-Saffar, H.H.
   Augul, Razzaq Sh.
   Ali, Hayder B.
   Abdul-Rassoul, M.S.
SO Bulletin of the Iraq Natural History Museum
VL 12
IS 1
PS 1-9
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Muscid flies Musca domestica L., M. biseta Hough, M. crassirostris
   Stein, M. sorbens Wied., Muscina stabulans (Fallen), Atherigona
   orientalis Schiner, Atherigona sp. and Limnophora quaterna (Loew) were
   captured by using yellow sticky traps from different provinces of Iraq
   during November 2010. The results showed the highest percentage of all
   collected species were recorded in Babylon (48.33%), while the lowest
   percentage was observed in Baghdad (4.88%). Musca domestica was the
   predominant species and was ranked first in overall prevalence in all
   provinces studies, while M. biseta was the lowest abundant species.

DT Article
TI NEW COPROLITE ICHNOTAXA FROM THE BUCKLAND COLLECTION AT THE OXFORD
   UNIVERSITY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY.
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.com) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
   Spielmann, Justin A.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 57
PS 115-124
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The Buck land collection at the University of Oxford Museum of Natural
   History (UK) is the oldest collection of coprolites in the world. It
   comprises Mesozoic and Cenozoic coprolites and other bromalites, the
   majority of which are derived from the Lower Lias of southwestern
   England. The collection includes the most comprehensive samples of two
   important British coprofaunas - the Lower Liassic of Lyme Regis and the
   Rhaetic bone bed. We describe four new coprolite ichnotaxa from this
   collection: Ichthyosaurolites duffini ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov.,
   Strabelocoprus pollardi ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov. and Plektecoprus
   whitbyensis ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov. from the Late Triassic and Early
   Liassic and Hyaenacoprus bucklandi ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov. from the
   Late Pleistocene.
C1 Hunt, Adrian P.; Flying Heritage Collect, 3407 109th St SW, Everett, WA,
   98204, USA, USA.
EM adrianhu@flyingheritage.com

DT Article
TI THE VERTEBRATE COPROLITE COLLECTION AT THE NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM
   (LONDON).
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.com) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
   Spielmann, Justin A.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 57
PS 125-130
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Natural History Museum has a diverse collection of coprolites that
   represents the second oldest coprolite collection, after the Oxford
   University Museum of Natural History. The Paleozoic collection includes
   three Carboniferous coprolites from Europe and three coprolites from the
   Early Permian of the USA. Early-middle Mesozoic specimens are
   represented by four Rhaetian coprolites from England, a diverse
   collection from the Early Jurassic of England and Late Jurassic
   coprolites from Germany and England. There are three coprolites from the
   Early Cretaceous of England, including Costacoprus chinae ichnogen. et
   ichnosp. nov., and six coprolites from the Late Cretaceous of India.
   There is one Cenozoic coprolite from Nigeria. There is need for further
   study of the collection, notably a description of the large samples from
   the Oxford Clay Formation and Purbeck Limestone Formation.
C1 Hunt, Adrian P.; Flying Heritage Collect, 3407 109th St SW, Everett, WA,
   98204, USA, USA.
EM adrianhu@flyingheritage.com

PT J

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTIVE TERMINOLOGY OF COPROLITES AND RECENT FECES.
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.com) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 57
PS 153-160
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Vertebrate coprolites and Recent feces display a wide range of
   morphological variation. A relatively small number of authors have
   explicitly addressed the terminology used to describe coprolites. Spiral
   coprolites externally have the appearance of a ribbon coiled around a
   long axis, but internally they consist of stacked, and spiraling, cones.
   Scroll coprolites are more analogous to a rolled sheet of paper in
   structure. These two morphologies reflect two architectures of valvular
   intestines of which Type D (mucosa forming spiraling cones, pointed
   anteriorly) is most common, and these intestines form coprolites of
   spiral morphology. The oldest possible spiral coprolites are from the
   Late Ordovician of South Africa. It is possible that some putative
   spiral vertebrate coprolites from the Ordovician-Permian might have been
   made by eurypterids. Spiral coprolites are amphipolar if the posterior
   spire constitutes more than 75% of the length; otherwise they are
   heteropolar. Heteropolar coprolites are microspiral, if the posterior
   spire constitutes less than 50% of the length of the coprolite in
   lateral view, and macrospiral if it represents 50% or more. The end of a
   spiral coprolite that externally appears to be more tightly spiraled is
   the posterior end. Scroll coprolites are very uncommon. Eucoprus
   cylindratus ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov. is a cylindrical coprolite with
   no inclusions. We recognize 27 morphotypes of coprolites and Recent
   vertebrate feces in 11 main categories: A, Cylindrical, elongate (length
   > 5 x diameter); B, Cylindrical, short (length < 5 x diameter); C,
   Subrounded; D, Flattened rounded plates that accumulate in circular
   piles; E, Reniform; F, Spiral; G, Elongate coiled cylinder; H, Thin and
   ovoid; I, Thin and linear; J, Splatter; and K, Irregular in shape.
C1 Hunt, Adrian P.; Flying Heritage Collect, 3407 109th St SW, Everett, WA,
   98204, USA, USA.
EM adrianhu@flyingheritage.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications;
   Dictionaries; Nutrition; Digestion; Defaecation; Ecology; Fossil traces;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Mesozoic
DE Eucoprus [Fossil excreta / New genus, Mesozoic & Tertiary / ] [Tertiary
   /  / New genus described from fossil excreta] [Mesozoic /  / ]. 
   Eucoprus cylindratus [Fossil excreta / New species, Tertiary & Triassic,
   New Mexico / ] [New Mexico /  / new species; Described from fossil

PT J
AN ZOOR15204021818
DT Article
TI The shark Carcharhinus sp. from the Middle Eocene of Jamaica and the
   Eocene record of Carcharhinus.
AU Underwood, Charlie J.
   Gunter, Gavin C.
SO Caribbean Journal of Earth Science
VL 44
PS 25-30
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An upper tooth of a previously unrecorded species of the shark
   Carcharhinus was recovered from the Middle Eocene of Jamaica. This
   represents one of the oldest examples of the genus, which today is one
   of the dominant groups of predators within a variety of tropical
   environments. This is also the oldest record of a carcharhinid shark
   from marginal marine facies and confirms that the early radiation of
   Carcharhinus occurred within Tethyan regions.
C1 Underwood, Charlie J.; Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences,
   Birkbeck College, London WC1E7HX, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0799-0901
BD Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Carcharhinus [Evolution / Evolutionary implications / New record;
   systematics] [Jamaica /  / ] [Eocene / Middle Eocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Carcharhiniformes, Carcharhinidae
OR Carcharhinus (Carcharhinidae): [Fossil; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15110062194
DT Article
TI The fauna of Agromyzidae (Diptera) in the Gemer region (Central
   Slovakia), with descriptions of three new species from Slovakia.
AU Cerny, Milos
SO Casopis Slezskeho Zemskeho Muzea Serie A Vedy Prirodni
VL 61
IS 1
PS 49-76
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the fauna of leaf-mining flies (Diptera: Agromyzidae) in the
   Gemer region (Slovakia) is presented. A total of 140 species of
   Agromyzidae are recorded from the Gemer region in central Slovakia
   (Muranska planina NP - 126 species, Slovensky raj NP 54 species,
   Slovensky has NP 22 species). Three new species, Cerodontha (Butomomyza)
   gemerensis sp. n., Chromatomyia cepelaki sp. n. and Liriomyza muranica
   sp. n., are described from Slovakia (Gemer region). All descriptions are
   supplemented by illustrations of diagnostic features including those of
   the male and female terminalia. Twenty-one species, Cerodontha
   (Dizygomyza) luzulae (Groschke, 1957), Hexomyza simplicoides (Hendel,
   1920), Liriomyza scorzonerae Ryden, 1951, L. urophorina Mik, 1894,
   Napomyza bellidis Griffiths, 1967, N. cichorii Spencer, 1966, N.
   maritima von Tschirnhaus, 1981, Ophiomyia spenceri Cerny, 1985, O.
   stenophaga Pakalniskis, 1998, Phytomyza adjuncta Hering, 1928, P.
   brischkei Hendel, 1922, P. griffithsi Spencer, 1963, P. medicaginis
   Hering, 1925, P. podagrariae Hering, 1954, P. rydeni Hering, 1934, P.
   salviae (Hering, 1924), P. soenderupi Hering, 1941, P. spoliata Strobl,
   1906, P. trolliivora Hering, 1935, P. tussilaginis Hendel, 1925 and P..
   vitalbae Kaltenbach, 1872, are recorded from Slovakia for the first
   time. The significance of the regional fauna of Agromyzidae in the Gemer
   area is discussed.
SC Zoology
SN 1211-3026
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Agromyzidae [Zoogeography /  / New record; systematics; annotated faunal
   list] [Slovakia / Gemer region / distribution]. 
   Cerodontha (Butomomyza) gemerensis; Chromatomyia cepelaki; Liriomyza
   muranica [Slovakia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Agromyzidae
OR Agromyzidae (Cyclorrhapha): [New record]. 
   Cerodontha (Butomomyza) gemerensis (Agromyzidae): [Sp nov, Slovakia, P.
   52]. 
   Chromatomyia cepelaki (Agromyzidae): [Sp nov, Slovakia, P. 55]. 
   Liriomyza muranica (Agromyzidae): [Sp nov, Slovakia, P. 57].

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the genus Singilis Rambur, 1837 of
   Africa (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Lebiini).
AU Anichtchenko, A.V. (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 9-12
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper deals with the taxonomy of several outstanding African
   species of the genus Singilis Rambur, 1837. Two new species are
   described: S. montanus sp. n. (Malawi), S. basilewskyi sp. n.
   (Zimbabwe). Two new species groups of the genus from tropical Africa are
   established: "montanus" species group and "cyaneus" species group. A key
   to species of both groups, illustrations of habitus and aedeagus are
   provided.
C1 Anichtchenko, A.V.; Institute of Systematic Biology, Daugavpils
   University, Vienibas iela, 13-229, Dagavpils LV-5400, Latvia, Latvia.

DT Article
TI A review of the genus Nalassus Mulsant, 1854 (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae:
   Helopini) of China with new concept of the distribution of the genus.
AU Nabozhenko, M.V. (nalassus@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 33-36
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two species of the genus Nalassus Mulsant, 1854: Nalassus (s. str.)
   pekinensis (Fairmaire, 1888), comb. n. (from Cylindrinotus) from Beijing
   and Nalassus (Helopocerodes) melchiades (Reitter, 1922) from Tarbagatai
   rige (Xinjiang) are recorded for China for the first time. Types of
   these species are studied; lectotype of Nalassus pekinensis is
   designated. Paleodistribution, assotiated with wide distribution of
   Turgayan flora in Middle[long dash]Late Oligocene is analized.
C1 Nabozhenko, M.V.; Azov branch of Murmansk marine biological institute,
   Kola Scientific centre, Institute of Aride zones, Southern Scientific
   centre, Russian Academy of Sciences, Chekhov str., 41, Rostov-on-Don
   344006, Russia, Russia.

PT J
AN ZOOR15003016037
DT Article
TI A review of weevils of the subgenus Hanibotus Reitter, 1912 of the genus
   Otiorhynchus Germar, 1822 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae).
AU Davidian, G.E. (GDavidian@yandex.ru) 
   Savitsky, V.Yu.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 71-99
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomic composition of the subgenus Hanibotus Reitter, 1912 of the
   genus Otiorhynchus Germar, 1822 is revised. O. auripes Stierlin, 1875 is
   transferred from the subgenus Panorosemus Reitter, 1912 to the subgenus
   Hanibotus. O. hajastani Arnoldi, 1966 and species allied to O.
   semigranulatus Stierlin, 1861 and O. coyei Marseul, 1868 are transferred
   from Hanibotus to Nubidanus Reitter, 1912. O. glazunovi Davidian et
   Savitsky, sp. n. from Iran is described. The new synonymy was
   established: O. eques Reitter, 1895 = O. sunicensis Arnoldi, 1964, syn.
   n. A key of species of the subgenus Hanibotus is given. Lectotypes of O.
   sulcibasis Reitter, 1895, O. eques Reitter, 1895, O. brevinasus Reitter,
   1910, O. pereques Reitter, 1912, O. subeques Reitter, 1912, O. iranicus
   Arnoldi, 1964, O. sunicensis Arnoldi, 1964 and O. zajcevi Arnoldi, 1964
   are designated.
C1 Davidian, G.E.; All-Russian Institute of Plant Protection, St.
   Petersburg - Pushkin 196608, Russia, Russia.
EM GDavidian@yandex.ru
RI Savitsky, Vladimir/T-2136-2017
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1814-3326

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

TI Materials on the Geometrid Moth fauna of the Northern Caucasus with
   description of Entephria cyanata alanica ssp. n. (Lepidoptera:
   Geometridae).
AU Tsvetkov, E.V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 153-154
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four Geometrid Moth species are reported as new for the fauna of the
   Northern Caucasus: Narraga tessularia (Metzner, 1845), Horisme corticata
   (Treitschke, 1835), Nebula senectaria (Herrich-Schaffer, 1852) and
   Entephria cyanata (Hubner, (1809)). N. senectaria is recorded for the
   first time for Russia. Caucasian populations of E. cyanata are
   attributed to a new subspecies E. cyanata alanica ssp. n.

TI Platypalpus negrobovi a new species of the family Hybotidae (Diptera:
   Empidoidea) from the North-West Caucasus.
AU Grootaert, P. (Patrick.Grootaert@naturalsciences.be) 
   Kustov, S.Yu.
   Shamshev, I.V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 161-163
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Platypalpus negrobovi sp. n. is described from the North-West Caucasus
   (Russia, Krasnodar Prov.). The new species belongs to the P. pallipes
   group and is closely related to P. longimanus (Corti, 1907) in having
   modified tarsomeres of male fore and mid legs.

DT Article
TI Systematics of the genus Katangaia Parent, 1933 (Diptera:
   Dolichopodidae).
AU Grichanov, I.Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 8
IS 1
PS 165-167
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Katangaia Parent, 1933 is reviewed. The systematic position
   and characters of this Afrotropical genus are discussed. It comprises
   four species including a new species Katangaia tanzaniensis sp. n. from
   Tanzania. A check list of species of this genus and a revised key to
   Afrotropical species are provided. The following recombinations are also
   proposed: Sybistroma leptocercus (Stackelberg, 1949: 682), comb. n.
   (from Hercostomus), Sybistroma paradoxopterus (Stackelberg, 1949: 681),
   comb. n. (from Hercostomus), Katangaia octaviana (Grichanov, 2004),
   comb. n. (from Polymedon).
C1 Grichanov, I.Ya.; All-Russian Institute of Plant Protection, Podbelskiy
   roadway, 3, St. Petersburg, Pushkin 196608, Russia, Russia.
EM grichanov@mail.ru

   position; Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa

   species]. 
   Katangaia tanzaniensis [Tanzania /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   Dolichopodidae

   to, Sybistroma, p. 165].

   [Referred to, Sybistroma, p. 166].

   position, P. 165; Key to species, Afrotropical region, P. 167]. 
   Katangaia octaviana - (Grichanov 2004) (Dolichopodidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Polymedon, p. 166].

   Katangaia, p. 166].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025885
DT Article
TI A deep-bodied ginglymodian fish from the Middle Triassic of eastern
   Yunnan Province, China, and the phylogeny of lower neopterygians.
AU Xu, GuangHui (xuguanghui@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Wu, FeiXiang
SO Chinese Science Bulletin
VL 57
IS 1
PS 111-118
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB The Ginglymodi are a group of ray-finned fishes that make up one of
   three major subdivisions of the infraclass Neopterygii. Extant
   ginglymodians are represented by gars, which inhabit freshwater
   environments of North and Central America and Cuba. Here, we report the
   discovery of well-preserved fossils of a new ginglymodian, Kyphosichthys
   grandei gen. et sp. nov., from the Middle Triassic (Anisian) marine
   deposits (Guanling Formation) in Luoping, eastern Yunnan Province,
   China. The discovery documents the first known fossil record of highly
   deep-bodied ginglymodians, adding new information on the early
   morphological diversity of this group. The studies of functional
   morphology of extant deep-bodied fishes indicate that Kyphosichthys is
   not a fast swimmer but has a good performance in precise maneuvering,
   representing a morphological adaptation to structurally complex habitats
   (e.g. thick macrophyte beds, rocky areas, or coral reefs), which differs
   from the other members of this group. A cladistic analysis with the new
   fish taxon included supports the hypothesis that the Ginglymodi are more
   closely related to the Halecomorphi than to the Teleostei. Represented
   by Felberia, Kyphosichthys, and Dapedium, a highly deep and short fish
   body type has independently evolved at least three times in the
   stem-group neopterygians, ginglymodians, and basal teleosts within the
   lower neopterygians of the Triassic.
C1 Xu, GuangHui; Key Laboratory of Evolutionary Systematics of Vertebrates,
   Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese
   Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100044, China, China.
EM xuguanghui@ivpp.ac.cn
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 1001-6538
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Evolution;
   Evolutionary adaptation; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ginglymodi; Neopterygii [Body form /  / ] [Convergence /  / ] [Phylogeny
   /  / ] [Life habit /  / ] [Mesozoic /  / ]. 
   Kyphosichthys [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Kyphosichthys grandei [Yunnan /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii
OR Ginglymodi (Actinopterygii): [Fossil]. 
   Kyphosichthys (Actinopterygii): [Gen nov, Of Ginglymodi incertae sedis,
   Type species Kyphosichthys grandei, p. 112, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Kyphosichthys grandei (Actinopterygii): [Sp nov, Yunnan, Triassic, P.
   112; Fossil]. 
   Neopterygii (Actinopterygii): [Fossil].

AN ZOOR15302010518
DT Article
TI Geographic and bathymetrical range extension for Caribboecetes
   jenikarpae Just, 1984 (Amphipoda: Ischyroceridae) from Oaxaca, Mexico.
FT Ampliacion de ambito geografico y batimetrico de Caribboecetes
   jenikarpae Just, 1984 (Amphipoda: Ischyroceridae) para las costas de
   Oaxaca, Mexico.
AU Peralta-Garcia, Edith
   del Socorro Garcia-Madrigal, Maria (ms_garcia_m@hotmail.com) 
SO Ciencia y Mar
VL 15
IS 46
PS 25-28
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB From a recent sampling 106 specimens of Caribboecetes jenikarpae Just,
   1984, were collected at 10 m depth in La Tijera, Oaxaca, configuring the
   first record for the Mexican Pacific since its description. The examined
   material has variations respect to original description, these
   variations are related to the size of the organisms. The specimens were
   found on shells of the gastropods Crassispira sp. and Anachis sp.
   Therefore not seem to have specificity in the shells that use as
   residence. The geographical and bathymetrical range is extended,
   approximately 590 km southern Pacific of Mexico and of 1.5 m to 10 m in
   deep.
C1 del Socorro Garcia-Madrigal, Maria; Univ del Mar, Lab Sistemat
   Invertebrados Marinos LABSIM, AP 47, Puerto Angel, Oaxaca, 70902,
   Mexico, Mexico.
EM ms_garcia_m@hotmail.com

   &Freshwater Biology

   Pacific Ocean

   Mexico, Oaxaca / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15008039485
PM 24260679
DT Article
TI A contribution to the taxonomy, cytogenetics and reproductive biology of
   the genus Aclerda Signoret (Homoptera, Coccinea, Aclerdidae).
AU Gavrilov-Zimin, I.A. (coccids@gmail.com) 
SO Comparative Cytogenetics
VL 6
IS 4
PS 389-395
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of scale insects, Aclerda pseudozoysiae sp. n., is
   described and illustrated. The karyotypes and some aspects of
   reproductive biology and cytogenetics of the new species species and
   Aclerda takahashii Kuwana, 1932 were studied, representing the first
   data for the genus Aclerda Signoret, 1874 and the family Aclerdidae as a
   whole. A. pseudozoysiae sp. n. has 2n= 16, bisexual reproduction, and
   heterochromatinization of one haploid set of chromosomes in male stages
   of the life cycle, matching either a Lecanoid or a Comstockioid genetic
   system. A. takahashii demonstrates 2n= 18 and unusual type of
   parthenogenesis with diploid and haploid embryos (inside each gravid
   female) without heterochromatinization. Both species are ovoviviparous;
   all stages of embryonic development occur inside the mother's body.
C1 Gavrilov-Zimin, I.A.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nab 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM coccids@gmail.com
RI Gavrilov-Zimin, Ilya A/L-5401-2013
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1993-0771; 1993-078X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Genetics; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aclerda [Reproduction / Reproductive biology / systematics]
   [Cytogenetics /  / ] [Indonesia /  / ]. 
   Aclerda pseudozoysiae [Indonesia /  / New species].

   Coccoidea

DT Article
TI Karyotype analysis of seven species of the tribe Lophiohylini (Hylinae,
   Hylidae, Anura), with conventional and molecular cytogenetic techniques.
AU Gruber, Simone Lilian (sisilgg@hotmail.com) 
   Baptista Haddad, Celio Fernando
   Kasahara, Sanae
SO Comparative Cytogenetics
VL 6
IS 4
PS 409-423
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Few species of the tribe Lophiohylini have been karyotyped so far, and
   earlier analyses were performed mainly with standard staining. Based on
   the analysis of seven species with use of routine banding and molecular
   cytogenetic techniques, the karyotypes were compared and the cytogenetic
   data were evaluated in the light of the current phylogenies. A karyotype
   with 2n = 24 and NOR in the chromosome 10 detected by Ag-impregnation
   and FISH with an rDNA probe was shared by Aparasphenodon bokermanni
   Miranda-Ribeiro, 1920, Itapotihyla langsdorffii (Dumeril and Bibron,
   1841), Trachycephalus sp., T. mesophaeus (Hensel, 1867), and T.
   typhonius (Linnaeus, 1758). Phyllodytes edelmoi Peixoto, Caramaschi et
   Freire, 2003 and P. luteolus (Wied-Neuwied, 1824) had reduced the
   diploid number from 2n = 24 to 2n = 22 with one of the small-sized pairs
   clearly missing, and NOR in the large chromosome 2, but the karyotypes
   were distinct regarding the morphology of chromosome pairs 4 and 6.
   Based on the cytogenetic and phylogenetic data, it was presumed that the
   chromosome evolution occurred from an ancestral type with 2n = 24, in
   which a small chromosome had been translocated to one or more
   unidentified chromosomes. Whichever hypothesis is more probable, other
   rearrangements should have occurred later, to explain the karyotype
   differences between the two species of Phyllodytes Wagler, 1830. The
   majority of the species presented a small amount of centromeric C-banded
   heterochromatin and these regions were GC-rich. The FISH technique using
   a telomeric probe identified the chromosome ends and possibly (TTAGGG)n
   -like sequences in the repetitive DNA out of the telomeres in I.
   langsdorffii and P. edelmoi. The data herein obtained represent an
   important contribution for characterizing the karyotype variability
   within the tribe Lophiohylini scarcely analysed so far.
C1 Gruber, Simone Lilian; Univ Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Av 24A,1515, Rio
   Claro, SP, BR-13506900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM sisilgg@hotmail.com
RI Haddad, Celio F. B./C-4267-2012
OI Haddad, Celio F. B./0000-0002-7044-5764
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology
SN 1993-0771; 1993-078X
BD Genetics; Cytogenetics; Chromosomes; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Aparasphenodon bokermanni; Itapotihyla langsdorffii; Phyllodytes
   edelmoi; Phyllodytes luteolus; Trachycephalus; Trachycephalus
   mesophaeus; Trachycephalus typhonius [Karyotype /  / ] [Brazil /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Hylidae
OR Aparasphenodon bokermanni (Hylidae).

PT J
AN ZOOR15109055585
DT Article
TI Systematic placement of some Eocene gastropods with the last whorl
   disjunct (Mollusca, Gastropoda, Caenogastropoda): Delphinula conica,
   Omalaxis, Eoatlanta.
FT Position systematique de quelques gasteropodes de l'Eocene a dernier
   tour disjoint (Mollusca, Gastropoda, Caenogastropoda): Delphinula
   conica, Omalaxis, Eoatlanta.
AU Lozouet, Pierre (lozouet@mnhn.fr) 
SO Cossmanniana
VL 14
PS 57-66
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The systematic placement of three classic groups of the Paris basin
   Eocene is reconsidered. The new genus Trypatrochus (included in the
   family Trypanaxidae) is proposed for Delphinula conica previously
   included in the genus Vermicularia (Turritellidae). A new species of the
   Trypatrochus is described from the Priabonian of Aquitaine Basin; this
   species has a planktotrophic protoconch close to that of the
   Campaniloidea. The Omalaxinae, previously classified close to the
   Heterobranchia (Architectonicoidea), is considered as a subfamily of the
   Turritellidae on the basis of the teleoconch and protoconch characters.
   The genus Eoatlanta is removed from the Pterotracheoidea (Heteropoda)
   and included in the Vanikoroidea (Hipponicidae). One new species of
   Eoatlanta is described from the Priabonian of Landes (Aquitaine Basin).
C1 Lozouet, Pierre; Museum Natl Hist Nat, 55 Rue Buffon,CP 51, Paris,
   F-75005, France, France.
EM lozouet@mnhn.fr

DT Article
TI Hermit crabs in the Miocene shelly sands of Channay-sur-Lathan
   (Indre-et-Loire, France).
FT Des bernard l'hermites dans les faluns miocenes de Channay-sur-Lathan
   (Indre-et-Loire, France).
AU Gagnaison, Cyril (cyril.gagnaison@lasalle-beauvais.fr) 
SO Cossmanniana
VL 14
PS 67-72
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hermit crab fossils are known in the literature from the Miocene shelly
   sands of Touraine. In 1997, three specimens identified as Paguroidea
   propodi were discovered in the La Sonneterie quarry (Channay-sur-Lathan,
   Indre-et-Loire, France). New descriptions of these fossils make it
   possible to relate them to the families Paguridae (Paguridae indet.) and
   Diogenidae (Paguristes gagnaisoni nov. sp.). These hermit crabs complete
   the list of decapods crustaceans from the Miocene basin of
   Savigne-sur-Lathan/Noyant-sous-le-Lude.

DT Article
TI The Remains of Small Mammals in the Eagle Owl (Bubo Bubo) Pellets from
   Basakli Village (Diyarbakir-Bismil) Province.
FT Basakli Koyu (Diyarbakir-Bismil) Civarinda Yasayan Puhu (Bubo
   bubo)'larin Peletlerindeki Kucuk Memelilerin Dagilimi.
AU Seckin, Seven
   Kaya, Alaettin
   Coskun, Yuksel (yukselc@dicle.edu.tr) 
SO Cumhuriyet Universitesi Fen Edebiyat Fakultesi Fen Bilimleri Dergisi
VL 33
IS 1
PS 34-42
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Turkish
U1 0
U2 0
AB 52 pellets Eagle owl (Bubo bubo) from Diyarbakir-Bismil, Basakli village
   were collected at March-2006 and remains were analiysed. In the pellets,
   9 different mammalian species (Mus macedonicus, Microtus guentheri,
   Rattus rattus, Rattus norvegicus, Rattus sp., Meriones tristrami,
   Cricetulus migratorius, Crocidura suaveolens, Suncus etruscus) and some
   bird remains were identified. Mus macedonicus was mostly found with a
   ratio of 38,5 % in mammal remains. It was followed by Microtus
   guentheri, Crocidura suaveolens and Suncus etruscus with the rate of
   24,2 %, 13.2% and 2.2 %, respectively. Suncus etruscus is the first
   record for Bismil. Because of the sampling area was close to the
   settlement, Mus macedonicus became most prefered prey item. Bird remains
   were consisted 14,2 % the part of pellets contents. In Diyarbakir-Bismil
   province, Bubo bubo prey preference were mainly consist of Murids,
   additionaly the other small mammals species and bird remains were
   identified, this indicate that Eagle Owl fed on a large scale living
   things.
C1 Coskun, Yuksel; Dicle Univ, Fen Fak, Diyarbakir, Turkey, Turkey.
EM yukselc@dicle.edu.tr

DT Article
TI A New Species of Gill Monogenea (Dactylogyrus Diesing, 1850) from
   Hampala macrolepidota van Hasselt and Kuhl 1823 (Cyprinidae) in Sungai
   Kiang and Tanjung Mentong, Tasik Kenyir Lake: Malaysia.
AU Modu, B.M.
   Saiful, M.F.
   Kassim, Zaleha
   Hassan, Marina
   Shaharom-Harrison, F.M.
SO Current Research Journal of Biological Sciences
VL 4
IS 4
PS 488-491
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During surveys of gill monogenean parasites in tropical freshwater lake
   (Kenyir Lake) in Malaysia, one new species of the genus Dactylogyrus
   Diesing, 1850 was found and described. The study aims at investigating
   monogenean parasites parasitizing Hampala macrolepidota Van Hasselt and
   Kuhl 1823 (Cyprinids) in Sungai Kiang and Tanjung Mentong from the
   Kenyir Lake, Malaysia. In record there were three known species of the
   genus Dactylogyrus found in this fish host in Malaysia viz: D. hampali,
   D. macrolepidoti and D. quadribrachiatus and one also known in Thailand:
   D. anchorobustussumming to four known Dactylogyrus sp. parasitizing
   Hampala macrolepidota from this region. Taxonomic and morphometric data
   for this new species was presented. Dactylogyrus terengganusis n. sp.
   differs from the previously described species at the species level
   principally by its hamuli, dorsal connective bar, copulatory organ
   accessory piece and worm size.

   Kuala Terengganu, 21030, Malaysia, Malaysia.

DT Book
TI Deep sea shrimps of the family Nematocarcinidae (history of study,
   systematic, distribution, and biology).
AU Burukovsky, Rudolf Nikolaevich
BA Burukovsky, Rudolf Nikolaevich
SO Deep sea shrimps of the family Nematocarcinidae (history of study,
   systematic, distribution, and biology).
PS 1-288
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Shrimp family Nematocarcinidae are widely distributed on continental
   slope and abyssal of the World ocean. It includes six genera, four of
   which are monotypic, and the fourth contains only two species. The sixth
   genus [long dash] Ne- matocarcinus [long dash] is very diverse. Among
   representatives of this species there are mass obligatory
   detritophagues, forming consortia in areas with terrigenous
   sedimentogenesis where they are species[long dash]edificators. The large
   commercial predatory shrimps family Aristeidae (attacking predators,
   shrimp-eaters) are consorts in these communities (Burukovsky, 1985,
   1989; 2009; Burukovsky, Romensky, 1976, 1992; Burukovsky et al., 1982).
   Because of this the family description is based mostly on its main
   genus. During the work with Nematocarcinus collection in the National
   Museum of Natural History (Paris) the author did find new taxonomic
   features previously unknown, and re-considered other taxonomic features.
   A necessity of a complete revision of the genus became obvious,
   particularly because some type series turned out to be a mixture of the
   different species (Burukovsky, 2000). Later the author did investigate
   collections of the National Museum of Natural History, Washington
   (USNM), British Museum Natural History (BMNH), South African Museum
   (SAM), collections of RV "Meteor" stored in Forschunginstitut und
   Naturmuseum Senckenberg, Frankfurt-am-Main, Germany, collections of
   famous German Deep-sea and South Polar expeditions and some samples from
   Indian Museum from R. M. I. S. "Investigator" stored in Museum fuer
   Naturkunde Berlin (MNB), collections Institute Marine Biology Nation
   Taiwan Ocean University, shrimp collections of Zoological Institute of
   the Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg. Some materials from
   collections of Instituto de Ciencias del Mar (ICMD), Tasmanian Museum in
   Hobart, Australia (TMH), National Museum of New Zealand, Te Papa
   Tongarewa (NMNZ) were also investigated. All of 43 valid Nematocarcinus
   species are described or re-described, among them 25 [long dash] new to
   the science. Author also did describe four new genera and divided the
   family into two subfamilies: (Nematocarcininae and Lipkiinae).
PU "Prospekt Nauki" Publishing House
PA Saint Petersburg
SC History &Philosophy of Science; Zoology
BN 978-5-903090-81-5

   Combination; Taxonomy; Key; Animals and man; Documentation;

   Physical factors; Marine zones

   systematics] [Comprehensive works / Monograph / ] [Literature review / 
   / ] [Ecology /  / ] [Vertical distribution / Species bathymetric ranges

AB Supertribe Aphidoletidi, stat. n. includes two tribes: Aphidoletini s.
   str. (9 genera and 17 species) and Bremiini stat. n. with subtribes
   Bremiina s.l. (6 genera and 27 species) and Mirabilidiplosina subtr. n.
   (14 genera and 27 species). Seven new genera and fourteen new species,
   belonging to subtribe Mirabilidiplosina are described: Semperanta
   versura gen. et sp. n., S. diserta sp. n., S. munita sp. n., Viceversa
   caesariata gen. n. et sp. n., Tantumaura candela gen. n. et sp. n., T

   geniata gen. n. et sp. n., Exipsofonta hariola gen. n. et sp. n.,

   given. Key to genera of the subtribe Mirabilidiplosina and species from
   the genera Mirabilidiplosis, Falciformidiplosis, Semperanta and
   Tantuinaura are proposed.

DT Article
TI A new taxonomic arrangement for Paleorhinus scurriensis.
AU Stocker, Michelle R. (mstocker@utexas.edu) 
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 251-263
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The paraphyletic genus 'Paleorhinus' is understood currently as a
   cosmopolitan phytosaur taxon from the Late Triassic. There is no
   consensus regarding the number of species of 'Paleorhinus,' with
   multiple species and genera synonymised into a single genus or even a
   single species at various points in its published history. The taxonomy
   is confounded by historical descriptions without the benefit of
   comparisons to more recently collected specimens, emphasis on
   plesiomorphic cranial morphology as diagnostic features of the genus,
   and lack of cladistic analyses. When included in a recent explicitly
   cladistic phylogenetic analysis, the holotype of 'Paleorhinus'
   scurriensis (TTU P-00539) was found to be the earliest-branching
   phytosaur with respect to other North American specimens previously
   referred to 'Paleorhinus,' and is generically distinct from Paleorhinus.
   'Paleorhinus' scurriensis differs from all known phytosaurs in five
   unambiguous characters: basitubera widely separated mediolaterally;
   ridge present on lateral surface of jugal; thickened shelf present along
   posteroventral edge of expanded pterygoid-quadrate wing; 'septomaxillae'
   separated and excluded from internarial septum; and nasal swelling
   present posterior to posterior borders of nares. This detailed
   morphological description of an early-branching phytosaur taxon is a
   first step towards resolving long-standing issues surrounding specific
   anatomical features and relationships among early members of the clade.
C1 Stocker, Michelle R.; Field Museum Nat Hist, 1400 South Lake Shore Dr,
   Chicago, IL, 60605, USA, USA.
EM mstocker@utexas.edu
SC Paleontology; Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Description; Combination; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Wannia [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Thecodontia,
   Lepidosauria, Rhynchocephalia, Rhynchosauridae
OR Wannia (Thecodontia): [Gen nov, Of suborder Phytosauria, Type species
   Paleorhinus scurriensis Langston 1949, p. 253, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Wannia scurriensis - (Langston 1949) (Thecodontia): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 253; Redescription, P. 254; Comb nov, Transferred from Paleorhinus,
   p. 253; Fossil]. 
   Paleorhinus scurriensis - Langston 1949 (Rhynchosauridae): [Designated
   type species for new genus, Wannia, p. 253; Fossil].

AN ZOOR15002005891
DT Article
TI The taxonomic status of the phytosaurs (Archosauriformes)
   Machaeroprosopus and Pseudopalatus from the Late Triassic of the western
   United States.
AU Parker, William G. (William_Parker@nps.gov) 
   Hler, Axel Hungerbu
   Martz, Jeffrey W.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 265-268
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The genus Machaeroprosopus has long been considered invalid because the
   type specimen of the Late Triassic phytosaur species, M. validus, has
   been lost. Re-examination of the primary literature regarding the
   establishment of the Late Triassic phytosaur genus Machaeroprosopus
   demonstrates that M. buceros is the correct type species, not M.
   validus. Thus, the genus level name Machaeroprosopus has priority over
   the genera Pseudopalatus and Arribasuchus and all nominal species should
   be reassigned. Reassignment of these species to Machaeroprosopus
   satisfies the requirements of the International Code of Zoological
   Nomenclature (ICZN) and preserves historical context. The name
   Pseudopalatinae is retained as the valid clade name for these phytosaurs
   because its usage falls outside of the ICZN.
C1 Parker, William G.; POB 2217,Petrified Forest Natl Pk, Petrified Forest,
   AZ, 86028, USA, USA.
EM William_Parker@nps.gov

   position; Geological time periods

OR Machaeroprosopus - Mehl 1916 (Thecodontia): [Syn nov, Arribasuchus Long
   & Murry 1995, p. 266; Syn nov, Pseudopalatus Mehl 1928, p. 266; Fossil].
   
   Machaeroprosopus jablonskiae - (Parker & Irmis 2006) (Thecodontia):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Pseudopalatus, p. 266; Fossil]. 
   Machaeroprosopus mccauleyi - (Ballew 1989) (Thecodontia): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Pseudopalatus, p. 266; Fossil]. 
   Machaeroprosopus pristinus - (Mehl 1928) (Thecodontia): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Pseudopalatus, p. 266; Fossil].

   to, Machaeroprosopus, p. 266; Fossil].

   Machaeroprosopus, p. 266; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Cranial anatomy of the Late Triassic phytosaur Machaeroprosopus, with
   the description of a new species from West Texas.
AU Hungerbuehler, Axel (axelh@mesalands.edu) 
   Mueller, Bill
   Chatterjee, Sankar
   Cunningham, Douglas P.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 269-312
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The skull anatomy of a new species of the phytosaur Machaeroprosopus is
   described for the first time on the basis of two specimens from the
   Upper Triassic Cooper Canyon Formation of Texas. Additional information
   is provided by a third specimen referred to Machaeroprosopus sp. A
   paranasal bone, an additional paired element of the narial region, is
   identified. Important new data are presented for the braincase,
   including the morphology of the epipterygoid and presphenoid, an
   anterior process of the prootic, an anteroventral process of the
   laterosphenoid, and a parasphenoid process. Machaeroprosopus lottorum n.
   sp. is characterised by four apomorphies: a supratemporal fenestra
   closed on the skull roof with bevelled anterior rim, a comparatively
   short squamosal, a flat and rugose narial rim, and medially extended
   palatines that come close to form an ossified secondary palate. With
   respect to the supratemporal fenestra, the supraoccipital-parietal
   complex and several features of the squamosal, Machaeroprosopus lottorum
   n. sp. bridges the morphological gap between species previously referred
   to the genera Pseudopalatus and Redondasaurus. A parsimony analysis of
   known species of Machaeroprosopus supports the hypothesis that the
   development of the rostral crest in Machaeroprosopus is a sexually
   dimorphic feature, and questions the validity of the genus
   Redondasaurus. Consequently, Redondasaurus is here considered a junior
   synonym of Machaeroprosopus.
C1 Hungerbuehler, Axel; Mesalands Community Coll, 911 S 10th St, Tucumcari,
   NM, 88401, USA, USA.
EM axelh@mesalands.edu
RI Chatterjee, Sankar/A-3801-2016
OI Chatterjee, Sankar/0000-0002-1065-0782

   time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI Lone Star Pterosaurs.
AU Andres, Brian (brianandres@usf.edu) 
   Myers, Timothy S.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 383-398
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 22
AB The state of Texas has one of the greatest records of pterosaurs in the
   world, surpassing all other US states and most countries in the number
   of occurrences. Uniquely, this record extends over the entire 150+
   million history of the Pterosauria. A review of this pterosaur record
   confirms at least 30 pterosaurs known from 13 occurrences, including
   five valid species. The holotypes of two of these species have been
   described before and are diagnosed and erected here as the new species
   Radiodactylus langstoni, gen. et sp. nov., named in honour of Dr. Wann
   Langston Jr, the father of Texas pterosaurology, and Alamodactylus
   byrdi, gen. et sp. nov.. Phylogenetic analysis of all Texas pterosaurs
   that can be coded for more than one character confirms that these
   species are distinct from others and occupy phylogenetic positions close
   to their original classifications. Radiodactylus langstoni is recovered
   as a non-azhdarchid azhdarchoid, Quetzalcoatlus northropi as an
   azhdarchid, Alamodactylus byrdi as a non-pteranodontoid pteranodontian,
   Aetodactylus as a pteranodontoid, and Coloborhynchus wadleighi as an
   ornithocheirid. The presence of eudimorphodontid, dsungaripterid, as
   well as other azhdarchid and pteranodontoid pterosaurs, is also
   confirmed in Texas.
C1 Andres, Brian; Univ S Florida, Dept Geol, Tampa, FL, 33620, USA, USA.
EM brianandres@usf.edu
SC Zoology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Alamodactylus; Radiodactylus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Alamodactylus byrdi; Radiodactylus langstoni [Texas /  / new species]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Pterosauria [Texas /  / distribution; faunal list; stratigraphical
   distribution; systematics] [Cretaceous /  / ] [Triassic / Late Triassic
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Pterodactyloidea

   Radiodactylus (Pterosauria): [Gen nov, Of Neoazhdarchia, family not
   given, Type species Radiodactylus langstoni, p. 387, Cretaceous;
   Fossil]. 
   Radiodactylus langstoni (Pterosauria): [Sp nov, Texas, Cretaceous, P.
   387; Fossil]. 
   Alamodactylus (Pterodactyloidea): [Gen nov, Of Pteranodontia, family not
   given, Type species Alamodactylus byrdi, p. 391, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Alamodactylus byrdi (Pterodactyloidea): [Sp nov, Texas, Cretaceous, P.
   391; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002005897
DT Article
TI The Late Jurassic pterosaurs from northern Patagonia, Argentina.
AU Codorniu, Laura (lcodor600@gmail.com) 
   Gasparini, Zulma
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 399-408
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Records of flying Jurassic reptiles are very scarce in the Southern
   Hemisphere. Upper Jurassic pterosaurs have been discovered in marine
   Tithonian sediments of the Vaca Muerta Formation, in the Neuque ' n
   Basin, Patagonia, Argentina. Only four specimens are known so far: the
   first from Arroyo Picun Leufu, and the other three from the lithographic
   limestones of Los Catutos. Here, we update knowledge of Late Jurassic
   pterosaurs from northwest Patagonia. We revise the diagnosis and
   description of a previously described pterodactyloid, which is named as
   a new genus and species, Wenupteryx uzi. This small-sized pterosaur
   shows affinities with Euctenochasmatia or Archaeopterodactyloidea, and
   represents the most complete Jurassic pterosaur so far known from the
   Southern Hemisphere. We also report a recent finding suggesting that the
   new specimen belongs to a new species of pterodactyloid pterosaur. These
   records show that at least three different taxa of pterosaurs coexisted
   in the Neuque ' n Basin: Herbstosaurus, Wenupteryx and a more derived
   pterodactyloid that represents the largest pterosaur known from the
   Upper Jurassic of Gondwana.
C1 Codorniu, Laura; Univ Nacl San Luis, Dept Geol, Chacabuco 917, San Luis,
   RA-5700, Argentina, Argentina.
EM lcodor600@gmail.com
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Wenupteryx [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Wenupteryx uzi [Argentina /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Pterosauria,
   Pterodactyloidea
OR Wenupteryx (Pterodactyloidea): [Gen nov, Family not given, Type species
   Wenupteryx uzi, p. 401, Jurassic; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002005898
DT Article
TI A new unusual tapejarid (Pterosauria, Pterodactyloidea) from the Early
   Cretaceous Romualdo Formation, Araripe Basin, Brazil.
AU Kellner, Alexander W.A. (kellner@mn.ufrj.br) 
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 409-421
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new unusual tapejarid pterosaur from the Early Cretaceous Romualdo
   Formation (Araripe Basin, Brazil) is described, based on a skull, lower
   jaw and some postcranial elements. Caupedactylus ybaka gen. et sp. shows
   the typical high nasoantorbital fenestra of the Thalassodrominae but
   lacks a palatal ridge, and shares with the Tapejarinae several features,
   including a downturned rostral end, allowing its allocation to that
   clade. Furthermore, the new species differs in having an anteriorly and
   posteriorly expanded premaxillary sagittal crest, the lacrimal process
   of the jugal strongly inclined, and a slit-like postpalatine fenestra,
   among other characters. The region of the left
   jugal-quadratojugalquadrate shows a pathology that is likely the result
   of an infection. The lateral surface of the premaxillary crest presents
   grooves that were interpreted in other pterosaurs as impressions of
   blood vessels, corroborating growing evidence that cranial crests could
   have been involved in thermoregulation. Also, the new species has a
   well-preserved palate with a large palatine forming the anterior region
   of the choanae and the postpalatine fenestra and a secondary subtemporal
   fenestra. Since the latter has been regarded as unique to
   non-pterodactyloids, its occurrence in Caupedactylus demonstrates that
   the evolution of palatal region in pterosaurs is more complex than
   previously thought.
C1 Kellner, Alexander W.A.; UFRJ, Museu Nacl, Quinta da Boa Vista S-N, Rio
   De Janeiro, RJ, BR-20940040 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM kellner@mn.ufrj.br
RI Kellner, Alexander W/H-1023-2015
OI Kellner, Alexander W/0000-0001-7174-9447
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Caupedactylus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Caupedactylus ybaka [Brazil /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Pterosauria,
   Pterodactyloidea
OR Caupedactylus (Pterodactyloidea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Tapejarinae,
   Type species Caupedactylus ybaka, p. 409, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Caupedactylus ybaka (Pterodactyloidea): [Sp nov, Brazil, Cretaceous, P.
   409; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002005905
DT Article
TI Phylogenetic relationships of Palaeogene ziphodont eusuchians and the
   status of Pristichampsus Gervais, 1853.
AU Brochu, Christopher A. (chris-brochu@uiowa.edu) 
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 521-550
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 16
AB Eusuchians with deep snouts and labiolingually compressed teeth are
   known from the Palaeogene of Laurasia. These are usually referred to
   Pristichampsinae, but the type species, Pristichampsus rollinati, is
   based on insufficiently diagnostic material and should be treated as a
   nomen dubium. At least two Lutetian species formerly referred to
   Pristichampsus can be recognised Boverisuchus magnifrons in Germany and
   possibly elsewhere in Europe, and Boverisuchus vorax, new combination,
   in western North America. Material from the middle Eocene of Italy and
   Texas may represent distinct species. A phylogenetic analysis confirms
   their close relationship and also supports a relationship with two Asian
   forms - early Eocene Planocrania datangensis and Palaeocene Planocrania
   hengdongensis. The name Planocraniidae Li 1976 is applied to this group.
   A distinctive quadrate with a prominent dorsal peak between medial and
   lateral hemicondyles is known only in Boverisuchus, and although the
   teeth of Planocrania are flattened, they are not serrated. Planocraniids
   maintain a phylogenetic position as the sister group to Crocodyloidea +
   Alligatoroidea, but this part of the tree is unstable and discovery of
   older, more primitive planocraniids will help resolve conflicts on the
   phylogenetic relationships of extant crocodylian lineages.
C1 Brochu, Christopher A.; Univ Iowa, Dept Earth & Environm Sci, Iowa City,
   IA, 52242, USA, USA.
EM chris-brochu@uiowa.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Spelling; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Evolution; Geological time periods
DE Boverisuchus magnifrons; Boverisuchus vorax; Crocodilus bolcensis;
   Crocodylia; Planocrania datangensis; Planocrania hengdongensis
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic relationships / Systematics]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Crocodylia,
   Eusuchia, Crocodylidae, Sebecosuchia
OR Crocodylia (Archosauria). 
   Planocraniidae - Li 1976 (Crocodylia): [Emendation, P. 524; Fossil]. 
   Boverisuchus magnifrons (Crocodylidae): [Fossil]. 
   Boverisuchus vorax - (Troxell 1925) (Crocodylidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Pristichampsus, p. 524; Fossil]. 
   Crocodilus bolcensis (Crocodylidae). 
   Planocrania datangensis (Crocodylidae): [Fossil]. 
   Planocrania hengdongensis (Crocodylidae): [Fossil]. 
   Pristichampsus - Gervais 1853 (Crocodylidae): [Status, P. 523; Fossil]. 
   Pristichampsus rollinati - (Gray 1831) (Crocodylidae): [Nomen dubium, P.
   523; Fossil]. 
   Pristichampsus vorax - (Troxell 1925) (Crocodylidae): [Referred to,
   Boverisuchus, p. 524; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002005907
DT Article
TI Late Cretaceous mosasauroids (Reptilia, Squamata) of the Big Bend region
   in Texas, USA.
AU Bell, Gorden L., Jr (gorden_bell@nps.gov) 
   Barnes, Kenneth R.
   Polcyn, Michael J.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 103
IS 3-4
PS 571-581
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Upper Cretaceous marine rocks of the Big Bend Region of trans-Pecos
   Texas preserve a number of marine-adapted mosasauroids. At least three
   unnamed taxa of basal mosasauroids are represented by remains from shaly
   limestones in the middle Turonian portion of the Boquillas Formation.
   These occur along with remains of larger derived mosasaurs referable to
   Russellosaurina and an undescribed tylosaurine. Derived mosasaurs from
   the middle to late Coniacian include the first report of Tylosaurus
   kansasensis outside of Kansas, T. nepaeolicus, Platecarpus planifrons,
   and Platecarpus aff. P. planifrons. Clidastes liodontus is found in the
   latest Coniacian or early Santonian part of the Pen Formation. An
   undescribed species of Ectenosaurus, Clidastes sp. and an indeterminate
   plioplatecarpine occurs in the middle Santonian to early Campanian
   interval of the Pen Formation. The mosasaur fauna from the Big Bend
   region is quite similar to that from the Smoky Hill Chalk of Kansas, a
   thousand kilometres to the north. We refine the position of the
   Cenomanian-Turonian boundary within the Ernst Member of the Boquillas
   Formation, based on ammonite faunas. We also corroborate previous
   interpretations describing the time-transgressive nature of the onset of
   deposition of the Pen Formation based on a west-to-east descending level
   of the Inoceramus (Cremnoceramus) undulatoplicatus FAD.
C1 Bell, Gorden L., Jr; POB 38, Baker, NV, 89311, USA, USA.
EM gorden_bell@nps.gov
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Mosasaurinae [Skeleton /  / Systematics] [Texas / Brewster /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Cretaceous / Cenomanian-Turonian boundary
   / ]. 
   Tylosaurus kansasensis [Texas /  / New record]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Mosasauridae
OR Mosasaurinae - Williston 1897 (Mosasauridae): [Fossil]. 
   Tylosaurus kansasensis - Everhart 2005 (Mosasauridae): [Fossil; New
   record].

TI FOUR NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS GEOCHARIS EHLERS, 1883 (COLEOPTERA:
   CARABIDAE) FROM PORTUGAL AND NOTES ON RELATED SPECIES.
AU Serrano, Artur R.M. (aserrano@fc.ul.pt) 
   Aguiar, Carlos A.S.
SO Elytron (Barcelona)
VL 25
PS 87-110
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new endogean carabid species of the genus Geocharis Ehlers 1883
   (Carabidae: Trechinae, Anillini) from Portugal, Geocharis noudari n.
   sp., Geocharis caseiroi n. sp., Geocharis margaridae n. sp. and
   Geocharis capelai n. sp., are described. We provide diagnostic
   characters of these species, in particular, the structure of male
   genitalia. Affinities with closely related species as well as ecological
   and distribution comments are also included. Keys for the identification
   of the males of the species found north and south of the Tejo River in
   Portugal are given. New data on the distribution of Geocharis moscatelus
   Serrano & Aguiar, 2001 are included.

DT Article
TI Campamento Vespucio, a new locality with Pleistocene mammals from Salta
   province, Argentina.
FT Campamento Vespucio, una nueva localidad con mamiferos pleistocenos en
   la provincia de Salta, Argentina.
AU Zacarias, G.G. (gzpaleozacarias@gmail.com) 
   Mino-Boilini, A.R.
   Zurita, A.E.
   Francia, A.
SO Estudios Geologicos (Madrid)
VL 68
IS 2
PS 277-285
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 6
AB In this contribution a new locality with Pleistocene fossil mammals is
   presented. The materials come from the Quebrada del Aguay, Campamento
   Vespucio, General Mosconi, Salta province, Argentina; they are
   tentatively assigned to the Urundel Fm. (late Pleistocene). The
   palaeofaunistic association includes six taxa: Xenarthra Glyptodontidae:
   Glyptodon sp. and Panochthidae: Neosclerocalyptus sp.; Tardigrada
   Megatheriinae: gen. et. sp. indet.; Proboscidea Gomphotheriidae:
   Stegomastodon sp; Notoungulata Toxodontidae: Toxodon sp. Perissodactyla
   Equidae: Equus (Amerhippus) sp. This set of Pleistocene mammals presents
   a wide latitudinal distribution in South America. Some of them (e. g.
   Neosclerocalyptus) are congruent with arid/semiarid, cold conditions and
   open environments. In this scenario, this contribution improves the
   knowledge that we have in northern part of Argentina, very scarce
   compared with respect to that of the Pampean region.
C1 Zacarias, G.G.; Univ Nacl Nordeste, Secretaria Gen Ciencia & Tecn,
   Corrientes, RA-3400, Argentina, Argentina.
EM gzpaleozacarias@gmail.com
