DT Article
TI Feeding ecology of the Brazilian Duck Amazonetta brasilensis (Birds:
   Anatidae) at the alluvial valley of the Parana river, Argentina.
FT Biologia alimentaria del Pato Cutiri Amazonetta brasilensis (Aves:
   Anatidae) en el valle de inundacion del rio Parana medio, Argentina.
AU Don, M.A. (pameolguin_06@hotmail.com) 
   Beltzer, A.H.
   Leon, E.
   Olguin, P.
   Urich, G.
SO FABICIB
VL 16
PS 142-156
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The sustainable use of the Anatidae populations should incorporate
   knowledge of their food requirements. The purpose of this work was to
   study the diet of Brazilian duck (Amazonetta brasiliensis). We analyzed
   24 individuals captured in the Carabajal Island and areas of human
   activity of San Javier province of Santa Fe. The spectrum was
   constituted for 17 taxonomic entities, (13 vegetal fraction and 4 animal
   fraction). The IRI values obtained were: Sporolus sp. = 3192, Oryza
   sativa=1205, Graminea n.i.1=529, Graminea n.i. 2=327, Polygonum sp.=315
   and Panicum elephantypes=63. The accumulated trophic diversity was 2, 3.
   The trophic niche breadth was 1.46 in spring, 2.32 in autumn, 4.33 in
   winter and 1.98 in. Feeding efficiency was 99% in spring, autumn and
   winter. Habitat use yielded a value of 0.6 for floating and rooted
   vegetation. These results confirm that A. brasiliensis is basically
   phytophagous species.
C1 Don, M.A.; Fac Humanidades & Ciencias, Santa Fe, RA-3000, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM pameolguin_06@hotmail.com

DT Article
TI On the genus Elma H. Adams, 1866 (Mollusca, Streptaxiidae).
AU Varga, Andras (avarga46@freemail.hu) 
SO Folia Historico Naturalia Musei Matraensis
VL 36
PS 5-13
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The predatory genus Elma is comprised of 9 species occurring in Taiwan,
   mainland China, and northern Vietnam. The present paper provides an
   assessment of the literature data relevant to these species and the
   description of a new species, Elma matskasii sp. nov., from northern
   Vietnam (type locality: Lao Cai Province, Co Xan).

   Hungary, Hungary.

   / South east Asia / distribution].

PT J
AN ZOOR15309053521
DT Article
TI Seven new species in the Chaetopteryx rugulosa species group: applying
   the phylogenetic species concept and the sexual selection theory
   (Trichoptera: Limnephilidae).
AU Olah, Janos (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Kovacs, Tibor
   Sivec, Ignac
   Szivak, Ildiko
   Urbanic, Gorazd
SO Folia Historico Naturalia Musei Matraensis
VL 36
PS 51-79
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Emerging perspectives of the phylogenetic species concepts and of the
   sexual selection theory were reviewed in order to apply these new
   findings to separate species in the obscured Chaetoptery rugulosa
   species group. Species is no longer considered as a stage in the lineage
   divergence. All the separately evolving metapopulation lineages
   represent species, from initial separation to extinction. Species is not
   a taxonomic rank, but a level of biological organisation. There are
   newly born and there are dying species. There are no subspecies as there
   are no "subindividuals" in the hierarchy of the biological organisation.
   Stable initial split criterion became a dominating practical guide to
   separate and describe species. That means that finding reliable
   separating morphological characters remains the central target in
   taxonomy and faces a challenge to taxonomist. Intense recent sexual
   selection processes both in the sexually antagonistic coevolution and in
   the cryptic female choice have produced stable diversity on the
   intromitten region of the edaeagus and on the female anal tube in the C.
   rugulosa species group. The male lateral subapical processes on the
   aedeagus and the female anal tube were applied to describe new species
   in this group: C. giuliensis Olah & Kovacs sp. n., C. idriensis Olah &
   Urbanic sp. n., C. kamnikensis Olah & Urbanic sp. n., C. papukensis Olah
   & Szivak sp. n., C. pohorjensis Olah & Urbanic sp. n., C. prealpensis
   Olah sp. n., C. zalaensis Olah sp. n. Based on male and female genital
   characters and applying the phylogenetic species concept we have raised
   subspecies rank to species rank with three new combinations:
   Chaetopteryx mecsekensis Nogradi, 1986 comb. nov., Chaetopteryx schmidi
   Botosaneanu, 1957 comb. nov., Chaetopteryx noricum Malicky, 1976 comb.
   nov., and have established three new species subgroups in the C.
   rugulosa species group: C. schmidi, C. rugulosa, C. irenae. In the C.
   rugulosa new species subgroup we have erected two new species clusters:
   C. noricum, C. rugulosa.
C1 Olah, Janos; Tarjan U 28, Debrecen, H-4032, Hungary, Hungary.
EM profolah@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0134-1243
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Status; Evolution; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   pohorjensis [Slovenia /  / New species].

   Chaetopteryx prealpensis [Austria /  / New species] [Bosnia-Herzegovina
   /  / ] [Croatia /  / ] [Hungary /  / ] [Slovenia /  / ]. 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa species group [Natural selection / Sexual
   selection theory / systematics] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic species
   concept / ]. 
   Chaetopteryx zalaensis [Hungary /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Trichoptera
OR Chaetopteryx giuliensis - Olah & Kovacs 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov,
   Italy, P. 73]. 
   Chaetopteryx idriensis - Olah & Urbanic 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov,
   Slovenia, P. 75]. 
   Chaetopteryx irenae species subgroup (Trichoptera): [New species group,
   P. 73]. 
   Chaetopteryx kamnikensis - Olah & Urbanic 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov,
   Slovenia, P. 66]. 
   Chaetopteryx mecsekensis - Nogardi 1986 (Trichoptera): [Raised from,
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa mecsekensis, p. 59, Cited by author as comb.
   nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx noricum - Malicky 1976 (Trichoptera): [Raised from,
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa noricum, p. 63, Cited by author as comb. nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx papukensis - Olah & Szivak 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov,
   Croatia, P. 60]. 
   Chaetopteryx pohorjensis - Olah & Urbanic 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov,
   Slovenia, P. 63]. 
   Chaetopteryx prealpensis - Olah 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Hungary, P.
   68]. 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa mecsekensis - Nogardi 1986 (Trichoptera): [Raised
   to, Chaetopteryx mecsekensis, p. 59, Cited by author as comb. nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa noricum - Malicky 1976 (Trichoptera): [Raised to,
   Chaetopteryx noricum, p. 63, Cited by author as comb. nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa schmidi - Botosaneanu 1957 (Trichoptera): [Raised
   to, Chaetopteryx schmidi, p. 59, Cited by author as comb. nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa species group (Trichoptera). 
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa species subgroup (Trichoptera): [New species
   group, P. 63]. 
   Chaetopteryx schmidi - Botosaneanu 1957 (Trichoptera): [Raised from,
   Chaetopteryx rugulosa schmidi, p. 59, Cited by author as comb. nov.]. 
   Chaetopteryx schmidi species subgroup (Trichoptera): [New species group,
   P. 59]. 
   Chaetopteryx zalaensis - Olah 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Hungary, P.
   71].

PT J
AN ZOOR15309053523
DT Article
TI New species and records of autumnal Trichoptera from Albania.
AU Olah, Janos (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Kovacs, Tibor
SO Folia Historico Naturalia Musei Matraensis
VL 36
PS 89-104
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Our knowledge on late flying caddisflies, especially at higher
   elevations and particularly in Albania is very limited. Here we have
   reported 32 species collected on higher elevations in Albania. Five new
   species are described: Annitella ostrovicensis sp. n., Allogamus tomor
   sp. n., Potamophylax hajlos sp. n., Potamophylax kesken sp. n.,
   Potamophylax tagas sp. n. The unknown female of Drusus arbanios Olah,
   2010 has been discovered and described. Females of Potamophylax
   haidukorum Malicky, 1999 and P. winneguthi (Klapalek, 1902) were
   collected in Bosnia & Herzegovina and Serbia, their genitalia redrawn,
   compared and differentiated. Potamophylax winneguthi new species group
   and Potamophylax tagas new species cluster are erected.
C1 Olah, Janos; Tarjan U 28, Debrecen, H-4032, Hungary, Hungary.
EM profolah@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0134-1243
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Allogamus tomor; Annitella ostrovicensis; Potamophylax hajlos;
   Potamophylax kesken; Potamophylax tagas [Albania /  / New species]. 
   Trichoptera [Albania /  / New record; systematics; autumnal taxa]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Trichoptera
OR Trichoptera (Insecta): [New record]. 
   Allogamus tomor - Olah 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Albania, P. 95]. 
   Annitella ostrovicensis (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Albania, P. 92]. 
   Drusus arbanios - Olah 2010 (Trichoptera): [First time described,
   Female, p. 91]. 
   Potamophylax hajlos - Olah 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Albania, P. 98].
   
   Potamophylax kesken - Olah 2012 (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Albania, P.
   100].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic list of Trichoptera described and recorded from New Guinea
   region.
AU Olah, Janos (profolah@gmail.com) 
SO Folia Historico Naturalia Musei Matraensis
VL 36
PS 105-122
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Caddisfly species described and recorded from the New Guinea region are
   surveyed and listed including their locus typicus and their months of
   collection. Altogether 352 species are listed: 338 are newly described
   species from the New Guinea region and only 14 species are described
   from other faunal regions and recorded on the New Guinea region. Based
   on the genital structure Cheumatopsyche lelamba Botosaneanu, 2008 was
   transferred to Abacaria lelamba, as new combination.

DT Article
TI Two new species of the family Aporcelaimidae (Nematoda: Dorylaimida).
AU Andrassy, Istvan (istandrassy@gmail.com) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 2
PS 189-199
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new aporcelaimid nematode species are described. Aporcella magna sp.
   n. from Chile differs from the other three species of the genus by its
   large body shape, on average 4.7 mm. Aporcelinus vulvatus sp. n. from
   Papua New Guinea is distinguished from the eleven known species of the
   genus by the long body (on average 2.6 mm), long odontostyle and
   protruded vulva.
C1 Andrassy, Istvan; Eotvos Lorand Univ, Dept Systemat Zool & Ecol, Pazmany
   Peter Setany 1-C, Budapest, H-1117, Hungary, Hungary.
EM istandrassy@gmail.com

   Neotropical region; South America; Australasia

   Aporcella magna [Chile /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002006465
DT Article
TI Redescriptions of some jumping spiders described by R. Lessert from
   Central Africa (Araneae: Salticidae).
AU Wesolowska, Wanda (tomwes@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 2
PS 201-221
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Redescriptions of five species described by Lessert from Kilimanjaro
   massif (1925 - Dendryphantes hewitti, Hasarius berlandi, Cosmophasis
   fagei, Langona rufa, Plexippus auberti) and four from Congo (1927 -
   Hyllus carbonarius, Hasarius biprocessiger, Simaetha castanea, Tusitala
   lutzi) are given. Two new genera, Hasarinella and Simaethulina are
   established. Langelurillus difficilis Wesolowska & Russell-Smith is
   synonymised with Langelurillus rufus. Six new combinations are proposed:
   Evarcha carbonaria ex Hyllus carbonarius, Icius fagei ex Cosmophasis
   fagei, Hasarinella berlandi ex Hasarius berlandi, Langelurilus rufus ex
   Langona rufa, Plexippoides biprocessiger ex Hasarius biprocessiger and
   Simaethulina castanea ex Simaetha castanea. Female of Tusitala lutzi and
   male of Plexippus auberti are described for the first time.
   Dendryphantes hewitti and Plexippus auberti are recorded for the first
   time in Kenya.
C1 Wesolowska, Wanda; Univ Wroclaw, Dept Biodivers & Evolutionary Taxon,
   Przybyszewskiego 63-77, Wroclaw, PL-51148, Poland, Poland.
EM tomwes@biol.uni.wroc.pl

   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scydmaeninae).

SO Genus (Wroclaw)

LA English

AB Six new species of Cephennodes (s. str.) are described from China: C.
   guizhouanus sp. nov. (Guizhou Prov.), C. capra sp. nov. (Guizhou), C.
   clypeicornis sp. nov. (Zhejiang Prov.), C. capricornis sp. nov.
   (Zhejiang and a border between Zhejiang and Anhui), C. zunyianus sp.
   nov. (Guizhou) and C. clypeatus sp. nov. (Zhejiang). Affinities of the
   newly described taxa to previously proposed informal species groups
   within Cephennodes are discussed, and important characters, including
   aedeagi, are illustrated.

PT J
AN ZOOR15002006471
DT Article
TI Descriptions of new species of the genus Chaloenus Westwood from Greater
   Sunda Islands (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Alticinae).
AU Takizawa, Haruo (cpirka12@gmail.com) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 2
PS 269-330
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Chaloenus WESTWOOD of the Greater Sunda Islands is revised.
   Twenty-three new species are described: Chaloenus (Chaloenus)
   barioensis, fulvoantennatus, fulvohirtus, jamadai, kinabaluensis,
   lanjakensis, lehi, liwaguensis, monticola, permai, todai, yukikoae n.
   spp. and Chaloenus (Priostomus) kuningus, maryatiae, maklarini, minutus,
   moyogensis, muaya, nitidicupreatus, nitidihirtus, psi, tibowensis n.
   spp. from Borneo, and C. (C.) sumatrensis n. sp. from Sumatra. Genus
   Priostomus Jacoby is resurrected from synonymy as a subgenus. This genus
   is most speciose in Borneo with 36 species among 42 known species, as
   stated by MEDEVEDEV (2004). Many of the species in the subgnenus
   Chaloenus are characterized by sexually dimorphic head shape. Sometimes
   male heads are polymorphic, with shapes correlated with their body-size.
   On the basis of plant associations in adults, the genus is tentatively
   divided into 5 groups. Subgenus Chaloenus is clearly associated with the
   family Araceae, while Priostomus has rather limited known host records
   in Araceae.
C1 Takizawa, Haruo; Kami 2-7-16, Hasuda, Saitama, 3490122, Japan, Japan.
EM cpirka12@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0867-1710
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Status; Key; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chaloenus [Indonesia / Greater Sunda Islands / Systematics]. 
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus); Chaloenus (Priostomus) [Indonesia / Greater Sunda
   Islands / Key to species]. 
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) barioensis; Chaloenus (Chaloenus) fulvoantennatus;
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) fulvohirtus; Chaloenus (Chaloenus) jamadai;
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) kinabaluensis; Chaloenus (Chaloenus) lanjakensis;
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) lehi; Chaloenus (Chaloenus) liwaguensis; Chaloenus
   (Chaloenus) monticola; Chaloenus (Chaloenus) permai; Chaloenus
   (Chaloenus) yukikoae; Chaloenus (Priostomus) kuningus; Chaloenus
   (Priostomus) maklarini; Chaloenus (Priostomus) maryatiae; Chaloenus
   (Priostomus) minutus; Chaloenus (Priostomus) moyogensis; Chaloenus
   (Priostomus) muaya; Chaloenus (Priostomus) nitidicupreatus; Chaloenus
   (Priostomus) nitidihirtus; Chaloenus (Priostomus) psi; Chaloenus
   (Priostomus) tibowensis [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) basalis [Malaysia / Malay Peninsula / New record].
   
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) latifrons [Malaysia / Borneo / New record]. 
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) sumatrensis [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Chaloenus (Chaloenus) todai [Plant hosts / Piptospatha havilandi / New

PT J
AN ZOOR15102006054
DT Article
TI Taxonomic and faunistic notes on Oriental and Palaearctic Galerucinae
   and Cryptocephalinae (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae).
AU Bezdek, Jan (bezdek@mendelu.cz) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 3
PS 375-418
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Following taxonomic changes are proposed in Oriental and Palaearctic
   Galerucinae and Cryptocephalinae: Cerophysa CHEVROLAT, 1836 (=
   Taumaceroides LOPATIN, 2009, syn. nov.); Podontia DALMAN, 1824 (=
   Paramerista LOPATIN, 2011); Mimastracella palpalis SAMODERZHENKOV, 1988
   (= Sastroides pallidifulvus KIMOTO, 1989, syn. nov.); Aplosonyx
   emeishanica (LOPATIN, 2005) (comb. nov.) (= A. metallicus CHEN, 2008,
   syn. nov.); Aplosonyx quadripunctata (JACOBY, 1895) (comb. nov.) (= A.
   amorphophallus MOHAMEDSAID, 2008, syn. nov.); Leptarthra jayarami
   (VAZIRANI, 1970) (comb. nov.); Notonicea metallica (Jacoby, 1891) (comb.
   nov.); Notonicea ornata (Baly, 1886) (comb. nov.); Charaea mimicum
   (MEDVEDEV, 1998) (comb. nov.); Ch. miyamotoi (KIMOTO, 1969) (comb. nov.)
   (= Calomicrus takizawai MEDVEDEV, 1998, syn. nov.); Ch. shirozui
   (KIMOTO, 1969) (comb. nov.); Ch. takagii (TAKIZAWA, 1988) (comb. nov.);
   Ch. yasudai (CHUJO, 1966) (comb. nov.); Ch. yunnanum (LOPATIN, 2009)
   (comb. nov.); Cneorella bicoloripennis LOPATIN, 2003 (= Laosixantha
   bicolor MEDVEDEV, 2009, syn. nov.); Luperogala clermonti (LABOISSIERE,
   1929) (comb. nov.) (= L. paradoxa MEDVEDEV & SAMODERZHENKOV, 1989, syn.
   nov.); Japonitata costata (ALLARD, 1889) (comb. nov.) (= J. tricostata
   CHEN & JIANG, 1981, syn. nov.); Vietoluperus alleculoides MEDVEDEV &
   DANG DAP, 1981 (= V. bengalicus MEDVEDEV, 2009, syn. nov.); Nymphius
   artificiosus (PEYERIMHOFF, 1931) (comb. nov.); Cerophysa sinica
   (LOPATIN, 2009) (comb. nov.); Podontia lutea (Olivier, 1790) (=
   Paramerista luteola LOPATIN, 2011, syn. nov.); Stenoluperus pulchellus
   (LOPATIN, 2005) (comb. nov.); Clytra subfasciata (LACORDAIRE, 1848) (=
   Oides neobengalensis RIZVI & KAMALUDDIN, 2011, syn. nov.); Miochira
   signaticollis (KOLLAR & REDTENBACHER, 1844) (comb. nov.) (= Clythra
   montana JACOBY, 1895, syn. nov., = Miochira nuristanica LOPATIN, 1966,
   syn. nov.); Smaragdina vaulogeri (PIC, 1894) (= Gynandrophthalma
   laeviceps ABEILLE DE PERRIN, 1895, syn. nov.); Adiscus nigromaculatus
   (KOLLAR & REDTENBACHER, 1844) (= A. angulatus MEDVEDEV &
   SPRECHER-UEBERSAX, 1997, syn. nov.). Calomicrus lopatini nom. nov. is
   suggested for C. minutissimus LOPATIN, 2009 from Yunnan (nec C.
   minutissimus KIMOTO, 1996 from Taiwan). Calomicrus setulosus var.
   tripolitanus (PIC, 1939) is elevated to species rank. Sastracella
   laosensis KIMOTO, 1989, Apophylia laotica BEZDEK, 2005, A. purpurea
   (ALLARD, 1889), A. securigera CHUJO, 1962 and Theopea bicolor KIMOTO,
   1989 are recorded for the first time from China (Yunnan), Gallerucida
   duporti (LABOISSIERE, 1931) from Laos and China (Yunnan), Apophylia
   assamensis (Jacoby, 1891), A. cyanipennis LABOISSIERE, 1927 and
   Leptarthra jayarami (VAZIRANI, 1970) from China (Xizang), Apophylia
   flavovirens (FAIRMAIRE, 1878) from China (Zhejiang), A. lebongana
   MAULIK, 1936 from China (Sichuan), Agetocera yunnana CHEN, 1964,
   Liroetis viridipennis KIMOTO, 1989 and Taumacera frontalis MOHAMEDSAID,
   2001 from Thailand, Charaea pseudominutum BEENEN & WARCHALOWSKI, 2010
   from Russia, Medythia quaterna (FAIRMAIRE, 1880) from Oman; Calomicrus
   apicalis DEMAISON, 1891 from Cyprus, C. nuristanicus MEDVEDEV, 1985 from
   Pakistan, C. tripolitanus from Algeria, Polyclada benti GAHAN, 1895,
   Paraclytra cervenkai BEZDEK & KANTNER, 2010 and Acolastus wittmeri
   (LOPATIN, 1979) from Oman, Isnus biseriatus (CHAPUIS, 1877) and
   Pachybrachis saudicus LOPATIN, 1979 from Yemen, Cryptocephalus
   convergens SASSI, 2001 from Austria. The generic placement of Cneorella
   bicoloripennis is discussed but remains unclear.
C1 Bezdek, Jan; Mendel Univ, Dept Zool, Zemedelska 1, Brno, 61300, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.
EM bezdek@mendelu.cz
RI Bezdek, Jan/J-3548-2018

DT Article
TI An unusual species of Cryptoscenea ENDERLEIN, 1914 from Western
   Australia (Neuroptera: Coniopterygidae).
AU Sziraki, Gyorgy (sziraki@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Winterton, Shaun
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 3
PS 419-424
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cryptoscenea maior sp. n., an unusually large-bodied species of the
   genus Cryptoscenea with distinct wing pattern is described from south -
   western Australia. The specimens of the new dusty lacewing species were
   observed as predators of the scale insect Eucalyptococcus gisleni
   (OSSIANNILSSON, 1954) (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae).

DT Article
TI Salticidae from the Himalayas. The genus Dexippus THORELL, 1891
   (Araneae: Salticidae).
AU Jastrzebski, Piotr (pjast@uph.edu.pl) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 3
PS 441-448
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species of the jumping spider genus Dexippus THORELL, 1891: D.
   krystynae sp. n. is described, diagnosed and illustrated from Nepal. D.
   topali PROSZYNSKI, 1992 is reported for the first time from the
   Himalayas. A check-list of species of Dexippus is given.
C1 Jastrzebski, Piotr; Uniwersytet Przyrodniczo Humanistyczny, Katedra
   Zool, Prusa 12, Siedlce, PL-08110, Poland, Poland.

   zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Dexippus krystynae [Nepal /  / New species]. 
   Dexippus topali [Asia / Himalayas / New record; systematics].

   Dexippus krystynae (Araneae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 443]. 
   Dexippus topali - Proszynski 1992 (Araneae): [New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of Menemerus from Pakistan (Araneae: Salticidae).
AU Wesolowska, Wanda (tomwes@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
   Freudenschuss, Mario
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 3
PS 449-453
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description of Menemerus nigli ([male][upsilon]), a new species from
   western Pakistan is given. M. raji DYAL, 1935 is recognized as nomen
   dubium.

DT Article
TI Oribatid mites of the superfamily Galumnoidea from Zambia, with
   description of a new species of the genus Galumna (Acari: Oribatida).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 3
PS 455-460
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An annotated checklist of registered galumnoid mites from Zambia is
   presented. Five species, four genera and two families have been found.
   All taxa (except family Galumnidae) represent the first records from
   Zambia. A new species of the genus Galumna, Galumna wojciechniedbalai
   sp. nov., is described. In having the combination of straight lamellar
   lines, directed to insertion of rostral setae, and sensilli, having a
   dilated head, a new species resembles Galumna aba MAHUNKA, G. araujoi
   PEREZ-INIGO & BAGGIO and G. gibbula GRANDJEAN. However, it is clearly
   different from the listed species in several characters (body size,
   lengths of lamellar setae, presence or absence of interlamellar setae
   and dorsosejugal furrow, morphology of sensilli and porose areas).
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanit, Nizhniy Novgorod Referral
   Ctr, Gagarin 97, Nizhniy Novgorod, 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru

TI Ants of Greece - checklist, comments and new faunistic data
   (Hymenoptera: Formicidae).
AU Borowiec, Lech (cassidae@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
   Salata, Sebastian
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 4
PS 461-563
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A list of 291 ant species recorded from Greece are given but
   approximately 15% of taxa need confirmation due to recent studies on
   European ants and reinterpretation of several taxa. The following 17
   species are recorded from Greece for the first time: Camponotus sannini
   TOHME & TOHME, Crematogaster jehovae FOREL, Formica bruni KUTTER, Lasius
   jensi SEIFERT, Lasius nitidigaster SEIFERT, Lepisiota dolabellae
   (FOREL), Myrmica lonae FINZI, Myrmica tulinae ELMES, RADCHENKO & AKTAC,
   Temnothorax flavicornis (EMERY), Temnothorax sordidulus (MULLER),
   Temnothorax turcicus (SANTSCHI), Tetramorium hungaricum ROSZLER, and
   five species not attributed to a named species: Camponotus cf. lateralis
   sp. 1, Camponotus cf. lateralis sp. 2, Lepisiota cf. melas sp. 1,
   Lepisiota cf. syriaca sp. 1, and Tetramorium cf. caespitum sp. 1.
   Camponotus candiotes is recorded as new species to Croatia. New
   faunistic data for 132 other species are given.

DT Article
TI A new species of Orchesia LATREILLE, 1807 from Baltic amber (Coleoptera:
   Melandryidae).
AU Alekseev, Vitaly I. (alekseew0802@yahoo.com) 
   Bukejs, Andris
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 4
PS 571-576
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new fossil false darkling beetle, Orchesia (Orchestera) turkini sp.
   nov. from Baltic amber (Eocene) of the Kaliningrad region of Russia is
   described and compared with the closely related fossil species O.
   (Orchestera) rasnitzyni NIKITSKY, 2011. The newly described species
   differs morphologically from the latter in the structure of its
   maxillary palpi, proportions of antennomeres, and possessing an elytral
   surface without rugosity in the basal third.

DT Article
TI Oribatid mites from Bu Gia Map National Park (Southern Vietnam), with
   description of a new species of Dolicheremaeus (Tetracondylidae) (Acari:
   Oribatida).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, Alexander E.
   Wu, Donghui
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 23
IS 4
PS 591-601
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An annotated checklist of oribatid mite taxa of Bu Gia Map National Park
   (Southern Vietnam) with distributions is provided. We have registered 62
   species, 46 genera, 31 families of which five species, six genera, two
   families were found for the first time from Vietnam. A new species of
   the genus Dolicheremaeus, D. bugiamapensis sp. nov., is described. This
   new species can be included in the Dolicheremaeus species group with
   developed prodorsal and notogastral condyles, localization of adanal
   setae ad3 in preanal position, medium length of notogastral setae and
   clavate sensilli. However, it differs from all species of this group by
   a combination of the body size, length of adanal and aggenital setae;
   size and morphology of condyles, morphology notogastral setae,
   localization of lyrifissures iad, and the morphology of leg setae u.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanit Inspect, Nizhniy Novgorod
   Referral Ctr, Gagarin 97, Nizhniy Novgorod, 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0867-1710

   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   Oribatida [Checklists / Annotated checklist / New record; Binh Phuoc;
   Phuoc Long; Bu Gia Map National Park] [Vietnam / Binh Phuoc, Phuoc Long,
   Bu Gia Map National Park / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

TI Cebrio yolandae nov. sp. from northern Spain (Coleoptera: Elateridae:
   Cebrioninae: Cebrionini).
FT Cebrio yolandae nov. sp. del norte de Espana (Coleoptera: Elateridae:
   Elaterinae: Cebrionini).
AU Bahillo de la Puebla, P.
   Lopez-Colon, J.I.
SO Heteropterus Revista de Entomologia
VL 12
IS 2
PS 201-208
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cebrio yolandae nov. sp. is described from Huesca, Navarra and Zaragoza
   (northern Spain). Differences with the nearest Iberian species are
   discussed. Cebrio yolandae nov. sp. looks similar to C. gigas
   (Fabricius, 1787) but both species can be easily distinguished by the
   shape of antennae, the coloration of head and thorax, the cephalic and
   thoracic pubescence as well as the male genitalia.

AN ZOOR15101001555
DT Article
TI Endohelminth parasites of seven goodein species (Cyprinodontiformes:
   Goodeidae) from Lake Zacapu, Michoacan, Central Mexico Plateau.
AU Martinez-Aquino, Andres (ppdleon@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Perez-Rodriguez, Rodolfo
   Hernandez-Mena, David I.
   Garrido-Olvera, Lorena
   Aguilar-Aguilar, Rogelio
   Perez-Ponce de Leon, Gerardo
SO Hidrobiologica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 89-93
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A total of 11 parasitic endohelminth taxa were found in 7 freshwater
   fish species of the subfamily Goodeinae in Zacapu Lake, Michoacan,
   Mexico. Six were adults (Margotrema cf. bravoae, Phyllodistomum sp.,
   Saccocoelioides sogandaresi, Rhabdochona lichtenfelsi, Bothriocephalus
   acheilognathi and Caryophillidae gen. sp.), while the remaining 5 taxa
   (Clinostomum complanatum, Posthodiplostomum minimum, Tylodelphis sp.,
   Eustrongylides sp. and Polymorphus brevis) were larvae. The taxa S.
   sogandaresi, Tylodelphis sp., and R. lichtenfelsi reached the highest
   levels of prevalence and mean abundance among all hosts, while the
   cestodes B. acheilognathi and Caryophillidae gen. sp. showed the lowest
   values. This study contributes with the inventory of the freshwater fish
   helminth fauna in Central Mexico Plateau, and particularly with the
   previous work that has been done with Goodeinae, a subfamily of
   freshwater fishes endemic to that part of the country.
C1 Martinez-Aquino, Andres; UNAM, Inst Biol, Apartado Postal 70-153, Mexico
   City, DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.

DT Article
TI Confirmation of the presence of the Snail Kite (Rostrhamus sociabilis)
   in Jalisco, Mexico.
FT Confirmacion de la presencia del gavilan caracolero (Rostrhamus
   sociabilis) en Jalisco, Mexico.
AU Pineda-Lopez, Ruben (rpineda62@hotmail.com) 
   Morales, Nadia Febvre
   Martinez, Mahinda
SO Huitzil
VL 13
IS 1
PS 39-42
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.huitzil.net/nuevo_sitio/ingles.html
AW http://www.huitzil.net/nuevo_sitio/ingles.html
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report the presence of the Snail Kite (Rostrhamus sociabilis) in the
   state of Jalisco after observing an individual in the mouth of the
   Marabasco river. In Mexico, this species is restricted to the southeast,
   the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, portions of Veracruz, and occasionally in
   the coast of Chiapas, Guerrero and Colima. Its presence in Colima and
   Jalisco has been reported by birders. The presence of this species in
   Colima since 1998 is explained by the introduction of the snail Pomacea
   sp. and the seminomadic nature of the species. The presence of R.
   sociabilis in Jalisco and Colima is important as it extends the range of
   a species included within the category of special protection by Mexican
   laws.
C1 Pineda-Lopez, Ruben; Facultad de Ciencias Naturales, Universidad
   Autonoma de Queretaro, Av. de las Ciencias s/n, Juriquilla, Queretaro,
   76230, Mexico, Mexico.
EM rpineda62@hotmail.com

   Behavioral Sciences

   Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America

   extension response] [Introduction /  / ] [Mexico / Jalisco / ]. 
   Rostrhamus sociabilis [Molluscan prey / Pomacea / new record] [Food
   availability /  / ] [Migration / Nomadism / ] [Mexico / Jalisco / ].

DT Article
TI A contribution to the study of China Dorcadionini (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae). Part 1.
AU Danilevsky, Mikhail L. (danilevskyml@rambler.ru) 
   Lin, Mei-Ying
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
SU Supplement 4
PS 1-19
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species rank E. rubrosuturale (Breuning, 1943) is restored. Several
   local populations of E. chinganicum (Suvorov, 1909) and E. rubrosuturale
   are partly described. Most of localities were never published before, so
   new distributional records are proposed for several taxa. Specimens from
   about all new localities are figured. Two names are downgraded to
   subspecies rank: E. chinganicum mandschukuoense (Breuning, 1944), stat.
   nov. and E. chinganicum darigangense Heyrovsky, 1967, stat. nov. The
   taxon described as E. chinganicum kerulenum Danilevsky, 2007 is regarded
   as E. rubrosuturale kerulenum Danilevsky, 2007.
C1 Danilevsky, Mikhail L.; A.N. Severtzov Institute of Ecology and
   Evolution, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow
   119071, Russia, Russia.
EM danilevskyml@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 2226-0773

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Dorcadionini [China /  / Distribution; new record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Dorcadionini (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion) chinganicum daringangense - Heyrovsky 1967
   (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded from, Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion)
   daringangense, p. 9].

   mandschukuoense, p. 9].

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of the genus Paraleprodera from Xizang,
   China (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae, Monochamini).
AU Bi, Wenxuan (insectb@163.com) 
   Lin, Meiying
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
SU Supplement 12
PS 4-11
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Paraleprodera mesophthalma sp. n. is described from
   southeast Xizang, China. It can be distinguished from other known
   species by the remarkable eyelike marking on the middle of elytra. It is
   the ninth species of this genus from China. Illustrations of the habitus
   and genitalia including everted endophallus are provided.
C1 Bi, Wenxuan; Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and Evolution,
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beichen West Road,
   Chaoyang Dist., Beijing, 100101, China, China.
EM insectb@163.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

TI A new species of Phytoecia Dejean, 1835 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae) from

AB Phytoecia (s. str.) napolovi sp. n. is described from Israel. The new
   species is similar to Ph. (s. str.) shokhini Kasatl in, 2010, but
   differs primarily in the absence of male coxal spines.

DT Article
TI New Chinese Purpuricenus Dejean, 1821 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae) close
   to P. temminckii Guerin-Meneville, 1844 group of species.
AU Danilevsky, Mikhail L. (danilevsky@cerambycidae.net) 
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
SU Supplement 1
PS 8-28
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Purpericenus katerinae sp. n. close to P. globiger Fairmaire, 1888 is
   described from Shanxi. P. globiger is recorded from Liaoning province.
   P. g. anrbrusi, ssp. n., P. sideriger richardi ssp. n. and P.
   tenrrninckii oliveri are described from Gansu. Lectotype of P. globiger
   from near Beijing is designated. The general acceptance of the type
   locality of P. temminckii (Shanghai) was wrong; the species was
   described from Japan. P. t. sinensis A. White, 1853, new rank is
   accepted as a continental subspecies.

   Evolution, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect 33, Moscow
   119071, Russia, Russia.

AN ZOOR14808058413
DT Article
TI A contribution to the study of China Dorcadionini (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae). Part 2.
AU Danilevsky, Mikhail L. (danilevskyml@rambler.ru) 
   Lin, Mei-Ying
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
SU Supplement 4
PS 20-35
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Summary. Eodorcadion (s. str.) virgatum taihangense, ssp. nov. is
   described from Shanxi. E. (s. str.) minicarinatum, sp. nov. similar to
   E. (s. str.) multicarinatum (Breun.) is described from Anhui. E. (O.)
   potaninellum, sp. nov. close to E. (O.) potanini (Suv.) and E. (O.)
   pseudornatum sp. nov. similar to E. ornatum (Fald.) are described from
   Shaanxi. E. (Humerodorcadion) humerale xinganum Chiang & Wang, 2003,
   nom. rest. is redescribed and accepted as a widely distributed in NE
   China subspecies represented by numerous individual forms. E. (H.) h.
   qudrilineatum (Breit, 1915), nom. rest. is accepted as southernmost
   subspecies of E. humerale (Gebl.) known from Hebei and south-east of
   Inner Mongolia. A first description of a female of E. (O.) kaznakovi
   (Suvorov, 1912) is proposed. New specimens of E. (O.) heros (Jak.) - two
   males and a female - are described. Several new geographical data of
   Chinese Dorcadioni are recorded.
C1 Danilevsky, Mikhail L.; A.N. Severtzov Institute of Ecology and
   Evolution, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow
   119071, Russia, Russia.
EM danilevskyml@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 2226-0773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Status; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Dorcadionini [China /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion) minicarinatum [Anhui /  / New species]
   [Jiangxi /  / ]. 
   Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion) virgatum taihangense [Shanxi /  / New
   subspecies]. 
   Eodorcadion (Ornatodorcadion) potaninellum; Eodorcadion
   (Ornatodorcadion) pseudornatum [Shaanxi /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Dorcadionini (Cerambycidae). 
   Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion) minicarinatum (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Anhui,
   P. 22]. 
   Eodorcadion (Eodorcadion) virgatum taihangense (Cerambycidae): [Subsp
   nov, Shanxi, P. 21]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale - (Gebler 1823) (Cerambycidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) xinganum Chiang &
   Wang 2003, p. 25]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale quadrilineatum - (Breit 1915)
   (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded from, Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion)
   quadrilineatum, p. 27]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale trabeatum - Jak. (Cerambycidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) quadrilineatum
   (Breit 1915), p. 27]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale xinganum - Chiang & Wang 2003
   (Cerambycidae): [Redescription, P. 25; Downgraded from, Eodorcadion
   (Humerodorcadion) xinganum, p. 25]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) quadrilineatum - (Breit 1915)
   (Cerambycidae): [Removal from synonymy, With Eodorcadion
   (Humerodorcadion) humerale trabeatum Jak., p. 27; Downgraded to,
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale quadrilineatum, p. 27]. 
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) xinganum - Chiang & Wang 2003
   (Cerambycidae): [Removal from synonymy, With Eodorcadion
   (Humerodorcadion) humerale (Gebler 1823), p. 25; Downgraded to,
   Eodorcadion (Humerodorcadion) humerale xinganum, p. 25].

   (Cerambycidae): [First time described, Female, p. 29].

   Shaanxi, P. 23].

   Shaanxi, P. 24].

PT J
AN ZOOR14809065219
DT Article
TI Additions and corrections to the new Catalogue of Palaearctic
   Cerambycidae (Coleoptera) edited by I. Loebl and A. Smetana, 2010. Part.
   V.
AU Danilevsky, M.L. (danilevskym1@rambler.ru) 
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
IS 3
PS 695-741
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB More than hundred misprints, wrong combinations, wrong geographical
   records, wrong references, wrong status of certain names, wrong
   synonyms, wrong authorships and dates of certain names, wrong original
   combinations, wrong spellings of several names and so on are fixed.
   Sometimes unavailable names were published as available. Missing names,
   geographical data and references are added. Leiopus nebulosus insulanus
   Slama, 1985, stat. nov. is proposed. Prinobius myardi slamorum nom. nov.
   is proposed as replacement name for Prinobius myardi scutellaris
   (Germar, 1817) (HN) described as Prionus (not Prionus scutellaris
   Olivier, 1795, now in Mallaspis Audinet-Serville, 1832). Cortodera
   flavimana rufipes Kraatz, 1876 described from "Smyrna" is proposed as a
   valid name for the subspecies from South-Western Anatolia. The type
   locality of Cortodera flavimana (Waltl, 1838) is accepted as Stambul
   environs. Xylosteus caucasicola Plavilstshikov, 1936 and X. kadleci
   Miroshnikov, 2000 are accepted as separate species. Clytus robertae
   Mineau & Teocchi, 1986 from France is proposed to be regarded as
   available and valid. Stromatium auratum (Boeber, 1793) is supposed to be
   valid fort the species known now as Stromatium unicolor (Olivier, 1795).
   New synonyms: Acanthocinus aedilis (Linnaeus, 1758) = Acanthocinus
   validus Matsushita, 1936, syn. nov.; Acanthocinus griseus (Fabricius,
   1792) = Astynomus alpinus L. Redtenbacher, 1848, syn. nov. are proposed
   on the base of original descriptions. New synonyms are proposed on the
   base of available materials: Phytoecia geniculata orientalis Kraatz,
   1871a = Phytoecia icterica donatellae Rapuzzi & Sama, 2010, syn. nov.
   Mesosa hirsuta continentalis Hayashi, 1964 is accepted as a valid name.
   Two names are downgrated to subspecies rank: Exocentrus fasciolatus
   conjugatofasciatus Tsherepanov, 1973, new rank and E. f. tsushimanus
   Hayashi, 1968, new rank.
C1 Danilevsky, M.L.; A. N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution,
   Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect 33, Moscow 119071,
   Russia, Russia.
EM danilevskym1@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 2226-0773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Status;
   Documentation; Publications
DE Cerambycidae [Catalogues / New Catalogue of Palaearctic Cerambycidae /
   Additions & corrections]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Cerambycidae (Chrysomeloidea). 
   Acanthocinus aedilis - (Linnaeus 1758) (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Acanthocinus validus Matsushita 1936, p. 719]. 
   Acanthocinus griseus - (Fabricius 1792) (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Astynomus alpinus Redtenbacher 1848, p. 719]. 
   Clytus robertae - Mineau & Teocchi 1986 (Cerambycidae): [Available name,
   P. 708; Valid name, P. 708]. 
   Cortodera flavimana rufipes - Kraatz 1876 (Cerambycidae): [Valid name,
   P. 703]. 
   Exocentrus conjugatofasciatus - Tsherepanov 1973 (Cerambycidae):
   [Downgraded to, Exocentrus fasciolatus conjugatofasciatus, p. 734]. 
   Exocentrus fasciolatus conjugatofasciatus - Tsherepanov 1973
   (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded from, Exocentrus conjugatofasciatus, p.
   734]. 
   Exocentrus fasciolatus tsushimanus - Hayashi 1968 (Cerambycidae):
   [Downgraded from, Exocentrus tsushimanus, p. 734]. 
   Exocentrus tsushimanus - Hayashi 1968 (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded to,
   Exocentrus fasciolatus tsushimanus, p. 734]. 
   Leiopus insularis - Slama 1985 (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded to, Leiopus
   nebulosus insularis, p. 696]. 
   Leiopus nebulosus insularis - Slama 1985 (Cerambycidae): [Downgraded
   from, Leiopus insularis, p. 696]. 
   Mesosa hirsuta continentalis - Hayashi 1964 (Cerambycidae): [Valid name,
   P. 732]. 
   Phytoecia geniculata orientalis - Kraatz 1871 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Phytoecia icterica donatellae Rapuzzi & Sama 2010, p. 732]. 
   Prinobius myardi scutellaris - (Germar 1817) (Cerambycidae):
   [Preoccupied name replaced by, Prinobius myardi slamorum, p. 698]. 
   Prinobius myardi slamorum (Cerambycidae): [Nom nov, For Prinobius myardi
   scutellaris (Germar 1817), p. 698]. 
   Stromatium auratum - (Boeber 1793) (Cerambycidae): [Valid name, P. 712].
   
   Xylosteus caucasicola - Plavilstshikov 1936 (Cerambycidae): [Status, P.
   695]. 
   Xylosteus kadleci - Miroshnikov 2000 (Cerambycidae): [Status, P. 695].

PT J
AN ZOOR15011063818
DT Article
TI Additions and corrections to the new Catalogue of Palaearctic
   Cerambycidae (Coleoptera) edited by I. Loebl and A. Smetana, 2010. Part.
   VI.
AU Danilevsky, M.L. (danilevsky@cerambycidae.net) 
SO Humanity Space International Almanac
VL 1
IS 4
PS 900-939
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Misprints, wrong combinations, wrong geographical records, wrong
   references, wrong status of certain names, wrong synonyms, wrong
   authorships and dates of certain names, wrong original combinations,
   wrong spellings of several names and so on are fixed. Sometimes
   unavailable names were published as available. Missing names,
   geographical data and references are added. Distenia japonica Bates,
   1873 is accepted as an island species. Lobarthron balassogloi
   brevispinum (Jakovlev, 1885a) is accepted as a north subspecies
   distributed in Uzbekistan, Kirgizia and Kazakhstan. Dinoptera concolor
   Heyden & Faust, 1888 is accepted as a species from Black See Coast of
   Abkhazia and Turkey. Anoplodera rufipes astrabadensis Pic, 1900s is
   accepted for North Iran and Talysh area of Azerbaijan; A. r. ventralis
   Heyden, 1886a is accepted for Russia, Kazakhstan, Caucasus and Turkey.
   A. r. krueperi (Ganglbauer, 1882) is supposed to be valid for Greece.
   Stictoleptura rufa excelsa (A. Costa, 1863) is accepted for Italy. S. r.
   nigropicta (Fairmaire, 1866b) [long dash] for West Anatolia; S. r.
   attaliensis (K. Daniel & J. Daniel, 1891) [long dash] for South Turkey;
   S. r. dimidiata (K. Daniel & J. Daniel, 1891) [long dash] for most part
   of Anatolia and Iraq; S. r. rubromarginata (Plavilstshikov, 1932) [long
   dash] for Iran; S. r. realis ssp. n. is described from Caucasus with
   Transcaucasia and neighbor regions of Turkey. Japanocorus gen. nov.
   (type species Toxotus caeruleipennis Bates, 1873) is described.
   Stenocorus validicornis mediocris ssp. n. is described from Uzbekistan,
   Kirgizia and Kazakhstan and S. v. karatauensis ssp. n. is described from
   South Kazakhstan. Cortodera differens magdae ssp. n. is described from
   Bulgaria. Alosterna tabacicolor tenebris ssp. n. from Ussuri Land of
   Russia, Korea and NE China and A. t. sachalinensis ssp. n. from North
   Sakhalin are described. S. scutellata miroshnikovi, ssp. n. is described
   from Talysh area of Azerbaijan and North Iran. Semiangusta ambrusi sp.
   n. is described from Esfahan (Iran). Tetrops gilvipes niger Kraatz, 1859
   is accepted for Italy and France, as well as T. praeustus angorensis
   Pic, 1918d and T. p. anatolicus Ozdikmen & Turgut, 2008e for Turkey. T.
   starkii aquilus ssp. n. is described from Russian north-west Caucasus.
   Drymochares cavazzutii Sama & Rapuzzi, 1993 is accepted as a species
   from Georgia, Armenia and Turkey with a western subspecies Drymochares
   cavazzutii ivani Sama & Rapuzzi, 1993. New synyms are proposed:
   Grammoptera ingrica var. diversipes Pic, 1929b = Alosterna perpera
   Danilevsky, 1988c, syn. nov., so the valid name of the species is:
   Alosterna diversipes (Pic, 1929b).
C1 Danilevsky, M.L.; A. N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution,
   Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect 33, Moscow 119071,
   Russia, Russia.
EM danilevsky@cerambycidae.net
SC Zoology
SN 2226-0773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Documentation; Publications;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe

   / New subspecies]. 
   Alosterna tabacicolor tenebris [Russia /  / New subspecies] [China /  /

   [Azerbaijan /  / ]. 
   Stictoleptura scutellata miroshnikovi [Azerbaijan /  / New subspecies]
   [Iran /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Cerambycidae (Chrysomeloidea). 
   Alosterna diversipes - (Pic 1929) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   with status upgrading from Grammoptera ingrica, p. 904]. 
   Alosterna tabacicolor sachalinensis (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Russia,
   P. 904]. 
   Alosterna tabacicolor tenebris (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Russia, P.
   904]. 
   Cortodera differens magdae (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Bulgaria, P.
   916]. 
   Grammoptera ingrica var. diversipes - Pic 1929 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Alosterna perpera Danilevsky 1988, p. 904; Referred with status
   upgrading to, Alosterna, p. 904]. 
   Japanocorus (Cerambycidae): [Gen nov, Of family Cerambycidae, Type
   species Toxotus caeruleipennis Bates 1873, p. 919]. 
   Japanocorus caeruleipennis - (Bates 1873) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Toxotus, p. 920]. 
   Semiangusta ambrusi (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 934]. 
   Stenocorus validicornis karatauensis (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov,
   Kazakhstan, P. 920]. 
   Stenocorus validicornis mediocris (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov,
   Uzbekistan, P. 920]. 
   Stictoleptura rufa realis (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Armenia, P. 912]. 
   Stictoleptura scutellata miroshnikovi (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov,
   Azerbaijan, P. 916]. 
   Tetrops starkii aquilus (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Russia, P. 937]. 
   Toxotus caeruleipennis - Bates 1873 (Cerambycidae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Japanocorus, p. 919].

TI Agapanthia (Epoptes) paki sp. n. from central Afghanistan (Coleoptera:

AB In this paper I describe a new species of Agapanthia Audinet-Serville,
   1835 from Central Afghanistan (Ghor province). The new species is
   related with A. (Epopetes) detrita Kraatz, 1882.

TI New Baetidae (Insecta: Ephemeroptera) Records from Venezuela and Nymph
   Description of an Unnamed Fallceon Species.
AU Cruz, Paulo Vilela (pvilelacruz@gmail.com) 
   Boldrini, Rafael
   Quinto, Carlos F.
   Frontado, Hortencia
SO International Journal of Zoology
SU Article ID 837092
PS 1-6
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Ephemeroptera fauna in Venezuela is poorly known, as is also the
   case in others areas in South America. Recently, two studies increased
   from 33 to 50 the number of species recorded in Venezuela. The objective
   of the present study is to report for the first time in Venezuela the
   following species: Baetodes levis; Camelobaetidius edmundsi; Fallceon
   sp.; Mayobaetis ellenae. The nymph of Fallceon sp. is described, but is
   not named because adults were not reared to allow species
   identification; however, description of this nymph indicates the
   presence of this genus in South America.

DT Article
TI On the Taxonomy of Acanthoscurria Ausserer from Southeastern Brazil with
   Data on the Natural History of A. gomesiana Mello-Leitao (Araneae,
   Mygalomorphae, Theraphosidae).
AU Gonzalez-Filho, Hector M.O.
   Lucas, Sylvia M. (sylvialucas@butantan.gov.br) 
   Paula, Felipe dos S.
   Indicatti, Rafael P.
   Brescovit, Antonio D.
SO International Journal of Zoology
SU Article ID 721793
PS 1-11
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of type material and specimens of A. gomesiana of several
   Brazilian spider collections offered us the possibility to redescribe
   this species and consider synonyms of the first one of the following: A.
   violacea, A. pugnax, and A. aurita. Acanthoscurria cunhae and A.
   melanotheria are considered Species inquirendae, the types were not
   located, and the descriptions are not enough for identification of
   similar ones. We considered as valid only two species from the southeast
   of Brazil: A. paulensis and A. gomesiana. The distribution range of A.
   gomesiana is enhanced in the state of Minas Gerais, Brazil. Some data on
   natural history and phenology are presented.

   Brazil 1500, Sao Paulo, BR-05503900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Records and Descriptions of Epitoniidae (Orthogastropoda: Epitonioidea)
   from the Deep Sea off Northeastern Brazil and a Checklist of Epitonium
   and Opalia from the Atlantic Coast of South America.
AU Lima, Silvio F.B. (sfblima@yahoo.com.br) 
   Christoffersen, Martin L.
   Barros, Jose C.N.
   Folly, Manuella
SO International Journal of Zoology
SU Article ID 394381
PS 1-12
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A total of six genera and 10 species of marine gastropods belonging to
   the family Epitoniidae were collected from dredges of the continental
   slope off Brazil during the development of the REVIZEE (Live Resources
   of the Economic Exclusive Zone) Program. These species, referable to the
   genera Alora, Amaea, Cycloscala, Epitonium, Gregorioiscala, and Opalia,
   are reported from bathyal depths off northeastern Brazil. Alora sp.,
   Gregorioiscala pimentai n. sp., and Opalia revizee n. sp. are species
   heretofore unknown to science. A list of the species of Epitonium and
   Opalia from the Atlantic coast of South America is presented based
   primarily on data from the literature. In addition, an overview of the
   biodiversity and distribution of the genera studied is presented for the
   Atlantic Ocean.
C1 Lima, Silvio F.B.; Univ Fed Paraiba UFPB, Dept Sistemat & Ecol, Joao
   Pessoa, Paraiba, BR-58059900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI The Lizard Fauna of Kurdistan Province, Western Iran.
AU Bahmani, Z. (zahedbahmany@gmail.com) 
   Karamiani, R.
   Gharzi, A.
SO Iranian Journal of Animal Biosystematics
VL 8
IS 1
PS 27-37
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Kurdistan Province in the western Iran possesses varied climatic and
   geographical conditions that led to rich biodiversity. An investigation
   on the status of lizards in this Province was carried out from June 2010
   to September 2011. A total of 73 specimens were collected and
   identified. The collected specimens represented four families, 10
   genera, and 14 species and subspecies, including Agamidae: Laudakia
   nupta nupta, Laudakia caucasia and Trapelus lessonae, Gekkonidae:
   Cyrtopodion scabrum, Asaccus kurdistanensis, Lacertidae: Eremias
   montanus, Eremias sp. (1) and Eremias sp. (2) (unknown taxa which may be
   related to E. persica complex), Apathya cappadocica urmiana, A. c.
   muhtari, Lacerta media media and Ophisops elegans, Scinicidae: Eumeces
   schneideri princeps and Trachylepis aurata transcaucasica. With respect
   to the data which was reported by Rastegar-Pouyani et al. (2008) and
   Anderson (1999) Eremias sp. (1) and Eremias sp. (2) may belong to two
   new taxa, Apathya cappadocica muhtari is a new record from Iran, and
   also Eremias montanus is a new record from Kurdistan Province. The
   Lacertidae with six species, showed the highest diversity among the
   families represented here.
C1 Bahmani, Z.; Lorestan Univ, Fac Sci, Khoramabad, Iran, Iran.
EM zahedbahmany@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1735-434X
BD Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Eremias montanus [Iran / Kurdistan Province / New record]. 
   Sauria [Iran / Kurdistan Province / Faunal list; new record]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Lacertidae
OR Sauria (Squamata): [New record]. 
   Apathya cappadocica muhtari (Lacertidae): [New record]. 
   Eremias montanus (Lacertidae): [New record].

TI A new Phyllolabis from Israel with reduced wings and halteres (Diptera:
   Limoniidae).
AU Stary, Jaroslav (stary@prfnw.upol.cz) 
   Wizen, Gil
   Freidberg, Amnon
SO Israel Journal of Entomology
VL 41-42
PS 107-114
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Phyllolabis parvihalterata n. sp., a new limoniid species from Israel,
   is described based on numerous male and female specimens collected along
   winter pools in the Upper Galilee. This species is compared to P.
   golanensis Stary and Freidberg, from which it differs primarily by the
   greatly reduced wings and halteres. These characters also distinguish
   this species from all other congeners.

   CZ-77146, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

TI Review of the genus Elasmus Westwood (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) in Israel
   with description of a new species.
AU Yefremova, Zoya (eulophids@mail.ru) 
   Strakhova, Irina
SO Israel Journal of Entomology
VL 41-42
PS 221-237
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the genus Elasmus Westwood (Eulophidae) in Israel is
   presented for the first time. Twelve species are included and keyed, 11
   of which are newly recorded from Israel. Elasmus aternalis is described
   as new to science. The most common species are E. flabellatus
   (Fonscolombe), E. nudus (Nees), E. viridiceps Thomson and E. westwoodi
   Giraud. Elasmus africanus Ferriere is a rare species and Israel is the
   third country in which it was collected.

DT Article
TI A New Species of Genus Anelpistina and the Second Described Nicoletiid
   (Zygentoma: Insecta) Species from the Mayan Ruins of Palenque, Chiapas,
   Mexico.
AU Espinasa, Luis (luis.espinasa@marist.edu) 
   Collins, Emily
   Socci, Kimberly
SO ISRN Zoology
SU Article ID 802371
PS 1-4
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent studies on the American nicoletiid insects ("silverfish") of the
   subfamily Cubacubaninae have shown that the group is more species rich
   than previously recognized. It has become common to find that a single
   locality is inhabited by more than one species of nicoletiid. In
   previous studies, a species from genus Squamigera had been described
   from the rainforest surrounding the Mayan ruins of Palenque, Chiapas,
   Mexico. We report here the presence of two more species of nicoletiids
   in the same locality and we describe here a new species of genus
   Anelpistina. DNA sequence data and morphology are provided to
   differentiate these species.
C1 Espinasa, Luis; Marist Coll, Sch Sci, 3399 North Rd, Poughkeepsie, NY,
   12601, USA, USA.
EM luis.espinasa@marist.edu

   America

DT Article
TI Pathological and Parasitological Findings in South American Fur Seal
   Pups (Arctocephalus australis) in Uruguay.
AU Katz, Helena (helekatz@gmail.com) 
   Morgades, Diana
   Castro-Ramos, Miguel
SO ISRN Zoology
SU Article ID 586079
PS 1-7
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper presents the necropsy findings in South American fur seal
   (Arctocephalus australis) pups from Uruguayan colonies. Animals (n =
   105) were aged between 0 and 18 months old. From 0 to 6 months, 69.4% of
   the pups showed a poor body condition, while 68.8% of animals from 7 to
   18 months had fair-to-good body condition. From 6 to 7 months of age,
   the stomach content included fishes, crustaceans, and foreign bodies.
   Starvation in the first months of life and traumatic lesions in pups
   older than 9 months were the most frequent causes of death. Uncinaria
   spp. was the only parasite found in the small intestine between 0 and 6
   month-old pups. Parasites with indirect cycle (Contracaecum spp.,
   Corynosoma sp., Tetrabothriidae) were present from 6 months of age as
   well as the first report of the nematode Strongyloides spp. in
   pinnipeds. Orthohalarachne spp. was found in the respiratory tract.
   Mycobacterium pinnipedii was isolated from 9 animals without gross
   pathological lesions. Other pathological conditions were found in lesser
   extent. This information contributes to the main causes of death of A.
   australis pups at different ages and could be useful to perform further
   health studies on this wild pinniped species.
C1 Katz, Helena; Univ Republ, Area Patol, Ave Lasplaces 1550, Montevideo,
   11600, Uruguay, Uruguay.
EM helekatz@gmail.com
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Pathology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 2090-522X
BD Nutrition; Parasites diseases and disorders; Ecology; Population
   dynamics; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Arctocephalus australis [Starvation /  / new record; pathology]
   [Diseases and disorders / Necropsy / ] [Mortality / Death rate / ]
   [South Atlantic / Uruguay, Maldonado & Rocha / ]. 
TN Carnivores; Chordates; Mammals; Pinnipeds; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Carnivora, Otariidae
OR Arctocephalus australis (Otariidae): [New record].

TI A New Species of the Genus Garra Hamilton, 1822 from the Chindwin Basin
   of Manipur, India (Teleostei: Cyprinidae: Labeoninae).
AU Shangningam, Bungdon
   Vishwanath, Waikhom (wvnath@gmail.com) 
SO ISRN Zoology
SU Article ID 325064
PS 1-6
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Garra namyaensis sp. nov., a new cyprinid fish, is described from the
   Chindwin River basin in Manipur, India. It is distinguished from its
   congeners in having a unique combination of the following characters:
   smoothly rounded snout tip with a prominent rostral lobe, chest and
   abdominal region with scales, dorsal fin with a black band near the
   posterior margin, and caudal fin with a distinct W-shaped black band.

TI A new species of Lethrus Scop., 1777 (Coleoptera: Geotrupidae) from

LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Lethrus (Furcilethrus) paki sp. n. is described on the big series
   collected in 2011 in Baljuvon vicinities (Vakhsh Ridge, Tajikistan). The
   new species is related to L. banghaasi Reitter, 1893, L. tadzhicorum
   Medvedev, 1959 and L. saryhissoricus Nikolajev, 1987, but can be
   distinguished easily by shape of right mandibular process, which is
   kinking upward and inward.

PT J
AN ZOOR15101005166
DT Article
TI [Lepidoptera of Woerschacher Moos Natura 2000 protected area (Styria) -
   endangered biodiversity.]
FT Schmetterlinge (Lepidoptera) des Natura 2000-Schutzgebietes Woerschacher
   Moos (Steiermark) - eine gefaehrdete Vielfalt.
AU Huemer, Peter (p.huemer@tiroler-landesmuseen.at) 
SO Joannea Zoologie
VL 12
PS 49-98
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB During the vegetation periods 2009 (late May to late September) and 2010
   (mid-April to mid-June) 558 species of butterflies and moths
   (Lepidoptera) have been recorded in the area of the Natura 2000 site
   Worschacher Moos (Worschach, Styria) together with earlier data of 21
   species. Eight species are new records for Styria: Micropterix
   osthelderi HEATH, 1975, Eriocrania sangii (WOOD, 1891), Eriocrania sp.,
   Coleophora glitzella HOFMANN, 1869, Coleophora hieronella ZELLER, 1849,
   Teleiodes flavimaculella (HERRICH-SCHAFFER, 1854), Syncopacma wormiella
   (WOLFF, 1958), Epermenia falciformis (HUBNER, 1813). Altogether 25
   species are protected by the regional conservation bylaw, including
   Euphydryas aurinia, a species protected by the fauna flor habitat
   directive of the EU. 48 endangered species are listed in the Red Data
   Book of Styria. An analysis of ecological guilds proves the dominance of
   mesophilous species from woodland habitats and ecotone. 54 species of
   Lepidoptera are restricted to wetland habitats and further seven species
   to bogs. Conservation problems are related to urban waste, drainage and
   fertilization. A list of conservation measures to be taken is discussed
   in detail.
C1 Huemer, Peter; Tiroler Landesmuseum Betriebsges.m.b.H.,
   Naturwissenschaftliche Sammlungen, Feldstrasse 11 a, 6020 Innsbruck,
   Austria, Austria.

TI A new species of Heterolacurbs (Opiliones: Biantidae: Stenostygninae)
   from Puerto Rico.
AU Alegre Barroso, Aylin (aylinalegre@gmail.com) 
   de Armas, Luis F.
SO Journal of Arachnology
VL 40
IS 3
PS 291-295
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Biantidae belonging to the genus Heterolacurbs Roewer
   1912 is herein described. Heterolacurbs perezassoi new species from
   Puerto Rico, Greater Antilles, is the second species included in the
   genus, and it is clearly recognized by the pair of large spiniform
   apophyses on area IV that does not restrain area III of the dorsal
   scutum, the smooth legs, femora 11 IV without dorsodistal spine, its
   tarsal formula, sternites with small tubercles and penis that exhibits a
   distinctive morphology.

PT J
AN ZOOR15003013439
DT Article
TI Bycatch of the Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops aduncus) in
   gillnet fisheries off Amakusa-Shimoshima Island, Japan.
AU Shirakihara, Miki (mikishirak@me.com) 
   Shirakihara, Kunio
SO Journal of Cetacean Research and Management
VL 12
IS 3
PS 345-351
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A year-round resident population of the Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin
   (Tursiops aduncus) inhabits the waters off Amakusa-Shimoshima Island
   (32[degree]25'N, 130[degree]05'E), in Japan. The effect of bycatch in
   gillnet fisheries on the Amakusa population was examined. Population
   size in 2007 and 2008 was estimated at 230 individuals (CV = 2.5%) and
   216 individuals (CV = 2.1%), respectively, based on a mark-recapture
   technique. The magnitude of bycatch was evaluated by analysing interview
   surveys (263 gillnetters) during these two years. Minimum numbers of
   dolphin bycatch were 12 individuals in 2007 and 14 individuals in 2008.
   Most of the dolphins, which were captured by bottom-set gillnets, were
   considered to be Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins for the following
   reasons: (1) two individuals were identified based on DNA analysis; (2)
   only Tursiops sp. and finless porpoises were found in the sighting
   survey by ferry boats, and fishermen can distinguish between the two;
   and (3) the seasonal and spatial distribution of bycatch corresponded
   well to habitat use patterns of the Amakusa population. If the US
   potential biological removal (PBR) approach is used it estimates two
   individuals per year, which is much lower than the minimum bycatch
   numbers of 12-14 individuals per year (5.2-6.5% of abundance estimates).
   Reducing bycatch mortality caused by bottom-set gillnets is essential
   for the effective conservation of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins in
   Amakusa, Japan.
C1 Shirakihara, Miki; Toho Univ, Fac Sci, Funabashi, Chiba, 2748510, Japan,
   Japan.
EM mikishirak@me.com
SC Fisheries; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity
   &Conservation
SN 1561-0713
BD Animals and man; Disturbance by man; Commercial activities;
   Conservation; Ecology; Population dynamics; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Tursiops aduncus [Fishing and fisheries / Gillnet fishery bycatch / ]
   [Conservation measures /  / ] [Mortality /  / ] [Population size /
   Abundance / ] [Distribution within habitat / Seasonal & spatial
   distribution / ] [Accidental entrapment /  / ] [North Pacific / Japan,
   Kyushu, Amakusa / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Cetacea, Delphinidae
OR Tursiops aduncus (Delphinidae).

PT J
AN ZOOR15103015635
DT Article
TI Uncus shaped akin to elephant tusks defines a new genus for two very
   different-in-appearance Neotropical skippers (Hesperiidae: Pyrginae).
AU Grishin, Nick V. (grishin@chop.swmed.edu) 
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 45
PS 101-112
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Analyses of male genitalia, other aspects of adult, larval and pupal
   morphology, and DNA COI barcode sequences suggest that Potamanaxas
   unifasciata (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1867) does not belong to Potamanaxas
   Lindsey, 1925 and not even to the Erynnini tribe, but instead is more
   closely related to Milanion Godman & Salvin, 1895 and Marries Godman &
   Salvin, 1897, (Achlyodini). Unexpected and striking similarities are
   revealed in the male genitalia of P unifasciata and Atarnes hierax
   (Hopffer, 1874). Their genitalia are so similar and distinct from the
   others that one might casually mistake them for the same species.
   Capturing this uniqueness, a new genus Eburuncus is erected to include:
   E. unifasciata, new combination (type species) and E. hierax, new
   combination.
C1 Grishin, Nick V.; Univ Texas SW Med Ctr Dallas, Howard Hughes Med Inst,
   5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas, TX, 75390, USA, USA.
EM grishin@chop.swmed.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0022-4324
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae
OR Atarnes hierax - (Hopffer 1874) (Hesperiidae): [Referred to, New genus
   Eburuncus, p. 106]. 
   Eburuncus (Hesperiidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Pyrginae, Type species
   Leucochitonea unifasciata C. Felder & R. Felder 1867, p. 106]. 
   Eburuncus hierax - (Hopffer 1874) (Hesperiidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Atarnes, p. 106]. 
   Eburuncus unifasciata - (C. Felder & R. Felder 1867) (Hesperiidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Potamanaxas, p. 106]. 
   Leucochitonea unifasciata - C. Felder & R. Felder 1867 (Hesperiidae):
   [Designated type species for new genus, Eburuncus, p. 106]. 
   Potamanaxas unifasciata - (C. Felder & R. Felder 1867) (Hesperiidae):
   [Referred to, New genus Eburuncus, p. 106].

DT Article
TI A new species of Neodactria Landry, 1995 (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae,
   Crambinae) from Arizona, USA.
AU Landry, Bernard (bernard.landry@ville-ge.ch) 
   Albu, Valeriu
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 45
PS 113-118
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB So far only two species of Neodactria Landry have been found in the
   state of Arizona: N. luteolellus (Clemens, 1860) and Neodactria
   cochisensis Landry & Albu, sp. n. described and illustrated here from
   the Huachuca and Chiricahua Mountains of Cochise County. It differs from
   the other members of the genus most conspicuously by the curved and
   dorsally projecting costal process of the valva and in the female by the
   diminutive anterior apophyses and the regularly cylindrical corpus
   bursae.

   described: Mirekiana gen. nov. with the type species Cleigastra anthrax
   Schiner, 1864. Mirekiana anthrax (Schiner, 1864) comb. nov. from the

PT J
AN ZOOR15006032287
DT Article
TI Diversity of Copepods in Pak Phanang Bay, Nakhon Si Thammarat Province.
AU Anonymous
SO KKU Science Journal
VL 40
IS 1
PS 281-292
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study of copepod diversity in Pak Phanang Bay was carried out in
   the wet and dry seasons of 2007 and 2008. Zooplankton samples were
   collected horizontally with a 330 [mu]m-mesh net. Twenty eight species
   of copepods from 18 genera were recorded. Pseudodiaptomus annandalei
   Sewell was the dominant species with an average density of 97% of total
   copepod density in the wet season and 76% of total copepod density in
   the dry season with the maximum density in Pak Nakhon estuary. Acartia
   plumosa Scott was recorded in Pak Phanang estusry and Pak Nakhon estuary
   in the dry season only while Calanopia australica Bayly & Greenwood,
   Labidocera minuta Giesbrecht, Pontellopsis sp., Subeucalanus subtenuis
   Giesbrecht and Centropagas furcipatus Dana inhabited only the seaward
   area of the bay near Laem Talumphuk. Five species of copepods from Pak
   Panang Bay, Pseudodiaptomus incisus Shen & Lee, P. trihamatus Wright,
   Subeucalanus subtenuis Giesbrecht, Pontellopsis sp. and Caligus sp.,
   were discovered as new records in Thai waters.
SC Zoology
SN 0125-2364
BD Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Caligus; Pontellopsis; Pseudodiaptomus incisus; Pseudodiaptomus
   trihamatus; Subeucalanus subtenuis [North Pacific / Thailand, Nakhon Si
   Thammarat, Pak Phanang Bay / New record]. 
   Copepoda [North Pacific / Thailand, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Pak Phanang Bay
   / Faunal list].

PT J
AN ZOOR15006032288
DT Article
TI Algae-Living Gammarid Amphipods of South Sea Islands Marine National
   Park, Nakhon Si Thammarat Province.
AU Anonymous
SO KKU Science Journal
VL 40
IS 1
PS 293-302
PD Jan 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Gammaridean amphipods were collected from 4 stations of algal bed from
   South Sea Islands Marine National Park in March 2008. A total of 14
   species from 9 families were reported. The Families Hadziidae and
   Photidae were the most diverse in species richness (3 species each). The
   common and dominant species were Paradusa bilobata and Podocerus
   andamanensis found in all stations. Anamixis sp., Malacoota sp. and
   Hyale sp. were found only at Rab Island and Maera quadrimana occurred
   only at Tan Island. Rab Island contained the most diverse gammarid
   amphipod species following by Tan, Tharai and Wangnok Islands, 12, 8, 6
   and 5 species respectively. Nine species were new records from the Gulf
   of Thailand and South China Sea i.e. Ampithoe ramondi, Paradusa
   bilobata, Anamixis sp., Maera quadrimana, Isaeopsis tenax, Gammaropsis
   abotti, Grandidierella megnaem, Podocerus andamanensis, and Tethygeneia
   khanomensis.
SC Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology

   andamanensis; Tethygeneia khanomensis. [North Pacific / Gulf of Thailand
   & South China Sea / New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15307040567
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI An updated checklist of currently accepted species of Enchytraeidae
   (Oligochaeta, Annelida).
AU Schmalz, Rudiger M. (rutco@udc.es) 
   Collado, Rut
SO Landbauforschung-vTI Agriculture and Forestry Research Sonderheft
VL 357
PS 67-87
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB An updated checklist of all currently accepted species of Enchytraeidae
   (Oligochaeta, Clitellata, Annelida) is presented. The list comprises 676
   species, which add up to 715 species-group taxa when subspecies and
   controversial species are included. Species-richest genera are
   Fridericia (99 species) and Marionina (96 species), followed by
   Lumbricillus (80 species), Mesenchytraeus (76 species), and Grania (71
   species). Six genera are monospecific. Given the generally poor
   knowledge of Enchytraeidae in most regions on earth, these numbers most
   probably represent only a minute fraction of the actual diversity, but
   reasonable estimates as to the actual number of enchytraeid species are
   not possible at present. For reasons of homonymy, Henlea dicksoni
   (Nurminen, 1980) and Henlea irkutensis (Nurminen, 1980) are renamed into
   Henlea dicksoniana and Henlea irkutiana, respectively.
C1 Schmalz, Rudiger M.; Univ A Coruna, Fac Sci, Rua Fraga 10, A Coruna,
   15008, Spain, Spain.
EM rutco@udc.es
SC Zoology
SN 0376-0723

   Taxonomic position; Documentation; Publications
DE Enchytraeidae [Checklists / Updated taxonomic checklist / ].

ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Bryodrilus arctica - (Bell 1962) (Oligochaeta): [Spelling, P. 68]. 
   Bryodrilus arcticus - (Bell 1962) (Oligochaeta): [Spelling, P. 68]. 
   Buchholzia - Michaelsen 1886 (Oligochaeta): [Publication date, P. 68]. 
   Enchytraeidae (Oligochaeta). 
   Fridericia christofferseni - (Righi 1975) (Oligochaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Timmodrilus, p. 68]. 
   Henlea dicksoni - (Nurminen 1980) (Oligochaeta): [Preoccupied name
   replaced by, Henlea dicksoniana, p. 68]. 
   Henlea dicksoniana (Oligochaeta): [Nom nov, For Henlea dicksoni
   (Nurminen 1980), p. 68]. 
   Henlea irkutensis - (Nurminen 1980) (Oligochaeta): [Preoccupied name
   replaced by, Henlea irkutiana, p. 68]. 
   Henlea irkutiana (Oligochaeta): [Nom nov, For Henlea irkutensis
   (Nurminen 1980), p. 68]. 
   Marionina litterata - (Hesse 1893) (Oligochaeta): [Status, P. 68]. 
   Timmodrilus christofferseni - (Righi 1975) (Oligochaeta): [Referred to,
   Fridericia, p. 68].

TI Macratriinae (Coleoptera: Anthicidae) of the Baltic amber.
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
SO Latvijas Entomologs
VL 51
PS 27-39
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Macratriinae (Coleoptera: Anthicidae) from Baltic amber
   is described and illustrated Macratria alleni sp. nov. The genus
   Protomacratria ABDULLAH, 1964 is placed as a junior synonym of Macratria
   NEWMAN, 1838. A key to fossil species of Macratriinae is presented for
   the first time. Additional information on known species of Baltic amber
   Macratriinae is also provided.

AN ZOOR14912063433
DT Article
TI First report of metazoan fish parasites with zoonotic potential in
   Scomberomorus brasiliensis and Trichiurus lepturus from the coastal
   waters of Rio Grande do Norte, Brazil.
AU Santos Cavalcanti, Elizete Teresinha
   Takemoto, Ricardo Massato
   Alves, Leucio Camara
   Chellappa, Sathyabama (chellappa.sathyabama63@gmail.com) 
SO Marine Biodiversity Records
VL 5
PS 1-4
PD 2012
PY 2012
NT Article e40.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study analysed samples of Serra Spanish mackerel,
   Scomberomorus brasiliensis and largehead hairtail, Trichiurus lepturus
   captured from the coastal waters of Rio Grande do Norte, Brazil, with a
   view to verify the occurrence of metazoan parasites related to public
   health in these fish and determine the parasitic indices and sites of
   infection. In S. brasiliensis, 28 nematode specimens of Contracaecum
   fortalezae were encountered in the branchial chamber and gonads with 20%
   prevalence. Besides 24 trematode specimens of Didymocystys sp. were
   found in the tegument, muscles and branchial chamber with 40%
   prevalence. In T. lepturus, a nematode Hysterothylacium sp. was found in
   the intestine, with a prevalence of 33.33% and 641 digenetic specimens
   of Catarinatrema verrucosum were found in the tegument, branchial
   chamber and stomach, with a prevalence of 100%. The occurrence of the
   parasitic members of the family Anisakidae and the digenetic trematodes
   of the families Hemuridae and Didymozoidae have zoonotic potential and
   are related to public health since the fish hosts are of commercial
   importance.
C1 Chellappa, Sathyabama; Univ Fed Rio Grande Norte UFRN, Dept Oceanog &
   Limnol, Campus Univ Lagoa Nova, Natal, RN, BR-59072970 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM chellappa.sathyabama63@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1755-2672
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Ecology; Population dynamics; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Catarinatrema verrucosum; Hysterothylacium [Piscean hosts / Trichiurus
   lepturus / New record; prevalence] [Population size /  / ] [South
   Atlantic / Brazil, Rio Grande do Norte / ]. 
   Contracaecum fortalezae; Didymocystys [Piscean hosts / Scomberomorus
   brasiliensis / New record; prevalence] [Population size /  / ] [South
   Atlantic / Brazil, Rio Grande do Norte / ]. 
   Scomberomorus brasiliensis [Digenean parasites / Didymocystys / New
   record; prevalence] [Nematode parasites / Contracaecum fortalezae / ]
   [South Atlantic / Brazil, Rio Grande do Norte / ]. 
   Trichiurus lepturus [Digenean parasites / Catarinatrema verrucosum / New
   record; prevalence] [Nematode parasites / Hysterothylacium / ] [South
   Atlantic / Brazil, Rio Grande do Norte / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Scombridae, Trichiuridae, Nematoda, Platyhelminthes,
   Trematoda, Digenea
OR Scomberomorus brasiliensis (Scombridae): [Host; New record]. 
   Trichiurus lepturus (Trichiuridae): [Host; New record]. 
   Contracaecum fortalezae (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Hysterothylacium (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Catarinatrema verrucosum (Digenea): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Didymocystys (Digenea): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063433

PT J
AN ZOOR14807047113
DT Article
TI Two new gorgonian species (Anthozoa: Octocorallia: Gorgoniidae) from
   Ecuador (Eastern Pacific).
AU Del Mar Soler-Hurtado, Maria (mar.s.hurtado@gmail.com) 
   Lopez-Gonzalez, Pablo J.
SO Marine Biology Research
VL 8
IS 4
PS 380-387
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Two new gorgonian species of the gorgoniid genera Eugorgia and
   Leptogorgia are described from Los Ahorcados (Ecuador, Eastern Pacific).
   The distinctive features of Eugorgia ahorcadensis sp. nov. are the
   brownish-orange colour of the colony, the polyp-mounds (slightly raised
   with red rings) and the coenenchymal sclerites (red, yellow, some
   bicoloured, abundant spindles and disc-spindles with the presence of
   capstans, but no complete double discs or crosses). The new species is
   compared with its closest congeners, the Eastern Pacific species E.
   ampla and E. bradleyi. The distinctive features of Leptogorgia
   mariarosacea sp. nov. are: the red colony colour, the prominent
   polyp-mounds and the coenenchymal sclerites (red, no bicoloured
   sclerites, spindles abundant, capstans present, but no crosses). The new
   species is compared with its closest congeners, the Eastern Pacific
   species L. aequatorialis and L. diffusa.
C1 Del Mar Soler-Hurtado, Maria; Univ Sevilla, Fac Biol, Reina Mercedes 6,
